ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: Breaking news. More than a dozen women arrested as thousands of women staged what was supposed to be peaceful pro- women rallies and walkouts across the country for the controversial day without a woman protest. It turned into an anti-Trump march.

Welcome to Risk and Reward. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald, in for Deirdre Bolton.

Women across the country walked off the job. White collar workers, blue collar workers, government workers, and teachers. One teacher in Philadelphia says it's about demonstrating support for the value of women.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I think this is a big year for us women. We need to prove that we are a big part of this economy and we're a big part of our nation. So, I'm glad that we could get together today and speak on behalf of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: But was that always the case, because in order to show the vital role that women played in all fascist of this nation, the rally organizers said women must leave their jobs for the day to protest President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Trump does not have respect for women. But he also doesn't know the power of women. By the time why Trump and republicans to diminish women we know our value and we know that America doesn't function without us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Not every woman was on board with the statements like this. We have also working moms and working parents telling that they were struggling to get by and that they're now upset that their children were left stranded with some schools cancelling classes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm appalled that they just made this decision because people don't have the luxury like me and my family to have someone at home with the kids. Some people working two or three jobs, some people don't have the resources to hire a babysitter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: And it's not just teachers, government workers including house democrats whose salaries are paid with your tax dollars they walked off the job joining rallies in Washington, D.C. to show support. It's all part of a plan set by the organizers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The color red signifies revolutionary love.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Action and our pioneering spirit.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number two, strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three. Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With the exception of small, and women and minority- owned business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. You can agree or disagree with that. But while the protestors and organizers say they're about the moral authority of empowering women, among the organizers and speakers at these women marchers are three murderers. One a convicted terrorist involved in the murder of two students.

Another in (Inaudible) starts a homicide it was on the FBI's 10 most wanted list. And still another convicted felon involved in the kidnapping, rape and murder of a gay man. Conspicuously missing from the list of the women inspiring marches like this.

Democrats like Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren, more on that coming up. My first guest is here to talk about how teachers were walking out to send and anti-Trump message.

Let's bring in Bre Payton, reporter for the Federalist. Bre, was this a woman's rally or an anti-Trump protest?

BRE PAYTON, THE FEDERALIST REPORTER: I think it's pretty clear tha this was an anti-Trump protest. The catalyst behind all these subsequent marches, and day without women, and strikes, and et cetera, et cetera, is Donald Trump's electoral victory, right, and I think pretending otherwise isn't really tricking anyone.

I think we all know that this is an anti-Donald Trump rally. And I think we know that a lot of these districts overwhelmingly vote -- the districts that closed the schools today they overwhelmingly voted for Hillary Clinton. And in some cases they didn't really need to close the doors. They could have still let kids into the classroom and allowed parents to go to work today, right.

MACDONALD: But Bre, stay on that. Are you saying that your team found the schools did have enough workers to stay open but they still shut their doors today? Wasn't that stranding working families, including single moms who work?

PAYTON: Yes, that's exactly what I'm saying. And I think a lot of the school districts are kind of enabling the strike instead of cracking down and saying no you need to show up for work. This is paid for and funded by taxpayer dollars. We need to provide the servants that we promised to provide to parents, instead of cracking down and being tough and doing their jobs, they decided to fold and enable teachers to allow then to protest the president, right. I mean, this is completely absurd.

MACDONALD: Yes. Bre, when teachers and government workers don't show up don't pack -- taxpayers have to pay extra including for replacement workers? Yes, protesting is a fundamental American right. You know, women, of course you want to support women and getting the pay that they deserve. But should protests like this be done on one's own time, say on the weekend when taxpayers aren't stuck with the bill?

PAYTON: Right. I mean, I would definitely think that if you're a taxpayer funded worker, that is if your paycheck is being funded by taxpayer dollars, you should do this on your own time and you should make them pay for it, right. I mean, that's why we have a lot of laws like the amendment in place that prevents taxpayer funding from going to abortion, right.

It's like a moral clause. In order to keep taxpayers for having to pay for things that they don't agree with. I don't agree with this protest and I'm upset that my taxpayers --my taxpayer dollars, you know, went to fund this kind of enable this behavior.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, you wonder if the parents as they agree with the teachers going to protest like this because protest organizers say that anyone questioning the goodness of communism, that communism acts should liberates people, or that Islam is really a feminist religion and it's good for women, anybody who says otherwise is an idiot or a racist. And they say capitalism is the problem when women are routinely brutalized under these regimes. What are your thoughts?

PAYTON: Right. Well, you know, my kid was in a classroom and a teacher called out to protest, to pay in this protest, I would think twice about sending them back to school the next day, right. And I myself I'm a product of home schooling because my parent didn't want to deal with indoctrinating in classrooms and teachers forcing an agenda down my throat, right.

So, I think a lot of parents are probably upset by this whole ideological battle that's being wage right now in classroom. And I think it's really unfair for, you know, 5-year-old kids to have to navigate or deal with this kind of propaganda that their teachers are pushing down their throats.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, I mean, some of this is really just tweaks deep accusations. You know, you see the accusations of sexism, racism, take your 'pickisms,' we get it. But they're letting in bad people like murderers and Islamists and communists. I mean, this really is a silly led by the sinister, right?

PAYTON: Yes. You're exactly right. And you know, this whole thing was supposed to be a grassroots-led movement. But it's pretty clear that it's not. It's pretty clear that there are very large organizations bankrolling this and that it is very well organize and that it is coming from the top down, right. It's not grassroots in any way, shape or form. And pretending that it is really just intellectually insulting.

MACDONALD: Bre Payton, you're always terrific. Please come back soon.

PAYTON: As always. I'll come back whenever.

MACDONALD: OK. Soon. Staying on this topic, the organizers of a day without women saying the women are encouraged to take the day off but avoid shopping.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three, avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three, avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With the exception of small, women and minority-owned businesses.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Some wondering if a group of men were protesting would not go shopping or wearing a color be on the list of things to do.

For that let's bring in the political power panel. Conservative Review Deneen Borelli, and democrat strategist Jennice Fuentes. Deneen, take off from work but don't work. Is that really the new feminist message?

DENEEN BORELLI, CONSERVATIVE REVIEW CORRESPONDENT: Liz, let me just tell you that I wore red today because I felt like it. I'm going shopping after this segment. And yes, I did work today. I was at the White House briefing. Liz, this is nothing but progressive activism women in skirts and dresses.

What people need to understand and realize is that America is an exceptional country. Anyone can succeed. We have women in all levels of all different jobs and responsibilities, whether it's television, entertainment, corporate America, you name it.

I worked hard to get where I am today to be on national television to talk about the policies and issues that I support. And for people to go out and protest industries the way that they are is absolutely ridiculous.

MACDONALD: Jennice, it's good to see you. The question has been, why should women get to walk off work to prove that women are equal to everyone else not able to take the day off. Isn't that kind of illogical and inconsistent? To some it's really impassively absurd because they just don't think that that's the way to go. What are your thoughts?

JENNICE FUENTES, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, there are short-term goals and there are long-term goals here. And I think that we all three of us women have the same goal in mind, in which we want to be treated like ladies but we want to get paid like men.

But what we have here is that they're all about their emotions, they're all about their ideology, and it supersedes logic.

Any reasonable person would agree that holding children's education hostage is really the wrong approach. It affects the -- it affects the families, it affects the parents, it affects the children. It's this very disruptive. And it affects poor children who rely on breakfasts and lunches at school.

MACDONALD: So, part of the school statement reads. "We support and appreciate our female workers. The decision to close schools with neither a statement nor an endorsement of the demonstration. It was entirely about our inability to insure the safety of students due to insufficient staffing."

Now, Mary, you are for equal pay for women, I take it, right, and for, you know, empowering women and getting women better jobs. And you know, doing - doing the right thing for women. But what did you make of the school's statement here?

CARTER: Well, I think frankly they're just lying. Because Durham Schools which is Durham County is right next door to Chapel Hill-Carrboro, the Orange County school system and they said they were going to open their doors. They were not going to close the doors on the children. So they made the decision that no, this is not acceptable and we are just going to keep our doors open and continue with school as usual.

MACDONALD: Why couldn't the schools just say, you know what, we're not going to allow the request to be absent. Shouldn't it -- you know, do they -- did that come up?

CARTER: Well, I think what is happening is that the administration is fully supporting this. So the thing is, you are seeing this in blue counties. And Chapel Hill-Carrboro Schools is in a very liberal area. And we are seeing it now in Virginia and in Maryland. Again, blue counties. So that tells you that's political.

MACDONALD: Mary, thank you so much for your time. I really appreciate it. Come back soon, OK?

CARTER: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Coming up, our very own Neil Cavuto has the first interview with Trump's labor secretary nominee Andy Puzder since he withdrew his name from his consideration. The details coming up, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Our own Neil Cavuto has the first interview with former Trump labor secretary nominee, Andrew Puzder since he withdrew his name from consideration. Tune in tomorrow at 12 p.m. Eastern Time for this exclusive.

Well, thank you for having us in your homes. Making Money with Charles Payne is next.

END

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: Breaking news. More than a dozen women arrested as thousands of women staged what was supposed to be peaceful pro- women rallies and walkouts across the country for the controversial day without a woman protest. It turned into an anti-Trump march.

Welcome to Risk and Reward. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald, in for Deirdre Bolton.

Women across the country walked off the job. White collar workers, blue collar workers, government workers, and teachers. One teacher in Philadelphia says it's about demonstrating support for the value of women.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I think this is a big year for us women. We need to prove that we are a big part of this economy and we're a big part of our nation. So, I'm glad that we could get together today and speak on behalf of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: But was that always the case, because in order to show the vital role that women played in all fascist of this nation, the rally organizers said women must leave their jobs for the day to protest President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Trump does not have respect for women. But he also doesn't know the power of women. By the time why Trump and republicans to diminish women we know our value and we know that America doesn't function without us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Not every woman was on board with the statements like this. We have also working moms and working parents telling that they were struggling to get by and that they're now upset that their children were left stranded with some schools cancelling classes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm appalled that they just made this decision because people don't have the luxury like me and my family to have someone at home with the kids. Some people working two or three jobs, some people don't have the resources to hire a babysitter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: And it's not just teachers, government workers including house democrats whose salaries are paid with your tax dollars they walked off the job joining rallies in Washington, D.C. to show support. It's all part of a plan set by the organizers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The color red signifies revolutionary love.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Action and our pioneering spirit.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number two, strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three. Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With the exception of small, and women and minority- owned business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. You can agree or disagree with that. But while the protestors and organizers say they're about the moral authority of empowering women, among the organizers and speakers at these women marchers are three murderers. One a convicted terrorist involved in the murder of two students.

Another in (Inaudible) starts a homicide it was on the FBI's 10 most wanted list. And still another convicted felon involved in the kidnapping, rape and murder of a gay man. Conspicuously missing from the list of the women inspiring marches like this.

Democrats like Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren, more on that coming up. My first guest is here to talk about how teachers were walking out to send and anti-Trump message.

Let's bring in Bre Payton, reporter for the Federalist. Bre, was this a woman's rally or an anti-Trump protest?

BRE PAYTON, THE FEDERALIST REPORTER: I think it's pretty clear tha this was an anti-Trump protest. The catalyst behind all these subsequent marches, and day without women, and strikes, and et cetera, et cetera, is Donald Trump's electoral victory, right, and I think pretending otherwise isn't really tricking anyone.

I think we all know that this is an anti-Donald Trump rally. And I think we know that a lot of these districts overwhelmingly vote -- the districts that closed the schools today they overwhelmingly voted for Hillary Clinton. And in some cases they didn't really need to close the doors. They could have still let kids into the classroom and allowed parents to go to work today, right.

MACDONALD: But Bre, stay on that. Are you saying that your team found the schools did have enough workers to stay open but they still shut their doors today? Wasn't that stranding working families, including single moms who work?

PAYTON: Yes, that's exactly what I'm saying. And I think a lot of the school districts are kind of enabling the strike instead of cracking down and saying no you need to show up for work. This is paid for and funded by taxpayer dollars. We need to provide the servants that we promised to provide to parents, instead of cracking down and being tough and doing their jobs, they decided to fold and enable teachers to allow then to protest the president, right. I mean, this is completely absurd.

MACDONALD: Yes. Bre, when teachers and government workers don't show up don't pack -- taxpayers have to pay extra including for replacement workers? Yes, protesting is a fundamental American right. You know, women, of course you want to support women and getting the pay that they deserve. But should protests like this be done on one's own time, say on the weekend when taxpayers aren't stuck with the bill?

PAYTON: Right. I mean, I would definitely think that if you're a taxpayer funded worker, that is if your paycheck is being funded by taxpayer dollars, you should do this on your own time and you should make them pay for it, right. I mean, that's why we have a lot of laws like the amendment in place that prevents taxpayer funding from going to abortion, right.

It's like a moral clause. In order to keep taxpayers for having to pay for things that they don't agree with. I don't agree with this protest and I'm upset that my taxpayers --my taxpayer dollars, you know, went to fund this kind of enable this behavior.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, you wonder if the parents as they agree with the teachers going to protest like this because protest organizers say that anyone questioning the goodness of communism, that communism acts should liberates people, or that Islam is really a feminist religion and it's good for women, anybody who says otherwise is an idiot or a racist. And they say capitalism is the problem when women are routinely brutalized under these regimes. What are your thoughts?

PAYTON: Right. Well, you know, my kid was in a classroom and a teacher called out to protest, to pay in this protest, I would think twice about sending them back to school the next day, right. And I myself I'm a product of home schooling because my parent didn't want to deal with indoctrinating in classrooms and teachers forcing an agenda down my throat, right.

So, I think a lot of parents are probably upset by this whole ideological battle that's being wage right now in classroom. And I think it's really unfair for, you know, 5-year-old kids to have to navigate or deal with this kind of propaganda that their teachers are pushing down their throats.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, I mean, some of this is really just tweaks deep accusations. You know, you see the accusations of sexism, racism, take your 'pickisms,' we get it. But they're letting in bad people like murderers and Islamists and communists. I mean, this really is a silly led by the sinister, right?

PAYTON: Yes. You're exactly right. And you know, this whole thing was supposed to be a grassroots-led movement. But it's pretty clear that it's not. It's pretty clear that there are very large organizations bankrolling this and that it is very well organize and that it is coming from the top down, right. It's not grassroots in any way, shape or form. And pretending that it is really just intellectually insulting.

MACDONALD: Bre Payton, you're always terrific. Please come back soon.

PAYTON: As always. I'll come back whenever.

MACDONALD: OK. Soon. Staying on this topic, the organizers of a day without women saying the women are encouraged to take the day off but avoid shopping.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three, avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three, avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With the exception of small, women and minority-owned businesses.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Some wondering if a group of men were protesting would not go shopping or wearing a color be on the list of things to do.

For that let's bring in the political power panel. Conservative Review Deneen Borelli, and democrat strategist Jennice Fuentes. Deneen, take off from work but don't work. Is that really the new feminist message?

DENEEN BORELLI, CONSERVATIVE REVIEW CORRESPONDENT: Liz, let me just tell you that I wore red today because I felt like it. I'm going shopping after this segment. And yes, I did work today. I was at the White House briefing. Liz, this is nothing but progressive activism women in skirts and dresses.

What people need to understand and realize is that America is an exceptional country. Anyone can succeed. We have women in all levels of all different jobs and responsibilities, whether it's television, entertainment, corporate America, you name it.

I worked hard to get where I am today to be on national television to talk about the policies and issues that I support. And for people to go out and protest industries the way that they are is absolutely ridiculous.

MACDONALD: Jennice, it's good to see you. The question has been, why should women get to walk off work to prove that women are equal to everyone else not able to take the day off. Isn't that kind of illogical and inconsistent? To some it's really impassively absurd because they just don't think that that's the way to go. What are your thoughts?

JENNICE FUENTES, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, there are short-term goals and there are long-term goals here. And I think that we all three of us women have the same goal in mind, in which we want to be treated like ladies but we want to get paid like men.

And I think that at this day and age it misses the biggest point, which most household in a family with children under 18 are led by women. And that woman makes at least 80 cents on the dollar that the men make. If that woman is a mother she makes 71 cents of that dollar that men makes. If that woman is a single mother she makes 58.

Whether you dress in red or you beg for some establishment who doesn't employ women and pay them right. This fight goes on beyond today. And that's what will unite all of us. Because at the end of the day women have to stand united to protect the wages. We have the real problem with that wage gap.

MACDONALD: Yes, Jennice.

FUENTES: And that absolutely needs to be solved.

MACDONALD: I hear exactly what you're saying. And in fact, yes, women should get paid equally as men. But Deneen, it seems like an anti-Trump protest. To Jennice's point, we've have a really bad economy where women are working multiple part-time jobs just to get by.

I mean, is this the way to go? It just seems that, you know, some of the things that they're saying at these marches are so off the wall about how communism is good and capitalism is bad. Go ahead.

BORELLI: Well, where were the protests with the Obama administration and females who got paid less than the male staffers under Obama's leadership. I mean, listen, this is where it's good to have smaller government, fiscal responsibility, and initiatives that will propel businesses to hire and grow their business and hire people, lower taxes, less regulations. These are the policies that President Trump is talking about in order to grow our economy and for job growth. And that is something that he ran on as president.

MACDONALD: All right. Let's switch gears. Protestors calling it a day for women, but was it just another anti-Trump protest?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We see women uncertain of their rights. We see anti- women and anti-abortion groups emboldened.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. Protestors saying they're worried about their rights. This as the president just signed two new laws helping NASA, and saying that NASA and to the NASA (Inaudible) nation, you know, push to get more women and girls involved in science math and related field.

Also, the president's daughter, Ivanka and the Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau with the president, they with a dozen CEO and business leaders to forge an international council women business leaders intending to support women in the workplace.

So, Jennice, I hear what they're saying about abortion and those rights and those issues. Setting that aside, I understand that. I get it. We're talking about economic growth and what you just said about women working part time. Is President Trump taking really taking away women's right when it comes to economic growth?

FUENTES: Well, they just say that I don't see anything that inspires me, or making me feel better about myself, for my nieces and for my sisters, and for men as well. I mean, we all have to stand united in here. But I would like to see very specific steps to help women, single women, especially and mothers, single mothers I meant, have a balance between work and family. Get those skills to basically grow their business. Get access to capital, get mentorship, get education.

It is very hard to make it in this world whether you have your own business or whether you work for others. And if you're a mom it's doubly hard. We already stay that you make 80 cents at the best situations, right?

BORELLI: Then you should with Trump policies...

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Jennice, I hear what you're saying.

FUENTES: But you know what, I would like to see something very specific. And the women marching today have the right to be heard. That's what so great about our country.

MACDONALD: OK. Jennice.

FUENTES: Now one march alone is not going to change everything. You know that.

MACDONALD: Right.

FUENTES: We all agree on that. This continues and this needs follow-up and this needs consistencies with Congress where the fight really needs to be fought.

MACDONALD: OK. Deneen, go ahead.

BORELLI: Then you should be in accordance with the policies that President Trump is urging in urban communities where the schools are failing children and there is a high crime rates and there are high unemployment rates. And so what we need to do our better school choice initiative avenues and also incentivize businesses to reinvest in these communities so people are employed. Whether they are mothers, fathers, single parents, you name it.

MACDONALD: All right. Deneen and Jennice, thank you so much. You are going to be back later.

FUENTES: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Now next up, is your TV, is your cell phone, even your car spying on you? WikiLeaks releasing a trove of documents showing how the CIA spies on you via your devices even if they are turned off.

A big name tech company's products have been allegedly compromised. We're talking Apple, Samsung, and Microsoft. They are upset and they're responding to the CIA. Hear what they have to say.

Also, can you guess which state is first out of the box trying to stop the president's refugee pause? The judge says that he would toss this suit due to its dubious assertions. He's going to explain that next, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEVIN NUNES, (R) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Look, this is early on in the investigation, but these appear to be very, very serious. We don't know who is responsible for this for what's happened in the latest WikiLeaks round. So, let's just leave it at that and let them come up and let them come out and brief you at the proper time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: WikiLeaks releasing a trove of CIA documents showing how it can spy on you via your devices. Now the leaks contain this. Techniques to break into smart phones, including iPhones using (TECHNICAL DIFFICULTY) listening devices, even if your TV is turned off. Instructions on how the CIA can use Skype, Wi-Fi networks, and anti-virus computer programs to spy on you as well. And details about how to steal your passwords over the internet.

Big tech companies like Apple, Samsung, Microsoft up and arms over WikiLeaks and CIA dump. They're mad at the CIA. Apple is saying this. "While our initial analysis indicates that many of the issues leaked today were already patched. We will continue to work rapidly to address any vulnerabilities."

Let's bring in the best expert around, the judge. Judge Andrew Napolitano. Are you worried about this?

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: I'm terrified about it. You know, we've been saying for years that the mobile phones that we all carry around in our pockets which now you can't turn off are actually listening devices.

Now we also know that the microchip in the microwave in your kitchen can be used as a listening device. That certain televisions when they're turned off they only looked like off that can be used as a listening and a monitoring device.

Here is -- here is the problem. All of this is unlawful. The CIA is not permitted to ply its trade in the United States of America unless they are chasing somebody from outside the United States into the U.S. The government is spying on us without suspicion, without probable cause, and without a warrant from a judge.

That's un-American, unconstitutional and ineffective. It doesn't keep us safe. It produces information overload. It produces so much info...

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: How much?

NAPOLITANO: If it were printers on ordinary printing paper like you have in front over here. It would be 27 times the size of the -- of the contents of the library of Congress every year since 2005. The government doesn't have the resources to go through all of that to look for the bad that's buried in the good.

That's the genius of the Constitution in the fourth amendment. The government is force to focus on people as to whom it has suspicion or believe a crime or a terrorist activity is occurring or is about to occur. When you focus on the bad people you leave everybody out alone. This is spying on everybody.

MACDONALD: Yes, but your point is, I hear your point. The argument is that we have to catch the terrorist here. The FBI is 900 active terror plots in all 50 states.

NAPOLITANO: The FBI does not do this. The FBI, as far as I can tell you, and I've been monitoring and working with them within my ears in the bench for years. The FBI when they want to listen to a conversation or otherwise surveil you, goes to a judge and presents probable cause and gets a warrant.

MACDONALD: But what's the CIA doing? They trying to get terrorists?

NAPOLITANO: The CIA is trying to gather all the information they can because their theory is if they gather everything it is more efficient than isolating the bad people. The problem with that is the Constitution requires the isolation of the bad people.

Go to Fox News.com the headline is "FBI Searches for CIA mole." How about the headline is, "FBI searches for CIA who have been spying on innocent Americans." That's what the FBI should be searching for. That's a felony to do it and WikiLeaks has demonstrated that it's been going on under our noses.

MACDONALD: Wow.

NAPOLITANO: Where's the outrage?

MACDONALD: And all the leaks that are coming out of the government about spying on people in government. Wow.

Switching gears, here's the state that is first out of the box suing the Trump administration over its new refugee pause. It's Hawaii. Hawaii wants to fight it out in court, calling this version of the order a quote, "Muslim ban."

Now the imam of the Muslim Association of Hawaii he's complaining. He is saying this. "This new version in the executive order inflicts a grave injury on Muslims in Hawaii, including the imam, his family and members of the mosque." Judge, is this a Muslim ban?

NAPOLITANO: It is not a Muslim ban. The government has removed all references to religion. It certainly falls disproportionately on Muslims but it is not written in order to keep Muslims out of the United States. The government articulates in the ban the reasons why the State Department has chosen these six countries.

It's really far more bulletproof than the first one is -- first one was. But this Hawaii lawsuit is filled with some of the most scurrilous attacks on President Trump that I have seen on a sitting president since the ending days of the, of Richard Nixon.

They have taken out of context the most incendiary things he said since long before he was even a candidate and trying to ascribe that to his motivation now. So they're taking something he said two and a half years ago and trying to say this is his motivation for today.

That's not an appropriate way for a court to evaluate the true motivation of the President of the United States. Because this is an area of the law uniquely given by the Constitution just to the president. It's foreign policy. He decides who our enemies are, he decides who our friends are. The Congress gives him tools. One of tools is temporary immigration bans. He's using those tools.

MACDONALD: If this came before you as a judge, what would you do?

NAPOLITANO: Well, I would -- I would dismiss it. Because the State of Hawaii is the plaintiff here. And the State of Hawaii can't show that it is harmed. You can't go into federal court just because you don't like what the government did. You have to show how you are harmed. The state has not been harmed at all.

MACDONALD: Judge, you're great. Please come back soon. We love you.

NAPOLITANO: I'm just delighted to be able to work with you.

MACDONALD: Always great to see you.

NAPOLITANO: Especially when it starts this the day, starts here and then Stuart.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Stuart Varney and you have to do...

NAPOLITANO: Does Varney around somewhere?

MACDONALD: No, you have to do the queen's accents next time with Varney.

NAPOLITANO: You got it.

MACDONALD: He loves it.

Next more, a sanctuary state fallout. An illegal immigrant repeatedly arrested. He was deported to Mexico five times. He's now charged in a deadly car crash in Los Angeles that killed a woman.

Also shockingly gruesome story involving another illegal immigrant. This time in North Carolina. That man accused of beheading his own mother. Next, the father whose daughter was killed by an illegal immigrant react, after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's just unbelievable. They had him handcuffed and he was just sitting there just like he didn't have a care in the world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Last month Sandra Duran killed in Los Angeles by a drunk driver. The driver an illegal immigrant deported to Mexico five times before. He had been arrested and charged with more than 20 felonies and misdemeanors including gun and drug possession and driving under the influence.

Joining me now, John Pina, another father whose daughter was also killed by an illegal immigrant. Mr. Pina, we are so sorry for your loss, and we are so upset we are asking you to do this. But, please, we want to inform the viewer, what happened to your 14-year-old daughter. Can you tell us?

JOHN PINA, CHRISTY PINA'S FATHER: Yes. She was found February 8, 1990. (AUDIO GAP) stabbed in artichoke -- they threw her body in artichoke field in Castroville, California.

MACDONALD: Now, Mr. Pina, correct us if we're wrong, but is it true that an arrest warrant for this illegal immigrant was not issued until 17 years later? And in the meantime, he committed many more crimes? What happened? Where is he now?

PINA: Back in '87 he had kidnapped two 14-year-old girls. One in July, he got put in jail, got out. And in September he came back and did kidnapped another one. And he got out again. And then he came back and he murdered my daughter. And then a few months later he came back and tried to kidnap a 12-year-old at 7 o'clock in the morning. And he's supposedly, supposed to be incarcerated in Mexico for Christy's murder.

MACDONALD: Is he in jail in prison right now, sir?

PINA: That's what I heard last. But I haven't heard anything in almost a year. So, I really don't know. They haven't informed me, or they haven't contacted me for a while. So, I really don't know. I can't tell you.

MACDONALD: Well, it's absolutely disgrace and it's horrifying. We are so upset for you and your family.

PINA: Thank you.

MACDONALD: And I got a story that came up, sir, we want to talk to you about it. In North Carolina an 18-year-old illegal immigrant charged this week with murder. Olivia Machado was decapitated by this man, her son. He decapitated his own mother with a butcher knife. Here's what he told authorities. He did it because he felt like it. Now he was taking medication for a psychosis schizophrenia. He was in the United States illegally. Should he have been deported, sir?

PINA: Well, he should never been here in the first place, and yes, he should have been deported. But now it's going to be kind of hard to get him deported because now the system is going to look at him and support him and take care of him while the taxpayers are out all that money. He should have never been here in the first place.

MACDONALD: Mr. Pina, how do you feel about what President Trump is doing versus what, how President Obama handled these problems.

PINA: Donald Trump, our President, I think is doing a great job. He's doing what he said he's going to do. I met with the man, he is sincere and he will accomplish what he set out to do.

MACDONALD: John Pina, thank you so much. And again, with your story, you are helping so many people across the country. It is so difficult and horrifying what you went through. But we're grateful you came on the show. Thank you again.

PINA: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Breaking news. Sources telling Fox News that Jon Huntsman, Jr. will be the next U.S. ambassador to Russia. President Trump reportedly calling Mr. Huntsman two days ago to offer him the job, and apparently, Mr. Huntsman accepted.

This appointment comes as President Trump and his cabinet being scrutinized for alleged ties to Russia and Vladimir Putin.

Next up, the results are in. The president crushing job expectation in his month in office. Find out how many U.S. jobs were added. It's a surprise and it was a surprise to Wall Street.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: He's going to bring all these jobs back? Well, how exactly is he going to do? What are you going to do? There is no answer to it. He just says, well, I'm going -- I'm going to negotiate a better deal. Well, how -- what -- how exactly are you going to negotiate that? What magic wand do you have?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's been a little over a month since my inauguration, and I want to take this moment to update the nation on the progress I've made in keeping those promises.

Since my election, Ford, Fiat Chrysler, General Motors, Sprint, Soft Bank, Lockheed, Intel, Wal-Mart, and many others, have announced that they will invest billions and billions of dollars in the United States and will create tens of thousands of new American jobs.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: President Trump's first full month in office bringing a massive employment boom. EDP reporting U.S. companies added a whopping 298,000 new jobs in February. That's 100,000 more jobs than Wall Street had predicted. That looks like 3 percent even 4 percent growth, to me, that's what the president promised.

The co-chair of America -- great -- excuse me -- the Great American Alliance, he's Eric Beach. He joins me now. Eric, what do you think of the blistering pace of jobs that were added last month?

ERIC BEACH, GREAT AMERICAN ALLIANCE CO-CHAIR: Look, I mean, the last two months has been the largest increase in job creation since September of 2015, and it's interesting, we talk about the promises that he ran on, now they're promises kept. So, I think, you know, much like the stock market the market doesn't lie. Job creation and job growth also doesn't lie. I think the president is just simply keeping his promises to the American people.

MACDONALD: Yes. The market likes -- it looks like it likes these policies. And companies are investing to create these jobs and these are good paying jobs, Eric. There are construction jobs up by 66,000. Manufacturing jobs up by 32,000.

President Obama repeatedly said, you know what, manufacturing jobs is not coming back. How is Trump going to do that? He can't do that. Was he wrong?

BEACH: He was wrong. And that's because he's never had a private sector job before. And so, I think what you're seeing is you really is a culture of confidence for the business community. For example, when Samsung is going to move and bring in -- relocate some of their operations into the U.S., you know, that's simply because maybe they are afraid of the border tax proposal. Maybe they just understand that there might a better corporate tax here inside the United States.

Whatever that might be, you know, the president is creating a culture of confidence and once again, the market sees that. Remember when the market was at 18,000 when he was elected. And we said, well, that was a psychological number for the Dow.

Well, today it's 21,000. It's grown 3,000 points. And again, the market, the business community, they understand that we have a business-friendly president and it's good for all Americans.

MACDONALD: But you know, NBC is already out with a headline, "Fact check, how many jobs has the Trump created?" It looks like the media is not ever going to give the president credit for any positive news.

BEACH: Well, they haven't. But that's not really the important thing. The media called the race wrong on November 8. The media continues to try to digress into different areas and say look, the president is not doing this, or it's private sector jobs.

When is the last time you heard he's only creating private sector jobs? When was the last time you've heard off? He's only creating private sector jobs. He's not really doing much for the public sector. But that's what he ran on.

The American people voted for Donald Trump for a variety of reasons. You know, they wanted to repeal and replace healthcare. They wanted to, you know, make sure we secure America first. And then also to create jobs and he's doing all three of those things right out of the box.

MACDONALD: You know, Reagan inherited, I think two recessions. He created something like 16 million or 17 million jobs. Clinton created 22 million jobs. So, President Obama keeps saying I inherited recession. He only created 10 million jobs, way worse than Reagan.

I think you guys look into it. And he created an ad than that highlight past presidents and their job performance. And also, not following through with their promises. What do you, how do you think President Trump will stack up?

BEACH: Look, I think it takes courage to be president. I think when he ran, you know, really the media and really a lot of the Washington elites, they said, you know, he really can't get those things done. We heard time and time again from both the punditry class as well as the democrats to say, he'll never really try to execute on this agenda.

Well, look, the group that we formed Great America Alliance, you know, we're out there to support the Trump agenda. Because voters overwhelmingly, especially the middle class voters in Wisconsin and in middle America and Michigan, and Pennsylvania, states in which he won, they have to understand that we got to have a better culture out there to make sure that the business -- you know, that's make sure it's business friendly.

And Donald Trump is bringing that to the table. His inauguration speech is one of the best speeches ever given. And I think he's going to execute on that. And it takes a lot of courage to execute on the agenda that a lot of the elites really have been trying to stymie.

MACDONALD: Eric Beach, always terrific. Come back soon, OK?

BEACH: Thanks for having me, Liz.

MACDONALD: Sure. The fallout continues. It turns out that one of the organizers of todays without women, day without woman, rather, where women worked off their jobs. She is a convicted terrorist accused of helping to kill two students in Israel.

Now the nice of one of her victims is now speaking out. We have what she said after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. As we discuss earlier in the show today's day without women is organized, help, basically supported by a convicted terrorist. Rasmea Odeh served 10 years in prison for her involvement in the 1969 terror bombing in Jerusalem which killed two Hebrew student.

Odeh was also later convicted at the immigration fraud. She basically didn't tell regulators here that she was involved in that bombing.

Now the niece of one of those victims speaking out condemning the protest for supporter a murderer saying it's a day without her father. Here's the quote. "What is the difference between the act -- the acts of Omar Mateen, the Boston marathon bombers and Rasmea Odeh? There's no difference. They all carried out acts of terror in the name of their causes which resulted in the death of innocent civilians."

My political panel is back with me now, Deneen Borelli and Jennice Fuentes. Deneen, isn't having a convicted terrorist involved in these marches is a slap in the face of these victims, isn't that sending the wrong message?

DENEEN BORELLI, CONSERVATIVE REVIEW CORRESPONDENT: Yes, and my heart goes out to the victims and their families. Listen, this is just absolutely off the charts outrageous, Liz. This is a convicted murder, a terrorist, a bomber who was basically been put on a pedestal.

I mean, what are the people who are involved in these events thinking to be praising someone with such a past? I mean, you can't ignore what this woman has done. And to put her, you know, on the pedestal to be praising her so to speak, I think speaks volumes. It's outrageous.

MACDONALD: You know, Jennice, the organizers and supporters also include the convicted felon Angela Davis, remember the communist party charge with homicide. Four people killed in that assault in the courtroom that she helped organized including a judge dead. Angela is in the middle of that shot.

Also Donna Hilton, she is a convicted felon along with others. She kidnapped a gay man and tortured him to death. I mean, isn't this contradictory to what the march stands for to have people like this involved?

JENNICE FUENTES, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: That's where our court exists.

MACDONALD: No, I'm talking about the march. I'm talking about rally. What are these women involved?

(CROSSTALK)

FUENTES: You know what, I'll tell you -- I'll tell you what is an outrageous scandal. I think what is an outrageous scandal is that primary, and I go back to my point because this is what matters.

MACDONALD: Now, Jennice, just answer the question.

(CROSSTALK)

FUENTES: It's what -- no, no, no.

MACDONALD: Jennice, I'm sorry. And please answer the question. Jennice.

FUENTES: Let me tell you what a scandal is this. The primary breadwinner...

BORELLI: She can't defend the murderer...

MACDONALD: Deneen, hang on. Jennice, answer the question. Jennice, answer the question. Isn't this going against what the march is about, having murderers involved?

FUENTES: The march is about women's parity in the workplace, isn't it. Its about equality. It's about the end of discrimination.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: So you're OK with these women being involved?

FUENTES: I didn't organize that march.

MACDONALD: Are you -- are you OK with being involved?

FUENTES: I'll have (Inaudible) because the courts will have a fine of the crimes of those women...

(CROSSTALK)

BORELLI: That answers your question, Liz.

MACDONALD: OK.

BORELLI: She is OK with it.

FUENTES: No. Listen, you're trying to create a big distraction to what scandal is this. No, you're trying to create a distraction.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: No, no, no. I'm asking you a flat-out question. Is it OK to have murders involved?

FUENTES: You guys are two women. Do you think it's fair that women have to wait 44 years to have pay parity with men?

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: We understand what you're saying.

FUENTES: Really? Is that what I should interpret your silence to try to deviate the question to that? It's nonsense.

MACDONALD: OK. Jennice, we hear what you're saying.

FUENTES: You're trying to create a distraction here.

MACDONALD: Jennice, is it OK -- Jennice, thank you, we appreciate that. Just hang on one second. Deneen, is it OK to have -- what kind of message does it have, does this bring -- to have three women who are convicted felons involved in murders, involved in a march.

BORELI: Yes, it's horrible. And for your guest to not even address your question, is this really outrageous. She's bought into it. These people are murderers, they're terrorists...

(CROSSTALK)

FUENTES: Excuse me, no.

MACDONALD: Jennice, hang on. Jennice, sorry.

FUENTES: You seemed to be distracted by that nonsense.

MACDONALD: Jennice, Jennice, Jennice...

BORELLI: You can't even answer the question.

MACDONALD: Jennice, we let you answer. We're going to let Deneen answer. Go again, Deneen.

BORELLI: Right. So these people are murderers, they're terrorists, they've been convicted. And for them to be on a pedestal just like I said before is absolutely outrageous. And it speaks volumes to people like your guest Jellice or whatever her name is. And people who are allowing...

(CROSSTALK)

FUENTES: My name is Jennice.

BORELLI: ... these individuals to have a voice is outrageous. What about the family members of the people who were murdered and killed. Innocent people, nine people were murdered and two were killed with this Rasmea woman. It's outrageous.

MACDONALD: All right. You know, Jennice, do stay with me one second.

BORELLI: And you should be ashamed to yourself.

MACDONALD: Jennice, two names missing to the list.

FUENTES: No. Excuse me. Can I address that?

MACDONALD: Jennice, please?

FUENTES: Yes.

MACDONALD: Why were Hillary Clinton and Senator Elizabeth Warren not listed among the women inspiring the events?

FUENTES: I wasn't an organizer and I cannot -- I cannot comment on that. I agree that if you've been convicted of a crime, you shouldn't be put in charge of any event that is public that is trying to inspire the message. But do not interpret my comments to be supporting criminals. That is what's absurd.

And to be sidelining the issue at hand, which is...

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: I'm not sideling the issue. Jennice, hang on.

FUENTES: ... the gap parity. Yes, it is.

MACDONALD: Jennice, forgive me. We're just asking you if you support murderers and it took -- it took you five about minutes to answer the question.

FUENTES: Excuse me, ladies.

MACDONALD: Let's switch gears. Over the weekend in Berkeley...

FUENTES: We were preceded by a segment above the markets.

MACDONALD: Sorry, Jennice, we're going to move on. We are going to have to cut your mic, Jennice if you don't stop. Now over the weekend in Berkeley 10 were arrested at pro-Trump rallies where rioters clash with the president supporters. And we have a pro-Trump mother who was accosted. She spoke out last night. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EVA PETERS, TRUMP SUPPORTER: Most of the protesters actually were just coming up to me and, you know, throwing the f bomb, f you, f Trump. They were very just rude, asking me why I liked Trump. He was a racist. That means I'm a racist. Telling me to get out of Berkeley. I don't belong there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. Jennice, what do you -- what do you make of the violence at protests like that. I mean, people really getting, it looked like they're getting hurt at those Berkeley protests, Jennice. Do you agree with that?

FUENTES: No, of course not.

MACDONALD: OK.

FUENTES: Violence is unacceptable at any level. And the fact that that's happening could not, that could not. And I feel bad for law enforcements, I feel bad for protesters who want to protest peacefully. Because you can disagree and still be very peaceful about it.

So, of course, nobody in their right mind would agree with having violence. Nothing. Violence could lead to nothing good. And I think all the three of us can agree on that.

MACDONALD: All right. Jennice, notice the color Deneen and I'm wearing, it's red. Deneen Borelli and Jennice Fuentes, thank you so much for your time.

BORELLI: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Next up, a day without women protests, the fallout continues. Residents of one North Carolina town blindsided after a school in their district decided to close for the day without woman protest. An angry resident and school district parent Mary Lopez Carter speaks out next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm appalled that they just made a decision because people don't have the luxury like me and my family to have someone at home with the kids. Some people working on two and three jobs. Some people don't have the resources to hire a babysitter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Residents of a North Carolina town upset after a school in their district decided to close for the day without women protest. The school cancelled classes calling today a teacher work day.

An angry resident and school district parent, Mary Lopez Carter joins me now. Mary, were you shocked when you heard they were closing schools for the protest?

MARY LOPEZ CARTER, PARENT ANGRY OVER SCHOOL CLOSING: I was beyond shocked and beyond angry about this.

MACDONALD: So what happened, so go ahead, Mary, tell us what happened.

CARTER: Well, it was all over Twitter and Facebook and that's how I found out about it. And then it just kind of spread from there.

MACDONALD: So, you know, working parents, working moms, working dads. I guess they unexpectedly had to take care of their children today, right.

CARTER: Exactly. Here's the thing. Teachers -- teaching is a profession. And if teachers want to be politicians then they should just leave their profession and go run for office. But what we have here is that they're all about their emotions, they're all about their ideology, and it supersedes logic.

Any reasonable person would agree that holding children's education hostage is really the wrong approach. It affects the -- it affects the families, it affects the parents, it affects the children. It's this very disruptive. And it affects poor children who rely on breakfasts and lunches at school.

MACDONALD: So, part of the school statement reads. "We support and appreciate our female workers. The decision to close schools with neither a statement nor an endorsement of the demonstration. It was entirely about our inability to insure the safety of students due to insufficient staffing."

Now, Mary, you are for equal pay for women, I take it, right, and for, you know, empowering women and getting women better jobs. And you know, doing - doing the right thing for women. But what did you make of the school's statement here?

CARTER: Well, I think frankly they're just lying. Because Durham Schools which is Durham County is right next door to Chapel Hill-Carrboro, the Orange County school system and they said they were going to open their doors. They were not going to close the doors on the children. So they made the decision that no, this is not acceptable and we are just going to keep our doors open and continue with school as usual.

MACDONALD: Why couldn't the schools just say, you know what, we're not going to allow the request to be absent. Shouldn't it -- you know, do they -- did that come up?

CARTER: Well, I think what is happening is that the administration is fully supporting this. So the thing is, you are seeing this in blue counties. And Chapel Hill-Carrboro Schools is in a very liberal area. And we are seeing it now in Virginia and in Maryland. Again, blue counties. So that tells you that's political.

MACDONALD: Mary, thank you so much for your time. I really appreciate it. Come back soon, OK?

CARTER: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Coming up, our very own Neil Cavuto has the first interview with Trump's labor secretary nominee Andy Puzder since he withdrew his name from his consideration. The details coming up, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Our own Neil Cavuto has the first interview with former Trump labor secretary nominee, Andrew Puzder since he withdrew his name from consideration. Tune in tomorrow at 12 p.m. Eastern Time for this exclusive.

Well, thank you for having us in your homes. Making Money with Charles Payne is next.

END

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: Breaking news. More than a dozen women arrested as thousands of women staged what was supposed to be peaceful pro- women rallies and walkouts across the country for the controversial day without a woman protest. It turned into an anti-Trump march.

Welcome to Risk and Reward. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald, in for Deirdre Bolton.

Women across the country walked off the job. White collar workers, blue collar workers, government workers, and teachers. One teacher in Philadelphia says it's about demonstrating support for the value of women.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I think this is a big year for us women. We need to prove that we are a big part of this economy and we're a big part of our nation. So, I'm glad that we could get together today and speak on behalf of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: But was that always the case, because in order to show the vital role that women played in all fascist of this nation, the rally organizers said women must leave their jobs for the day to protest President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Trump does not have respect for women. But he also doesn't know the power of women. By the time why Trump and republicans to diminish women we know our value and we know that America doesn't function without us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Not every woman was on board with the statements like this. We have also working moms and working parents telling that they were struggling to get by and that they're now upset that their children were left stranded with some schools cancelling classes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm appalled that they just made this decision because people don't have the luxury like me and my family to have someone at home with the kids. Some people working two or three jobs, some people don't have the resources to hire a babysitter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: And it's not just teachers, government workers including house democrats whose salaries are paid with your tax dollars they walked off the job joining rallies in Washington, D.C. to show support. It's all part of a plan set by the organizers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The color red signifies revolutionary love.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Action and our pioneering spirit.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number two, strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three. Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With the exception of small, and women and minority- owned business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. You can agree or disagree with that. But while the protestors and organizers say they're about the moral authority of empowering women, among the organizers and speakers at these women marchers are three murderers. One a convicted terrorist involved in the murder of two students.

Another in (Inaudible) starts a homicide it was on the FBI's 10 most wanted list. And still another convicted felon involved in the kidnapping, rape and murder of a gay man. Conspicuously missing from the list of the women inspiring marches like this.

Democrats like Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren, more on that coming up. My first guest is here to talk about how teachers were walking out to send and anti-Trump message.

Let's bring in Bre Payton, reporter for the Federalist. Bre, was this a woman's rally or an anti-Trump protest?

BRE PAYTON, THE FEDERALIST REPORTER: I think it's pretty clear tha this was an anti-Trump protest. The catalyst behind all these subsequent marches, and day without women, and strikes, and et cetera, et cetera, is Donald Trump's electoral victory, right, and I think pretending otherwise isn't really tricking anyone.

I think we all know that this is an anti-Donald Trump rally. And I think we know that a lot of these districts overwhelmingly vote -- the districts that closed the schools today they overwhelmingly voted for Hillary Clinton. And in some cases they didn't really need to close the doors. They could have still let kids into the classroom and allowed parents to go to work today, right.

MACDONALD: But Bre, stay on that. Are you saying that your team found the schools did have enough workers to stay open but they still shut their doors today? Wasn't that stranding working families, including single moms who work?

PAYTON: Yes, that's exactly what I'm saying. And I think a lot of the school districts are kind of enabling the strike instead of cracking down and saying no you need to show up for work. This is paid for and funded by taxpayer dollars. We need to provide the servants that we promised to provide to parents, instead of cracking down and being tough and doing their jobs, they decided to fold and enable teachers to allow then to protest the president, right. I mean, this is completely absurd.

MACDONALD: Yes. Bre, when teachers and government workers don't show up don't pack -- taxpayers have to pay extra including for replacement workers? Yes, protesting is a fundamental American right. You know, women, of course you want to support women and getting the pay that they deserve. But should protests like this be done on one's own time, say on the weekend when taxpayers aren't stuck with the bill?

PAYTON: Right. I mean, I would definitely think that if you're a taxpayer funded worker, that is if your paycheck is being funded by taxpayer dollars, you should do this on your own time and you should make them pay for it, right. I mean, that's why we have a lot of laws like the amendment in place that prevents taxpayer funding from going to abortion, right.

It's like a moral clause. In order to keep taxpayers for having to pay for things that they don't agree with. I don't agree with this protest and I'm upset that my taxpayers --my taxpayer dollars, you know, went to fund this kind of enable this behavior.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, you wonder if the parents as they agree with the teachers going to protest like this because protest organizers say that anyone questioning the goodness of communism, that communism acts should liberates people, or that Islam is really a feminist religion and it's good for women, anybody who says otherwise is an idiot or a racist. And they say capitalism is the problem when women are routinely brutalized under these regimes. What are your thoughts?

PAYTON: Right. Well, you know, my kid was in a classroom and a teacher called out to protest, to pay in this protest, I would think twice about sending them back to school the next day, right. And I myself I'm a product of home schooling because my parent didn't want to deal with indoctrinating in classrooms and teachers forcing an agenda down my throat, right.

So, I think a lot of parents are probably upset by this whole ideological battle that's being wage right now in classroom. And I think it's really unfair for, you know, 5-year-old kids to have to navigate or deal with this kind of propaganda that their teachers are pushing down their throats.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, I mean, some of this is really just tweaks deep accusations. You know, you see the accusations of sexism, racism, take your 'pickisms,' we get it. EVA PETERS, TRUMP SUPPORTER: Most of the protesters actually were just coming up to me and, you know, throwing the f bomb, f you, f Trump. They were very just rude, asking me why I liked Trump. He was a racist. That means I'm a racist. Telling me to get out of Berkeley. I don't belong there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. Jennice, what do you -- what do you make of the violence at protests like that. I mean, people really getting, it looked like they're getting hurt at those Berkeley protests, Jennice. Do you agree with that?

FUENTES: No, of course not.

MACDONALD: OK.

FUENTES: Violence is unacceptable at any level. And the fact that that's happening could not, that could not. And I feel bad for law enforcements, I feel bad for protesters who want to protest peacefully. Because you can disagree and still be very peaceful about it.

So, of course, nobody in their right mind would agree with having violence. Nothing. Violence could lead to nothing good. And I think all the three of us can agree on that.

MACDONALD: All right. Jennice, notice the color Deneen and I'm wearing, it's red. Deneen Borelli and Jennice Fuentes, thank you so much for your time.

BORELLI: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Next up, a day without women protests, the fallout continues. Residents of one North Carolina town blindsided after a school in their district decided to close for the day without woman protest. An angry resident and school district parent Mary Lopez Carter speaks out next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm appalled that they just made a decision because people don't have the luxury like me and my family to have someone at home with the kids. Some people working on two and three jobs. Some people don't have the resources to hire a babysitter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Residents of a North Carolina town upset after a school in their district decided to close for the day without women protest. The school cancelled classes calling today a teacher work day.

An angry resident and school district parent, Mary Lopez Carter joins me now. Mary, were you shocked when you heard they were closing schools for the protest?

MARY LOPEZ CARTER, PARENT ANGRY OVER SCHOOL CLOSING: I was beyond shocked and beyond angry about this.

MACDONALD: So what happened, so go ahead, Mary, tell us what happened.

CARTER: Well, it was all over Twitter and Facebook and that's how I found out about it. And then it just kind of spread from there.

MACDONALD: So, you know, working parents, working moms, working dads. I guess they unexpectedly had to take care of their children today, right.

CARTER: Exactly. Here's the thing. Teachers -- teaching is a profession. And if teachers want to be politicians then they should just leave their profession and go run for office. But what we have here is that they're all about their emotions, they're all about their ideology, and it supersedes logic.

Any reasonable person would agree that holding children's education hostage is really the wrong approach. It affects the -- it affects the families, it affects the parents, it affects the children. It's this very disruptive. And it affects poor children who rely on breakfasts and lunches at school.

MACDONALD: So, part of the school statement reads. "We support and appreciate our female workers. The decision to close schools with neither a statement nor an endorsement of the demonstration. It was entirely about our inability to insure the safety of students due to insufficient staffing."

Now, Mary, you are for equal pay for women, I take it, right, and for, you know, empowering women and getting women better jobs. And you know, doing - doing the right thing for women. But what did you make of the school's statement here?

CARTER: Well, I think frankly they're just lying. Because Durham Schools which is Durham County is right next door to Chapel Hill-Carrboro, the Orange County school system and they said they were going to open their doors. They were not going to close the doors on the children. So they made the decision that no, this is not acceptable and we are just going to keep our doors open and continue with school as usual.

MACDONALD: Why couldn't the schools just say, you know what, we're not going to allow the request to be absent. Shouldn't it -- you know, do they -- did that come up?

CARTER: Well, I think what is happening is that the administration is fully supporting this. So the thing is, you are seeing this in blue counties. And Chapel Hill-Carrboro Schools is in a very liberal area. And we are seeing it now in Virginia and in Maryland. Again, blue counties. So that tells you that's political.

MACDONALD: Mary, thank you so much for your time. I really appreciate it. Come back soon, OK?

CARTER: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Coming up, our very own Neil Cavuto has the first interview with Trump's labor secretary nominee Andy Puzder since he withdrew his name from his consideration. The details coming up, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Our own Neil Cavuto has the first interview with former Trump labor secretary nominee, Andrew Puzder since he withdrew his name from consideration. Tune in tomorrow at 12 p.m. Eastern Time for this exclusive.

Well, thank you for having us in your homes. Making Money with Charles Payne is next.

END
