urn:contentItem:5N22-N941-DXH2-612D-00000-00Women from all Walks of Life Joined the Rally on International Women's Day; WikiLeaks Said that Gadgets are Being Used by CIA to Surveil People; Hawaii Filing a Suit Against President Trump's Revised Travel Ban; A Woman Killed in Los Angeles by an Illegal Immigrant; A Man Beheaded his Own Mother with a Butcher Knife; Jobs Creation Since President Trump Took Office Exceeds What Wall Street First Projected; A Convicted Terrorist Helped Organized the Day Without Women Rally; School District in North Carolina Closed Due to Lack of Staff During the Women's Day Rally2017-03-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTBre Payton, Deneen Borelli, Jennice Fuentes, John Pina, Eric Beach, Deneen Borelli, Jennice Fuentes, Mary Lopez CarterNEWSFinancial030801cb.233Women from all Walks of Life Joined the Rally on International Women's Day; WikiLeaks Said that Gadgets are Being Used by CIA to Surveil People; Hawaii Filing a Suit Against President Trump's Revised Travel Ban; A Woman Killed in Los Angeles by an Illegal Immigrant; A Man Beheaded his Own Mother with a Butcher Knife; Jobs Creation Since President Trump Took Office Exceeds What Wall Street First Projected; A Convicted Terrorist Helped Organized the Day Without Women Rally; School District in North Carolina Closed Due to Lack of Staff During the Women's Day RallyElizabeth MacDonald, Andrew Napolitano

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: Breaking news. More than a dozen women arrested as thousands of women staged what was supposed to be peaceful pro- women rallies and walkouts across the country for the controversial day without a woman protest. It turned into an anti-Trump march.

Welcome to Risk and Reward. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald, in for Deirdre Bolton.

Women across the country walked off the job. White collar workers, blue collar workers, government workers, and teachers. One teacher in Philadelphia says it's about demonstrating support for the value of women.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I think this is a big year for us women. We need to prove that we are a big part of this economy and we're a big part of our nation. So, I'm glad that we could get together today and speak on behalf of that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: But was that always the case, because in order to show the vital role that women played in all fascist of this nation, the rally organizers said women must leave their jobs for the day to protest President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Trump does not have respect for women. But he also doesn't know the power of women. By the time why Trump and republicans to diminish women we know our value and we know that America doesn't function without us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Not every woman was on board with the statements like this. We have also working moms and working parents telling that they were struggling to get by and that they're now upset that their children were left stranded with some schools cancelling classes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm appalled that they just made this decision because people don't have the luxury like me and my family to have someone at home with the kids. Some people working two or three jobs, some people don't have the resources to hire a babysitter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: And it's not just teachers, government workers including house democrats whose salaries are paid with your tax dollars they walked off the job joining rallies in Washington, D.C. to show support. It's all part of a plan set by the organizers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Wear red in solidarity.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The color red signifies revolutionary love.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Action and our pioneering spirit.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number two, strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Strike.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do not engage in paid or unpaid work.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three. Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With the exception of small, and women and minority- owned business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. You can agree or disagree with that. But while the protestors and organizers say they're about the moral authority of empowering women, among the organizers and speakers at these women marchers are three murderers. One a convicted terrorist involved in the murder of two students.

Another in (Inaudible) starts a homicide it was on the FBI's 10 most wanted list. And still another convicted felon involved in the kidnapping, rape and murder of a gay man. Conspicuously missing from the list of the women inspiring marches like this.

Democrats like Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren, more on that coming up. My first guest is here to talk about how teachers were walking out to send and anti-Trump message.

Let's bring in Bre Payton, reporter for the Federalist. Bre, was this a woman's rally or an anti-Trump protest?

BRE PAYTON, THE FEDERALIST REPORTER: I think it's pretty clear tha this was an anti-Trump protest. The catalyst behind all these subsequent marches, and day without women, and strikes, and et cetera, et cetera, is Donald Trump's electoral victory, right, and I think pretending otherwise isn't really tricking anyone.

I think we all know that this is an anti-Donald Trump rally. And I think we know that a lot of these districts overwhelmingly vote -- the districts that closed the schools today they overwhelmingly voted for Hillary Clinton. And in some cases they didn't really need to close the doors. They could have still let kids into the classroom and allowed parents to go to work today, right.

MACDONALD: But Bre, stay on that. Are you saying that your team found the schools did have enough workers to stay open but they still shut their doors today? Wasn't that stranding working families, including single moms who work?

PAYTON: Yes, that's exactly what I'm saying. And I think a lot of the school districts are kind of enabling the strike instead of cracking down and saying no you need to show up for work. This is paid for and funded by taxpayer dollars. We need to provide the servants that we promised to provide to parents, instead of cracking down and being tough and doing their jobs, they decided to fold and enable teachers to allow then to protest the president, right. I mean, this is completely absurd.

MACDONALD: Yes. Bre, when teachers and government workers don't show up don't pack -- taxpayers have to pay extra including for replacement workers? Yes, protesting is a fundamental American right. You know, women, of course you want to support women and getting the pay that they deserve. But should protests like this be done on one's own time, say on the weekend when taxpayers aren't stuck with the bill?

PAYTON: Right. I mean, I would definitely think that if you're a taxpayer funded worker, that is if your paycheck is being funded by taxpayer dollars, you should do this on your own time and you should make them pay for it, right. I mean, that's why we have a lot of laws like the amendment in place that prevents taxpayer funding from going to abortion, right.

It's like a moral clause. In order to keep taxpayers for having to pay for things that they don't agree with. I don't agree with this protest and I'm upset that my taxpayers --my taxpayer dollars, you know, went to fund this kind of enable this behavior.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, you wonder if the parents as they agree with the teachers going to protest like this because protest organizers say that anyone questioning the goodness of communism, that communism acts should liberates people, or that Islam is really a feminist religion and it's good for women, anybody who says otherwise is an idiot or a racist. And they say capitalism is the problem when women are routinely brutalized under these regimes. What are your thoughts?

PAYTON: Right. Well, you know, my kid was in a classroom and a teacher called out to protest, to pay in this protest, I would think twice about sending them back to school the next day, right. And I myself I'm a product of home schooling because my parent didn't want to deal with indoctrinating in classrooms and teachers forcing an agenda down my throat, right.

So, I think a lot of parents are probably upset by this whole ideological battle that's being wage right now in classroom. And I think it's really unfair for, you know, 5-year-old kids to have to navigate or deal with this kind of propaganda that their teachers are pushing down their throats.

MACDONALD: You know, Bre, I mean, some of this is really just tweaks deep accusations. You know, you see the accusations of sexism, racism, take your `pickisms,' we get it. But they're letting in bad people like murderers and Islamists and communists. I mean, this really is a silly led by the sinister, right?

PAYTON: Yes. You're exactly right. And you know, this whole thing was supposed to be a grassroots-led movement. But it's pretty clear that it's not. It's pretty clear that there are very large organizations bankrolling this and that it is very well organize and that it is coming from the top down, right. It's not grassroots in any way, shape or form. And pretending that it is really just intellectually insulting.

MACDONALD: Bre Payton, you're always terrific. Please come back soon.

PAYTON: As always. I'll come back whenever.

MACDONALD: OK. Soon. Staying on this topic, the organizers of a day without women saying the women are encouraged to take the day off but avoid shopping.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three, avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Number three, avoid spending money.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With the exception of small, women and minority-owned businesses.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Some wondering if a group of men were protesting would not go shopping or wearing a color be on the list of things to do.

For that let's bring in the political power panel. Conservative Review Deneen Borelli, and democrat strategist Jennice Fuentes. Deneen, take off from work but don't work. Is that really the new feminist message?

DENEEN BORELLI, CONSERVATIVE REVIEW CORRESPONDENT: Liz, let me just tell you that I wore red today because I felt like it. I'm going shopping after this segment. And yes, I did work today. I was at the White House briefing. Liz, this is nothing but progressive activism women in skirts and dresses.

What people need to understand and realize is that America is an exceptional country. Anyone can succeed. We have women in all levels of all different jobs and responsibilities, whether it's television, entertainment, corporate America, you name it.

I worked hard to get where I am today to be on national television to talk about the policies and issues that I support. And for people to go out and protest industries the way that they are is absolutely ridiculous.

MACDONALD: Jennice, it's good to see you. The question has been, why should women get to walk off work to prove that women are equal to everyone else not able to take the day off. Isn't that kind of illogical and inconsistent? To some it's really impassively absurd because they just don't think that that's the way to go. What are your thoughts?

JENNICE FUENTES, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Well, there are short-term goals and there are long-term goals here. And I think that we all three of us women have the same goal in mind, in which we want to be treated like ladies but we want to get paid like men.

And I think that at this day and age it misses the biggest point, which most household in a family with children under 18 are led by women. And that woman makes at least 80 cents on the dollar that the men make. If that woman is a mother she makes 71 cents of that dollar that men makes. If that woman is a single mother she makes 58.

Whether you dress in red or you beg for some establishment who doesn't employ women and pay them right. This fight goes on beyond today. And that's what will unite all of us. Because at the end of the day women have to stand united to protect the wages. We have the real problem with that wage gap.

MACDONALD: Yes, Jennice.

FUENTES: And that absolutely needs to be solved.

MACDONALD: I hear exactly what you're saying. And in fact, yes, women should get paid equally as men. But Deneen, it seems like an anti-Trump protest. To Jennice's point, we've have a really bad economy where women are working multiple part-time jobs just to get by.

I mean, is this the way to go? It just seems that, you know, some of the things that they're saying at these marches are so off the wall about how communism is good and capitalism is bad. Go ahead.

BORELLI: Well, where were the protests with the Obama administration and females who got paid less than the male staffers under Obama's leadership. I mean, listen, this is where it's good to have smaller government, fiscal responsibility, and initiatives that will propel businesses to hire and grow their business and hire people, lower taxes, less regulations. These are the policies that President Trump is talking about in order to grow our economy and for job growth. And that is something that he ran on as president.

MACDONALD: All right. Let's switch gears. Protestors calling it a day for women, but was it just another anti-Trump protest?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We see women uncertain of their rights. We see anti- women and anti-abortion groups emboldened.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. Protestors saying they're worried about their rights. This as the president just signed two new laws helping NASA, and saying that NASA and to the NASA (Inaudible) nation, you know, push to get more women and girls involved in science math and related field.

Also, the president's daughter, Ivanka and the Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau with the president, they with a dozen CEO and business leaders to forge an international council women business leaders intending to support women in the workplace.

So, Jennice, I hear what they're saying about abortion and those rights and those issues. Setting that aside, I understand that. I get it. We're talking about economic growth and what you just said about women working part time. Is President Trump taking really taking away women's right when it comes to economic growth?

FUENTES: Well, they just say that I don't see anything that inspires me, or making me feel better about myself, for my nieces and for my sisters, and for men as well. I mean, we all have to stand united in here. But I would like to see very specific steps to help women, single women, especially and mothers, single mothers I meant, have a balance between work and family. Get those skills to basically grow their business. Get access to capital, get mentorship, get education.

It is very hard to make it in this world whether you have your own business or whether you work for others. And if you're a mom it's doubly hard. We already stay that you make 80 cents at the best situations, right?

BORELLI: Then you should with Trump policies...

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Jennice, I hear what you're saying.

FUENTES: But you know what, I would like to see something very specific. And the women marching today have the right to be heard. That's what so great about our country.

MACDONALD: OK. Jennice.

FUENTES: Now one march alone is not going to change everything. You know that.

MACDONALD: Right.

FUENTES: We all agree on that. This continues and this needs follow-up and this needs consistencies with Congress where the fight really needs to be fought.

MACDONALD: OK. Deneen, go ahead.

BORELLI: Then you should be in accordance with the policies that President Trump is urging in urban communities where the schools are failing children and there is a high crime rates and there are high unemployment rates. And so what we need to do our better school choice initiative avenues and also incentivize businesses to reinvest in these communities so people are employed. Whether they are mothers, fathers, single parents, you name it.

MACDONALD: All right. Deneen and Jennice, thank you so much. You are going to be back later.

FUENTES: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Now next up, is your TV, is your cell phone, even your car spying on you? WikiLeaks releasing a trove of documents showing how the CIA spies on you via your devices even if they are turned off.

A big name tech company's products have been allegedly compromised. We're talking Apple, Samsung, and Microsoft. They are upset and they're responding to the CIA. Hear what they have to say.

Also, can you guess which state is first out of the box trying to stop the president's refugee pause? The judge says that he would toss this suit due to its dubious assertions. He's going to explain that next, don't go away.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEVIN NUNES, (R) UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE: Look, this is early on in the investigation, but these appear to be very, very serious. We don't know who is responsible for this for what's happened in the latest WikiLeaks round. So, let's just leave it at that and let them come up and let them come out and brief you at the proper time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: WikiLeaks releasing a trove of CIA documents showing how it can spy on you via your devices. Now the leaks contain this. Techniques to break into smart phones, including iPhones using (TECHNICAL DIFFICULTY) listening devices, even if your TV is turned off. Instructions on how the CIA can use Skype, Wi-Fi networks, and anti-virus computer programs to spy on you as well. And details about how to steal your passwords over the internet.

Big tech companies like Apple, Samsung, Microsoft up and arms over WikiLeaks and CIA dump. They're mad at the CIA. Apple is saying this. "While our initial analysis indicates that many of the issues leaked today were already patched. We will continue to work rapidly to address any vulnerabilities."

Let's bring in the best expert around, the judge. Judge Andrew Napolitano. Are you worried about this?

ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: I'm terrified about it. You know, we've been saying for years that the mobile phones that we all carry around in our pockets which now you can't turn off are actually listening devices.

Now we also know that the microchip in the microwave in your kitchen can be used as a listening device. That certain televisions when they're turned off they only looked like off that can be used as a listening and a monitoring device.

Here is -- here is the problem. All of this is unlawful. The CIA is not permitted to ply its trade in the United States of America unless they are chasing somebody from outside the United States into the U.S. The government is spying on us without suspicion, without probable cause, and without a warrant from a judge.

That's un-American, unconstitutional and ineffective. It doesn't keep us safe. It produces information overload. It produces so much info...

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: How much?

NAPOLITANO: If it were printers on ordinary printing paper like you have in front over here. It would be 27 times the size of the -- of the contents of the library of Congress every year since 2005. The government doesn't have the resources to go through all of that to look for the bad that's buried in the good.

That's the genius of the Constitution in the fourth amendment. The government is force to focus on people as to whom it has suspicion or believe a crime or a terrorist activity is occurring or is about to occur. When you focus on the bad people you leave everybody out alone. This is spying on everybody.

MACDONALD: Yes, but your point is, I hear your point. The argument is that we have to catch the terrorist here. The FBI is 900 active terror plots in all 50 states.

NAPOLITANO: The FBI does not do this. The FBI, as far as I can tell you, and I've been monitoring and working with them within my ears in the bench for years. The FBI when they want to listen to a conversation or otherwise surveil you, goes to a judge and presents probable cause and gets a warrant.

MACDONALD: But what's the CIA doing? They trying to get terrorists?

NAPOLITANO: The CIA is trying to gather all the information they can because their theory is if they gather everything it is more efficient than isolating the bad people. The problem with that is the Constitution requires the isolation of the bad people.

Go to Fox News.com the headline is "FBI Searches for CIA mole." How about the headline is, "FBI searches for CIA who have been spying on innocent Americans." That's what the FBI should be searching for. That's a felony to do it and WikiLeaks has demonstrated that it's been going on under our noses.

MACDONALD: Wow.

NAPOLITANO: Where's the outrage?

MACDONALD: And all the leaks that are coming out of the government about spying on people in government. Wow.

Switching gears, here's the state that is first out of the box suing the Trump administration over its new refugee pause. It's Hawaii. Hawaii wants to fight it out in court, calling this version of the order a quote, "Muslim ban."

Now the imam of the Muslim Association of Hawaii he's complaining. He is saying this. "This new version in the executive order inflicts a grave injury on Muslims in Hawaii, including the imam, his family and members of the mosque." Judge, is this a Muslim ban?

NAPOLITANO: It is not a Muslim ban. The government has removed all references to religion. It certainly falls disproportionately on Muslims but it is not written in order to keep Muslims out of the United States. The government articulates in the ban the reasons why the State Department has chosen these six countries.

It's really far more bulletproof than the first one is -- first one was. But this Hawaii lawsuit is filled with some of the most scurrilous attacks on President Trump that I have seen on a sitting president since the ending days of the, of Richard Nixon.

They have taken out of context the most incendiary things he said since long before he was even a candidate and trying to ascribe that to his motivation now. So they're taking something he said two and a half years ago and trying to say this is his motivation for today.

That's not an appropriate way for a court to evaluate the true motivation of the President of the United States. Because this is an area of the law uniquely given by the Constitution just to the president. It's foreign policy. He decides who our enemies are, he decides who our friends are. The Congress gives him tools. One of tools is temporary immigration bans. He's using those tools.

MACDONALD: If this came before you as a judge, what would you do?

NAPOLITANO: Well, I would -- I would dismiss it. Because the State of Hawaii is the plaintiff here. And the State of Hawaii can't show that it is harmed. You can't go into federal court just because you don't like what the government did. You have to show how you are harmed. The state has not been harmed at all.

MACDONALD: Judge, you're great. Please come back soon. We love you.

NAPOLITANO: I'm just delighted to be able to work with you.

MACDONALD: Always great to see you.

NAPOLITANO: Especially when it starts this the day, starts here and then Stuart.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Stuart Varney and you have to do...

NAPOLITANO: Does Varney around somewhere?

MACDONALD: No, you have to do the queen's accents next time with Varney.

NAPOLITANO: You got it.

Next more, a sanctuary state fallout. An illegal immigrant repeatedly arrested. He was deported to Mexico five times. He's now charged in a deadly car crash in Los Angeles that killed a woman.

Also shockingly gruesome story involving another illegal immigrant. This time in North Carolina. That man accused of beheading his own mother. Next, the father whose daughter was killed by an illegal immigrant react, after this.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's just unbelievable. They had him handcuffed and he was just sitting there just like he didn't have a care in the world.

MACDONALD: Last month Sandra Duran killed in Los Angeles by a drunk driver. The driver an illegal immigrant deported to Mexico five times before. He had been arrested and charged with more than 20 felonies and misdemeanors including gun and drug possession and driving under the influence.

Joining me now, John Pina, another father whose daughter was also killed by an illegal immigrant. Mr. Pina, we are so sorry for your loss, and we are so upset we are asking you to do this. But, please, we want to inform the viewer, what happened to your 14-year-old daughter. Can you tell us?

MACDONALD: Now, Mr. Pina, correct us if we're wrong, but is it true that an arrest warrant for this illegal immigrant was not issued until 17 years later? And in the meantime, he committed many more crimes? What happened? Where is he now?

PINA: Back in '87 he had kidnapped two 14-year-old girls. One in July, he got put in jail, got out. And in September he came back and did kidnapped another one. And he got out again. And then he came back and he murdered my daughter. And then a few months later he came back and tried to kidnap a 12-year-old at 7 o'clock in the morning. And he's supposedly, supposed to be incarcerated in Mexico for Christy's murder.

MACDONALD: Is he in jail in prison right now, sir?

PINA: That's what I heard last. But I haven't heard anything in almost a year. So, I really don't know. They haven't informed me, or they haven't contacted me for a while. So, I really don't know. I can't tell you.

MACDONALD: Well, it's absolutely disgrace and it's horrifying. We are so upset for you and your family.

PINA: Thank you.

MACDONALD: And I got a story that came up, sir, we want to talk to you about it. In North Carolina an 18-year-old illegal immigrant charged this week with murder. Olivia Machado was decapitated by this man, her son. He decapitated his own mother with a butcher knife. Here's what he told authorities. He did it because he felt like it. Now he was taking medication for a psychosis schizophrenia. He was in the United States illegally. Should he have been deported, sir?

PINA: Well, he should never been here in the first place, and yes, he should have been deported. But now it's going to be kind of hard to get him deported because now the system is going to look at him and support him and take care of him while the taxpayers are out all that money. He should have never been here in the first place.

MACDONALD: Mr. Pina, how do you feel about what President Trump is doing versus what, how President Obama handled these problems.

PINA: Donald Trump, our President, I think is doing a great job. He's doing what he said he's going to do. I met with the man, he is sincere and he will accomplish what he set out to do.

MACDONALD: John Pina, thank you so much. And again, with your story, you are helping so many people across the country. It is so difficult and horrifying what you went through. But we're grateful you came on the show. Thank you again.

PINA: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Breaking news. Sources telling Fox News that Jon Huntsman, Jr. will be the next U.S. ambassador to Russia. President Trump reportedly calling Mr. Huntsman two days ago to offer him the job, and apparently, Mr. Huntsman accepted.

BARACK OBAMA, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: He's going to bring all these jobs back? Well, how exactly is he going to do? What are you going to do? There is no answer to it. He just says, well, I'm going -- I'm going to negotiate a better deal. Well, how -- what -- how exactly are you going to negotiate that? What magic wand do you have?

Since my election, Ford, Fiat Chrysler, General Motors, Sprint, Soft Bank, Lockheed, Intel, Wal-Mart, and many others, have announced that they will invest billions and billions of dollars in the United States and will create tens of thousands of new American jobs.

That's 100,000 more jobs than Wall Street had predicted. That looks like 3 percent even 4 percent growth, to me, that's what the president promised.

The co-chair of America -- great -- excuse me -- the Great American Alliance, he's Eric Beach. He joins me now. Eric, what do you think of the blistering pace of jobs that were added last month?

ERIC BEACH, GREAT AMERICAN ALLIANCE CO-CHAIR: Look, I mean, the last two months has been the largest increase in job creation since September of 2015, and it's interesting, we talk about the promises that he ran on, now they're promises kept. So, I think, you know, much like the stock market the market doesn't lie. Job creation and job growth also doesn't lie. I think the president is just simply keeping his promises to the American people.

MACDONALD: Yes. The market likes -- it looks like it likes these policies. And companies are investing to create these jobs and these are good paying jobs, Eric. There are construction jobs up by 66,000. Manufacturing jobs up by 32,000.

President Obama repeatedly said, you know what, manufacturing jobs is not coming back. How is Trump going to do that? He can't do that. Was he wrong?

BEACH: He was wrong. And that's because he's never had a private sector job before. And so, I think what you're seeing is you really is a culture of confidence for the business community. For example, when Samsung is going to move and bring in -- relocate some of their operations into the U.S., you know, that's simply because maybe they are afraid of the border tax proposal. Maybe they just understand that there might a better corporate tax here inside the United States.

Whatever that might be, you know, the president is creating a culture of confidence and once again, the market sees that. Remember when the market was at 18,000 when he was elected. And we said, well, that was a psychological number for the Dow.

When is the last time you heard he's only creating private sector jobs? When was the last time you've heard off? He's only creating private sector jobs. He's not really doing much for the public sector. But that's what he ran on.

The American people voted for Donald Trump for a variety of reasons. You know, they wanted to repeal and replace healthcare. They wanted to, you know, make sure we secure America first. And then also to create jobs and he's doing all three of those things right out of the box.

urn:contentItem:5V44-WWN1-JBCN-40F2-00000-00Woodrow Hartzog and Neil Richards: It's time to try something different on Internet privacy2019-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisNEWSWoodrow Hartzog and Neil Richards: It's time to try something different on Internet privacyWoodrow Hartzog and Neil Richards

Since the dawn of the internet, American regulators and companies have pursued two goals to protect our privacy: that people should be in control of their data and that companies should be transparent about what they do with our data. We can see these goals detailed in the privacy policies and terms of service that we "agree" to as well as companies' increasingly complicated systems of privacy dashboards, permissions and sharing controls.

This approach has failed us. Too often it has resulted in little more than threadbare privacy protections and cluttered inboxes. The control that companies promise us over our data ends up illusory and overwhelming. And even when they act transparently, they don't embrace the privacy reforms we need.

And so, over the past decade, we've witnessed a cascade of high-profile privacy failures: the Edward Snowden disclosures, the Cambridge Analytica scandal, fake news and data breach after data breach after data breach. Big tech platforms and shadowy advertising companies make their fortunes while the rest of us are watched, nudged, exploited and exposed to cyberattacks and the manipulation of our political systems.

There's a better way, but it requires us to reimagine the relationship between consumers and online companies in a way that places trust at the center. Being trustworthy in the digital age means companies must be discreet with our data, honest about the risk of data practices, protective of our personal information and, above all, loyal to us — the data subjects. And it's up to our lawmakers to make it happen.

Congress stands alone among Western democracies in failing to pass a general privacy law covering all our information. The Federal Trade Commission has worked hard to be the top U.S. privacy cop, but it lacks the legal tools and financial resources needed to do the job.

The world is watching, and the economic stakes are enormous. International data flows are essential for the global economy to function without fundamentally — and expensively — restructuring the internet. American tech companies depend on being able to smoothly bring Europeans' data here for processing, but in 2015, a European court ruled that U.S. privacy protections were so poor that it struck down the Safe Harbor agreement, which helped enable an international flow of data. Our current data-sharing agreement with Europe, called the E.U./U.S. Privacy Shield, also seems destined to fail. If it does, we will need a good replacement.

Despite the failures of our current online privacy ecosystem, some lawmakers are considering doubling down on policies that do not work. But no matter how much control companies give us over our data, it will never work online. That's because control and transparency place the burden on consumers to protect themselves and understand where their data is going. And they must do this for every one of the dozens (or more) online accounts they may have.

So let's try something different. Consider the newly introduced legislation from Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) called the Data Care Act of 2018, for which we provided feedback in its draft form. The bill, one of the first and most significant moves to establish a new American privacy identity, favors three key non-waivable obligations for companies that use the internet to collect personal information: duties of care, loyalty and confidentiality. These duties are modeled on the privacy requirements for any fiduciary, such as doctors, lawyers or accountants — all of whom are legally required to act in good faith on behalf of their patients or clients and are bound to keep our disclosures safe and confidential.

Schatz's legislation would apply more broadly, compelling tech companies to be discreet and secure, discouraging manipulative practices and keeping companies from elevating their short-term profits over our long-term interests. In other words, the bill would require such companies to act more like doctors than telemarketers. The bill would also give regulators the resources they need to enforce privacy protections and prohibit companies from using dense terms-of-use agreements to get us to waive those obligations. Companies would have to be trustworthy regardless of what we "agree" to online.

It's time to take a bold step forward. The United States has an opportunity to redefine itself as the country that protects the trust that people give to companies. By embracing trust, the United States can become a leader on privacy instead of following the path of false promises and diminishing returns. Call it legal innovation, if that's what it takes. But whatever we call it, the United States can pave the way for a safe, sustainable and profitable digital future.

Woodrow Hartzog is a professor of law and computer science at Northeastern University. Neil Richards is the Thomas and Karole Green Professor of Law and director of the Cordell Institute at Washington University in St. Louis.

Woodrow Wilson Center And Nixon Foundation Hold Discussion On Us-China Relations

October 17, 2019 09:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

WILSON CENTER PRESIDENT JANE HARMEN NIXON FOUNDATION CEO HUGH HEWITT

BUREAU OF EAST ASIAN AND PACIFIC AFFAIRS ASSISTANT SECRETARY OF STATE DAVID R. STILWELL

CENTER FOR STRATEGIC AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES SENIOR FELLOW JONATHAN E. HILLMAN

AEI ASIAN STUDIES DIRECTOR DAN BLUMENTHAL

WILSON CENTER PUBLIC POLICY SCHOLAR JEAN LEE

NEW YORK TIMES DIPLOMATIC CORRESPONDENT EDWARD WONG

WILSON CENTER ASIA PROGRAM DIRECTOR ABRAHAM DENMARK

IMF FORMER EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR MEG LUNDSAGER

WALL STREET JOURNAL SENIOR EDITOR BOB DAVIS HILLS AND COMPANY MANAGING DIRECTOR JOHN FRISBIE

SEN. CHRIS COONS (D-DEL.)

COHEN GROUP SENIOR ADVISOR DAVE RANK

HUDSON INSTITUTE RELIGIOUS FREEDOM EXPERT NINA SHEA

NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR DEMOCRACY STUDIES AND ANALYSIS VICE PRESIDENT CHRISTOPHER WALKER

WILSON CENTER KISSINGER INSTITUTE ON CHINA AND THE UNITED STATES DIRECTOR ROBERT DALY

WILSON CENTER FELLOW KATIE STALLARD-BLANCHETTE

WATSON INSTITUTE AMBASSADOR CHAS W. FREEMAN, JR

NATIONAL COMMITTEE ON AMERICAN FOREIGN POLICY INTERNATIONAL RESCUE COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN EMERITUS WINSTON LORD

WILSON CENTER KISSINGER INSTITUTE ON CHINA AND THE UNITED STATES DISTINGUISHED SCHOLAR J. STAPLETON ROY

WOODROW WILSON INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR SCHOLARS SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT ROBERT S. LITWAK

[*]HARMAN: College for the Nixon Library and Museum. Marlene Malik was to join us, Fred's wife of 57 years, but sadly can't be here. But I know that she and their family send best regards for a successful event and ongoing support for the Nixon Center and the Wilson Center.

Hugh Hewitt, President of the Nixon Foundation, and an old friend from our press days and press conversations in--in--in--past--past decades, is here to introduce today's events, as well as to introduce our first keynote speaker.

So, one last point. This whole conversation today is designed, and I know, Hugh endorses this, to prevent to--present different views on China. The Wilson Center is strictly nonpartisan. That space has brought us enormous attention worldwide, we're ranked by our peers number one in regional expertise. And in that spirit, it is really a pleasure to introduce Hugh, and to introduce a fascinating day. Welcome to Hugh Hewitt.

HEWITT: Thank you, Congresswoman Harman. As the Congresswoman mentioned, I--she and I go back to 1992, when I hosted a Los Angeles PBS show and she is the equal of any member who has ever represented any part of California. And she would come and sit down with us and engage in the kind of conversations we're going to have today, frank, full, a lot of free flowing and full of facts as opposed to merely heat and light.

I thought I would remind our audience at the beginning, in 1971, when the Wilson Center was founded, President Nixon spoke at its dedication. He was introduced by Hubert Humphrey at that moment. He recalled at that time, "My mother and father were both Republicans", said RN in 1971. "California was the state," as you recall, I'm sure not many people did but he said it, "That decided the Election of 1916. The reason was that a number of Republicans voted for Wilson."

The President continued, "My mother was one of them. She was a devout Quaker, a dedicated pacifist. I was only three years old in 1916, the President continued, but for years afterwards, in a friendly way, my mother and father sometimes spoke of that election, as my father had voted for Hughes. But my mother, despite the fact that America did get into the war in 1916, always had her faith in Woodrow Wilson.

She used to say that he was a good man. He was a good man who believed deeply in peace. And she believed that the United States made an error at the conclusion of World War I in not following his initiative in the League of Nations. He inspired her with his idealism, and she in turn passed that inspiration on to me", end the quote of President Nixon.

I also want to join Congresswoman Harman in recognizing that Fred Malik made this conference possible, he conceived of it, it was his idea that the Center and the Foundation work together. Indeed, Marlene and I were talking at a recent event honoring Mrs. Nixon over at the White House Historical Association, how passionate Fred was about this particular partnership.

Julian Tricia said at the time that Fred died that no single individual had done more to preserve the good work and memory of President Nixon than Fred Malik, who is very much missed and today is very much about him. I want to conclude with two points, before we introduce our guest speaker, our honored speaker this morning. The first is I went to work for Richard Nixon in 1978, fresh out of college in San Clemente the elbow of America at that time, and got to spend a remarkable two years, hours and hours and hours listening to him talking about the world.

He was writing a book at that time called The Real War and it was followed by Leaders. I have no doubt his grandson, Christopher Cox, who is with us this morning, if your grandfather was still working on books, his next one would not be called The Real War. It would be called The Real Competition and it would be about the U.S.-PRC, and how that competition is going to be managed, and the coalition that Dr. Kissinger writes about in--on China evolves.

I'm also confident that his second book, Leaders. would still include, as the first one did, Mao and Zhou Enlai, for whom there are bronze life size replica statues at the library in Yorba Linda, because of his great esteem for their willingness to take the same risks that Winston Lord and Henry Kissinger and President Nixon took long ago, in the--in the early '70s.

I want to close by quoting Frank Garren is here, President Nixon's colleague in the writing of RN, and also in some extraordinary interviews he did in 1988. Frank asked President Nixon in 1980 about China. And the President said, "Reflecting on what had begun 15 years earlier, once that power of China is mobilized it is going to be an enormous force in the world for good or for bad. I think de Gaulle hit it in usually his right way in 1969 most effectively, when he said cryptically 'better to recognize China now when they need you than wait until later when their power is such that you will need them'."

With that now let me introduce our guest and honored speaker this morning, David Stilwell is the Assistant Secretary of State for the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs. Prior to his appointment as the Assistant Secretary on June 20, 2019 he served in the Air Force for 35 years, for that we are grateful. Beginning as an enlisted Korean linguist at 19, I don't know want to get the year '80, and he retired in 2015 as a Brigadier General, after multiple tours in Asia, in Japan, Korea as a fighter pilot, a linguist and as a commander.

He also served as the Defense Attache at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. And later went on to serve on the China Strategic Force Group at the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command in Hawaii from '17 to '19. He's an Adjunct Senior Fellow with the East West Center in Honolulu for those three years. He graduated from the Air Force Academy, got his Master's Degree in Asian Studies from the University of Hawaii, a Graduate of the Executive Leadership Program from the Darden School at the University of Virginia.

He was awarded the Department of Defense Superior Service Award in 2015. He speaks Korean, Chinese, a limited amount of Japanese so he has that against him. But other than that, we can't have a better person to open our day today, Assistant Secretary Stilwell. Thank you.

STILWELL: Well I appreciate that. And it's going to be really tough to live up to that intro, but I will do my best. Thanks for the opportunity to speak to a group of people that I've always wanted to get to meet personally. Robert Daley and Stapleton Roy and others have done me the service of giving me time to share ideas and help adjust my vision and the--and I can feed that into the Administration's vision for where we want to go with this Asia Pacific relationship.

China's a--a large part of that, but, you know, our own strategy and our relationships with the region are equally important. But today we're going to focus on U.S.-China and also mostly on the U.S. strategy.

I don't have all the answers. I've done some outreach with a number of you, I will continue to do that to hear other thoughts. I want to hear people who dis--just don't want to be that guy that's trudging down the--the wrong path, you know, let 100 flowers bloom since we're in this room. I won't kill you when it's over though.

I want to start off with a quote, and I won't tell you who--whose quote it is. I know many of you know who it is. But it was--it was surprising me, for me to hear this language. The quote is this, "We must have a deep appreciation for capitalism's ability to self-correct and a full objective assessment of the real long-term advantages that the developed Western nations have in the economic, technological and military spheres."

Again, I'll address the rest of this quote later when we get done. But I think that's a very important assessment of the strengths of these--of what we represent here in, not just the United States, but in the liberal democratic world.

Matt Potter was going to open this, and he shared me with his notes. I can't give Matt's speech. I'm giving my own. But he--he typically notes the three myths that have come to light that we need to discuss. First that is engagement with the PRC will lead eventually to some sort of liberalization or an accommodation. The second that the Chinese Communist Party's goal is simply to remain in power, to survive. The third is that ideology no longer matters.

Again, Ambassador Roy and I had a--a good conversation in getting ready for this event. And you know, nothing's black and white. Yeah you can throw these at the straw man. But I do think we need to address these in our--as we adapt our relationship here.

A lot of us have come to the conclusion throughout, I mean, certainly for last 10 or 20 years, we've come to our own understanding of these three ideas. For me, you know, while I was Defense Attache in Beijing, I went there with full--full intention of helping bring the PLA and the --the Chinese government, you know, expose them to the wonderfulness of what we do. And then bring them into what we would consider a more long term and--and more mutually beneficial relationship.

As happens with a lot of people who go to the embassy and then come back, I came back disappointed in the complete inability to--to make changes and to affect that system. In large part due to the--the restricted nature of our interaction. Where, you know, we were limited with who we could engage in the Chinese government and in society in general. And that has only continued that limited--limitation on engagement.

And--and I think that is probably, if you take anything away from this conversation, that--that to me is something that has to be addressed. If we're going to, if this relationship is going to grow in a productive way, we're going to have to have an open conversation. And you don't have that by limiting access.

So, engagement is obviously an important aspect to this. But the relationship and the Administration's perspective on U.S.-China relations right now is one of competition, strategic competition. And that is simply a realizing that, you know, if--if you're playing ping pong and one side is competing the other side is competing, it is defined as a competitive game, you are competing. You can't, you know, the--the side that's--that is competing defines a relationship.

The realization I think in general came about in 2013 with several speeches. For me it was 2012, during the 18th Party Congress. Then those ideas with the advent of a new leader came to fruition in 2013. And again this is where I'm going to pull some quotes here from Xi Jinping's speech in January of that year, where it became obvious that, you know, we're charting in our own path and we're going into direction, we the PRC, that is different than what many of us assumed, and we we're going to have to change our approach to that.

Look, if there's anything, so I was in the previous Administration in uniform, and--and you--you can--I think being slow to anger and giving everybody the best possible chance, you know, to--to clarify and understand is a great strength. And--and I think we did that very well. But it has come down now to the point where we have to acknowledge that the relationship is different than we assumed.

And so, the response by the--the Trump Administration is and the specific strategy, talks about three pillars. We're going to address the security; the defense guy knows what that's all about. That's probably the most mature part of this. The second part we're going to address prosperity or the economic aspects of this relationship. I think we all know what that looks like.

But the third one is governance. We have not really thought about governance. And governance takes you back to ideology and--and basic, the nature of who you are national character. Again, this came to me when--in a meeting in Beijing in 2014, with the PLA Navy. I was handed a copy of the gov--governance of China, Xi Jinping's, you know, book, volume one. I had then volume two.

And as you read that, it becomes clear that the concepts are different, fundamentally different. And again, acknowledging that and reading those differences and understanding where the Chinese Communist Party is going is important. So, I'm going to talk just briefly about what governance means.

So, missed two and three about the perpetuation, or simple existence of the Chinese Communist Party, and that ideology--ideology isn't really a function here, going back to the end of history thoughts. I think need to be addressed. The language you hear in--in most speeches now is about natural--a national rejuvenation fishing. Nothing wrong with that. There's nothing wrong with the Chinese wanting to stand up and--and be proud and grow to their greatest potential. You know, the issue I have is the way we're going about doing that.

So again, it's not about survival of the party, it's about achieving what China is capable of achieving. The Chinese Work Report, the 19th Party Congress Work Report 2017, mentions, you know, Chinese return to the--being near the center of the world's stage. And there's other language that I'll quote here that addresses that intent of becoming not just regionally vibrant and--and significant, but globally significant.

That explains a lot of what you're seeing outside of the--the Asia Pacific region. But I think idealize--ideology matters and liberal democracy, my opinion, is a direct threat to a more authoritarian approach, is which, what we're seeing out of Beijing. Hong Kong. Hong Kong's a great example of what--what you had as a, I won't say entirely democratic, but a--a system where people had a voice and they had a choice.

And we're going from one party two systems into a--a system that increasingly is going to make Hong Kong look just like the mainland, taking away that voice and we-re--we're again we're seeing how you--it's really difficult to put empowering the people and people who have at least some impact on how they're governed and--and bring them back into this more, as I would put it, a lower on the Maslow Hierarchy of needs, more subsistence type of--of governance.

So, since ideology matters, I think we need to get back to fundamental Western or at least American ideology. And that comes from of course the Declaration of Independence. "We hold these truths to be self-evident, all men are created equal." It's a short phrase but it means a lot, that they are endowed with certain unalienable rights, life, liberty, and the pursuit of--pursuit of happiness.

I mean, we-- we all know these things intuitively. But then I started reading, you know, I read on, that one we memorize, but that the securities rights, governments are instituted by men, deriving governments, derive their just powers from the consent of the governed.

This is the key difference is, in the one case, if--if you look back at, you know, Chinese history. I certainly don't have a great handle on it, but I think I've seen enough to understand, let's go back to the issue with Xinjiang right now.

The government says that what's going on in Xinjiang is counterterrorism, and that we are absolutely addressing human rights in Beijing. And--and I--first you say that's being cynical, but in fact, they--I think they really do believe that. Because they're addressing the rights of the many without necessarily regarding the--the rights of the few.

When they talk about human rights, and I'm not making it, I mean this is written. Human rights are accessed to--or to the ability to prosperity and security. You're avoiding the Chinese--the historical bent toward chaos, famine, poverty and all the rest. So, in this sort of inverted governance model, the governance is providing for the people their human right to, you know, three square meals a day and the chance to get rich.

It's--it's hard to disagree with that, but on the other hand, that does not comport with what we believe in that the human rights are individual. And that's what we sign when we signed the UN Charter, individual human rights. The rest of that we can deal with in a broader, more liberal government model. So, I think we really should, as we have this conversation, reflect on who we are, what we stand for. And I think that helps clarify the differences.

The President, in terms of Hong Kong, they said it many times they want--they want liberty, they want democracy, they want what they had. So, this sets up the--the strategic competition that we've been talking about. And so, I would like to briefly address strengths and weaknesses.

On the strengths side, the--the great news is that the U.S. isn't the only place in the world where we recognize the--the importance of individual human rights, of--of a government that supports the people instead of the other way around. And we have lots of folks in Europe, Japan, Korea, I mean, you name it Southeast Asia, democracies who are, you know, of the same beliefs.

So, having likeminded allies and partners is a, I mean, if you want to run a tally sheet about how both sides stack up, I think you'll see that the--the weight of history is on the side of liberal governance.

On the other hand, open liberal systems have weaknesses, which can be at times both weaknesses and strengths, but in a competition a weakness of being an open system we're discovering, we're, you know, learning again, leaves--leaves you open to things like adverse messaging, you know, we--we don't have a propaganda arm. So, you hear many voices coming out of Washington, D.C. And that's great, right? Let--let 100 flowers bloom. Let's have a conversation here instead of having a single party line, which again works against us in some cases, but I think over time is one of our--our great strengths.

We have fallen short I think in messaging who we are, what we stand for, what our ideals and values are. That's one of my goals is to better message. Again, a positive message of who we are, I don't want to keep pointing everything back to the other side. I just want to help people understand why we--who we are how we got here.

So, I've kind of quickly gone over our values. I just want to note, here's what the other side believes. And then Ambassador Roy and I are hap--happily having a conversation just now about we--we both recognize this document and these quotes as extremely relevant.

So, the--to quote, "Chinese Communist Party takes the historical materialist view that capitalism is bound to die out, and socialism--socialism is bound to win. The eventual demise of capitalism and the ultimate victory of socialism will require a long historical process to reach completion." It's not going to happen overnight, but we do have two goals 2021 and 2049, two centenary goals that I think that they're working to achieve those.

So, all along we've been slow to realize, over time, with a very positive Western hope that the other side would recognize the value here. We've been slow to recognize we're in competition, hoping to achieve our objectives through cooperation.

I'm here to say that this--we are now in a strategic competition that does not obviate cooperation in any way. As I said earlier, we just, you probably read last night that we announced that we're going to ask Chinese diplomats in the U.S. to notify us in advance before they go speak to our universities, our governors, mayors and municipal folks. We're not going to say no, we just want to have an idea who they're talking to.

And this is in response to how, again, having been there we, American diplomats are treated in China where you don't ask permission. I mean you don't notify; you ask permission to go engage with these folks. And you're frequently denied that. The goal is not to, you know, cut off communication., the goal is to lower barriers to communication, to make sure both sides are having that--that discussion. We can talk about that during the Q&A if anybody has any questions on that.

The--if anybody's read Silent Invasion, Clive Hamilton, if you've looked at the Australian Experience with Malcolm Turnbull, John Garnaut, I think you understand what the--the Chinese approach has been. It's been a very long-term deliberate approach over decades to take advantage of open systems, and then use, them manipulate them and--and adjust them, so they are not hostile to this new type ideology.

If you look inside the Australian system, you found many, lots of evidence of that and they are busy creating laws about, you know, accepting foreign money and--and the rest. And so, I'm characterizing all this in--in terms of my response and the administration's response is simply housekeeping. I mean, there's broken glass on the floor from years and years of--of hope. And we're just going to try to sweep up--sweep up to, that--that glass, get this relationship on a true even footing and--and then move out from there. We're not trying to cut off contact, we're trying to increase contact--contact.

So, in summary, our goal here is a region that is strong, sovereign and prosperous. And our goal is also a relationship with China that is fair and reciprocal. With Beijing living up to its many commitments. Commitments like the Convention on Law of the Sea World Trade Organization. It's joint declaration with Hong Kong, 50 years of autonomy and others.

And the goal to do that--in order to--we asked them to live up to these commitments, because in my mind there's a--an equation here. You've got words, that's these commitments you signed up to, and then you have actions, what you actually do. And words times actions equals trust. Trust is a result of stating what you're going to do, following through with what you're going to do, and you can't have trust without that. Words alone, talk is cheap.

So finally, I'm going to finish off with the quote the rest of that--that document here from 2013. Just to identify major differences in these approaches, and I'll open up to questions. So "In the meantime, we must have a deep appreciation for capitalism's ability to self-correct," I mentioned this already, "and a full objective assessment of the real long-term advantages that the developed Western nations have an economic, technological and military spheres. Then we must diligently prepare for a long period of cooperation, end of conflict between these two social systems in each of these domains.

For a fairly long time yet socialism, in its primary stage will exist alongside a more productive and developed capitalist system. In this long period of cooperation and conflict, socialism must learn from the boons that capitalism has brought to civilization. We must face the reality that people will use the strengths of developed Western countries to denounce our country's socialist development.

Here we must have a great strategic determination, resolutely rejecting all false arguments that we should abandon socialism. We must consciously correct the various ideas that do not accord with our current stage. More importantly, we must concentrate our efforts on bettering our own affairs, continually broadening our comprehensive national power, improving the lives of our people, building a socialism that is superior to capitalism, and laying a foundation for a future where we will win the initiative and have the dominant position.

We will be able to adhere to the correct political orientation, stand without arrogance and victory, without despair and adversity, and during all sorts of risk and adversity, consciously resisting the corrosion of decadent philosophies, forever fostering the political essence of a communist."

STILWELL: That's a great question. No--the--in--in short the answer is absolutely not. You have everybody's bio in your--in your packets so I won't belabor them. But very quickly

, we have Dan Blumenthal from AEI. We have Jonathan Hillman from CSIS. Jean Lee from here at the Wilson Center running our Career Center and Edward Wong from the New York Times and also the Wilson Center. Thank you all for coming.

You know--I--I'm digging deep into finishing a book so I feel like I'm let out of a cave and I can--I can actually have interaction with human beings and so forth and--and--but--you know--I've been thinking a lot about this subject for--for many, many years as--as you have--you know--for going on 20 years now. And I--so--the--the 19th Party Congress Report is a good start. The--the Chinese--it should be read in Chinese and in English.

It's very clear about--it's much more clear than--than we've ever seen before about exactly what--what the Chinese Communist Party wants to do. It's--it's very important--very, very important to separate the Communist Party from--from the Chinese people, because when people talk about--and I'm going off on a little aside here--the Chinese want this, and the Chinese want that. Well, we know what the Chinese Communist Party wants, but--but the Chinese are 1.2 billion people. We have no idea what the Chinese want or how much they support it. I mean--we--we know in Hong Kong they want freedom and probably throughout China they want more freedom as well.

So--so--anyway, it's very important to distinguish. The Chinese Communist Party says very clearly that they--I'm inter--you know--I'm interpreting but it--but a different world order with China at the center. And--and--you know--there's a lot of--lot of talk about One Belt One Road and so forth. Fundamentally, it's--it's--it's a means to an end. It's--it's a--it's--it's--if people are looking for massive amounts of money spent they're--you know--they're not going to see it. It's very unprofitable for China. It's a waste of money and so forth.

But what--what they have succeeded in doing is creating an international organization with China at the center. And--and the ability to bring 60 nations to China every year to--you know--to at least talk about the infrastructure projects even if they're not going forward with them. So, China--you know--wants a different world order. They--they are very clear about--you know--community of common destiny for all of mankind. They're not just talking about the Indo-Pacific. They're clear about wanting to propagate what they call a socialist culture. Some of these translations aren't--aren't great, but they're--they're certainly training other country's elites in what they call a socialist culture. Which basically means this Beijing model of--of elite authoritarian governance with--with some experimentation with markets.

They're very clear on becoming a world-class military and--and much more clear on what that means in terms of technological advancements. And they've made great strides--great, great strides in doing so. They've--they've changed the--the balance of power in the Indo-Pacific region with their military modernization program. Probably one of the vastest and fastest military modernization program in human history, if you look back to 1991, 1992. And the U.S. is finding itself playing catch up in--in--in a lot of different areas. A different world order also means different energy relationships because of--of Chinese deep insecurities about using the traditional energy markets.

So, this has led to new relationships with Russia, this has led to new relationships with the stans, this has led to part of One Belt One Road's building of ports and--and other infrastructure. So--you know--the--the Chinese Communist Party essentially wants a world that is--you know--A, keeps the Chinese Communist Party safe from--from--from liberal democracies and--and B--you know--B gives the Chinese Communist Party its new raison d'etre, which is leading China into finally--you know--the--what they write about is China stood up under Mao and went through reform and opening under Dong and now it's on the cusp of achieving national rejuvenation.

They're sort of saying to the Chinese people--you know--stick with us and we'll lead you to--to national greatness. If the United States remains the prime power in the international system then it'll continue setting the rules and the rules will be far more liberal and--and focused on human rights than they otherwise would be.

So--you know--and--and--I--we can go on and on about that--and international free markets. Free markets in energy, free markets in LNG, freedom of the seas, freedom of air passages, freedom of the internet, freedom--you know. All the freedoms that--that the world has--has come to enjoy. I--you know--I would note that--that it's very difficult to imagine a world with all of that gone--you know--because you're sort of imagining a negative.

We just all take it so for granted that the United States is--has retained this prime position and--and what that actually means. We can get into specifics of how the U.S. is strategically going about trying to maintain its position, but I think that's--you know--we're--we're--we're now fighting over what the world--what kind of world we're going to live in in the next--you know--20, 30 years.

UNKNOWN: Yeah.

DENMARK: Edward, you've written a lot about U.S.-China competition in the New York Times. You've described the face that the Chinese are trying to present to the world as tough but not threatening. If you ask the Chinese about these issues they say they are supportive of freedom of navigation, they're supportive of open markets, they're in favor of ec--economic liberalism, all these things. WONG: Thanks Abe, and thanks for inviting me to this panel. I think that there is a--we can look at it as sort of in the long term or in the short term. I think in the long term, the way I see it playing out is similar to what David Stilwell said and what Dan has alluded to also, which is that there is a fundamental difference in ideologies that--that these two countries, because of the status they occupy now in the world and because of the economic power that each exerts, it's hard to reconcile with each other. And I think that the--you know--the U.S. can work with authoritarian regimes. The question is can the U.S. coexist in a world when an authoritarian regime is as powerful as the U.S. is. And I--economically. I don't think that we've had that before. Like, in the--the Soviet Union never occupied the same economic space in the world that the U.S. does. And so, the U.S. is able to contain the Soviet Union on the--in many different areas. But most importantly, in the area of global markets. And right now, it's unable to do that with China. It's trying to figure out ways to that. So, I think that that's really--sort of--the foundation of the conflict that we're seeing emerge, is that there are these fundamentally different ideological systems.

And--you know--the--China will say that when you talk to Chinese officials or scholars they'll say, "Well, we're--you know--a very practical country and we don't need to export our ideology. That's not our goal." But at--and--you know--there--I think in the U.S. we can debate whether that's their goal or not. I don't think it's clear-cut. But I do think that there are concerns about whether they'll push certain--they'll force constraints on free society such as what we've seen with what happened with the NBA this past week, for example. That because of their power economically that we want access to their markets, and that we are--like, the U.S. supply chains are based in China. There are many different ways in which our economies are intertwined that they have so much leverage over us in this--in the capitalist system that we embrace that they are able to force constraints on us that we don't--that the U.S. doesn't want. And I think that's sort of the fundamental tension at the heart of this relationship.

And it--and it's not an easy one to reconcile bec--and I think this--someone--this was alluded to in the Q and A with Stilwell is that there is this idea that capitalism should be unfettered to a certain degree and so, like, for example institutions, organizations like the NBA should be able to do business on whatever grounds that they want and accept these constraints. But at the same time that acceptance of that undermines the sort of liberal democratic values that we--that America is based on. So, how do you reconcile? I think that's the--that's the sort of--given the eyes of a lot of--sort of--American strategic thinkers, that's the most fundamental threat that I think China poses to America right now. And that's where sort of this clash of systems comes into play.

I think in the--the sort of shorter term or more concrete area of competition, I think the most--probably the greatest point of tension is what China's military ambitions are in the Asia-Pacific region. And I think that Dan talked about sort of the rapid--the rapid buildup of their military capabilities in that area. And I think that the--the U.S. wants to remain the preeminent military power in the Pacific, and China wants that role. And I think that--that--that's another area that can't be reconciled easily. I think that's the--that's the most, like, immediate and concrete source of tension in terms of, like, geostrategic problems that the two countries face.

DENMARK: Jean, you've--you lived in Seoul, you lived in Pyongyang. I'm wondering if you could talk a bit about how you see this competition playing out in the Korean Peninsula. Obviously the competition between the U.S. and China's playing out across Asia, into Europe and to Latin America. But Korea, because of its geographic proximity to China is really one of the leading indicators of how this competition is playing out. I wonder if you could share some of your observations of how it's working in Korea.

LEE: Well, two things come to mind. First of all, we don't have to go that far back in history. But remember that in Korea we still refer to China as Jungkuk; middle--middle kingdom or middle country. And so, there's a long history that goes back centuries of China seeking to play that essential role, the central role within the Asia region. And perhaps we're--what we're seeing is a strong bid to reassert itself as the middle kingdom, as the country that can perhaps treat neighboring nations as vassal states.

I mention it because I--in Pyongyang as well, we always assume that these two countries, North Korea and China, are as close as lips and teeth. But there was so much historical resentment in North Korea on the part of the North Koreans toward that long history of having to serve as kind of a--a--paying respects to this tributary state and having to play this subservient role to China. And that was very palpable in North Korea.

I can tell you what China doesn't want, is U.S. troops up on its border. And I mention that because within our more recent history going back a couple decades, we have the Korean War to consider. And I mention it because next year marks the 70th anniversary of the start of the Korean War, and 70 years since China poured troops into that conflict in order to prevent U.S. troops from being on its border. And while things have certainly changed in the 70 years since, I would say China still does not want to have U.S. troops up on its borders and has been willing to maintain North Korea as sort of a buffer state between China and the Korean Peninsula. And the 28,500 U.S. troops that are positioned and stationed in South Korea.

So, that--that--that more immediate history is something that I think we need to take into account. And I would say also that this has been the basis for North Korea's justification for the building of its nuclear weapons program is the Korean War and this broader U.S.-China conflict. And so that's--that's something that the North Koreans have used very strategically to justify building nuclear weapons. And so, it has some bearing on what's happening today with the diplomacy between the U.S. and--and North Korea.

Small countries like North Korea have always sought to position themselves strategically in this great power competition in North East Asia. And I think we should look at North Korea as a cautionary tale. This is a country that has--even though--this is a--an issue that has--has not--it's not new. Indo-Pacific strategy, for example, may be some--a term that we're hearing just in the last few years. But Korea has been dealing with the concept behind Indo-Pacific strategy for not only decades but for centuries. And North Korea perhaps can be seen as a cautionary tale. What happens when a small country feels like the only way that--that it can remain relevant within this larger U.S.-China competition is to arm itself with nuclear weapons. And I would go one step further and say that if the diplomacy around this issue doesn't resolve itself soon, we may start to see some of the other smaller countries in that region--South Korea and Japan--seeking to arm themselves as well to remain relevant and protect themselves within this broader U.S.-China competition.

DENMARK: I'm wondering if just as a quick follow if you could speak a bit about South Korea as a--as a U.S. ally. 28,500 U.S. troops in--in South Korea, but also China being a critical economic partner for them. That it--they have had--Korea has had a long relationship with China--long complicated relationship with China both historically and so much of their economy today does rely on that relationship with China.

So, they're--they're seeing themselves having to kind of position themselves strategically. However, that THAAD incident really burned South Koreans. And they saw what happens when they don't s--they don't follow the rules that China has laid out for them and how they can be punished economically. Those were unofficial economic sanctions that shuttered and shut down many, many small and medium sized and very large South Korean companies.

And so, it put South Koreans in a posit--a very precarious position of realizing that if they put too much dependence economically on China that China very quickly and very easily could shut their business down, but also having to maintain the relationship with the United States and maintaining that alliance. And not only protection that the United States provides against North Korean aggression, right now the United States is key to resolving or helping to resolve some of the diplomatic tensions with North Korea. DENMARK: Jonathan, you--you do a tremendous amount of work on BRI, on the Belt and Road Initiative. Wondering if you could talk a bit about how that--that initiative is playing out in terms of China's efforts to build power, build influence around the world and how you see it as fitting in with the broader U.S.-China competitive dynamic.

HILLMAN: Sure. So, I think we're--we're just now past the six-year mark of Belt and Road being officially announced. And--you know--it was initially announced in two components; an over land component and then the maritime component. And I think it's been a difficult six years. I think the Belt and Road brand has been tarnished in many ways. And yet, even in the places in which it's really struggled--Malaysia is an example, Pakistan is--is an example--the leaders of those countries go to Beijing at the last forum and they publicly praise this initiative. And so, I think that speaks to a few things.

You know--first, the power of inducements. This is really an effective tool for China. You know--it's--it's something that speaks to the needs of developing economies and that's--so that's why they get 130 plus countries to sign up. Although I--you know--I don't think we should make too much of every MOU that's signed. But it's--it--there's something that's very attractive about that. And I think it should cause the U.S. to think a bit about what are we offering to the rest of the world as we think about how to compete with China.

I think infrastructure as a tool for influence can also be quite difficult. Because it's highly attractive. Everyone wants to sign up. Who wouldn't want to announce a big project? And yet, we know that in most--even in the best economies in the world, the best business environments, most big projects take longer than expected. They cost more than expected. And they deliver fewer benefits than expected. And so, all of this to me, I think points toward incentives that are slated toward announcing many projects. And there's certainly a domestic political incentive in China to announce many projects. But then actually delivering them is extremely difficult.

And so, I think China in--in its own way is learning the lessons that a lot of Western powers have already learned and--you know--that's--there's a reason why the multi-lateral development banks exist. You know--some of that is self-interest and wanting to protect yourself financially and reputationally. And China, in going it alone, has incurred these additional risks. So, I think it's been a difficult six years. And yet, it remains quite attractive. And I think the U.S. needs to think about what could it offer to these countries as well.

Hundreds of millions of Chinese have raised themselves out of poverty through determined hard work after Deng Xiaoping embraced market forces. Nonetheless, China's decision to neither open up politically, nor economically, sends its succession to the WTO in 2001, has forced us to a point where we now must reexamine, recalibrate, and adjust the parameters of our relationship. President Trump's tariff war, and Vice President Pence's October, 2018 speech at the Hudson Institute, have certainly gotten the attention of China's leadership and principally President Xi Jinping. And while I want to see the trade war end as do millions of American farmers, and manufacturers, and business owners, there is bipartisan consensus, that it should not end until we have rebalanced our trade relationship, to allow countries to compete on a level playing field globally.
