And I think frankly, this is going to be a consistent pressure, and challenge from American domestic politics going forward.

We also must make it clear as a nation and a people, that we are not opposed to China's success. That we have a deep respect for China's ancient culture and many accomplishments. And that the United States seeks to partner with China on many of the critical challenges that cross transnational borders. But at the same time, we cannot be naive.

The United States must be vigilant about China's assertiveness abroad and recognize that if we want to preserve the openness that is so central, so beneficial to our country and our place in the world over the last seven decades, we need to clarify our interest to Chinese officials. Work with our allies and partners to present a united message to China, and commit ourselves to domestic democratic renewal. As former U.S. officials like Tom Donald and Richard Haass have pointed out, in the case of competing with China, our foreign policy must begin at home.

In Congress, this means working in good faith with colleagues from both sides of the aisle. To reinvest in our communities and live up to and demonstrate the capacity, the potential of our democratic values to solve the real problems facing American families and America's economy. I want to offer up four specific ways in which the United States must play a leading role in working with its like-minded partners to preserve freedom and openness.

These domains of competition, are our seas and oceans, the industries of the future, the shape of the global economy, and the values systems of our societies. I'll also lay out a series of actions we can take now within the U.S. domestic context in each of these arenas to lay a better and stronger foundation for the future.

First, we must make clear we intend to preserve open ceilings and freedom of navigation around the world. China like us, has an interest in keeping the Red Sea, the Persian Gulf, the Straits of Malacca, other key maritime lanes open. Yet Chinese Island building in the South China Sea. The course of activity, of its maritime militia. The opening of its first overseas military base in Djibouti. All run the risk of constraining international shipping, the free flow of trade, and U.S. military operations.

U.S. leaders must work to bring their Chinese counterparts to the negotiating table, to establish an agreed upon maritime code of conduct, and maritime deterrence. The Chinese should know which of their actions we oppose, and our willingness to respond to preserve open ceilings. We should work with regional partners to improve maritime domain awareness, conduct regular freedom of navigation exercises, and maintain our military presence in the region.

Finally, the Senate should at long last ratify the United Nations convention on the law of the sea. To bolster our ability to resolve maritime disputes peacefully, and enshrine freedom of navigation as an international norm. During the summer of 2012, when I was a newly installed Senator serving on foreign relations, I watched in amazement as literally dozens of credible, serious, diplomatic military and business leaders, testified over a long series of hearings about the urgency of this matter. This treaty first advanced by the Reagan Administration, yet they were ignored by a minority in the other party who claimed that ratification would harm our sovereignty. I think the consequences have been significant, and harmful. And we have not been able to approach the developments in the South China Sea from a position of strength as a result.

There are also steps we can take to improve our ability to safeguard the seas by adjusting our defense budget. Our military doesn't necessarily need to be any larger, but it does have to become more modern. As Chris Brose has written in foreign affairs, a revolution in military affairs is occurring today as artificial intelligence, autonomous systems, ubiquitous sensors, advanced manufacturing, quantum science, and other emerging technologies transform warfare and war fighting platforms and systems in ways we haven't seen in living memory.

We should reprioritize our defense spending accordingly. Brose writes, and I quote, "A military made up of small numbers of very large, very expensive, heavily manned, harder placed systems, will not survive on battlefields. Success will require a different kind of military. One built around large numbers of small, inexpensive, expendable, highly autonomous systems." We look at our annual budget, which is now around 750 billion, and feel safer. By rank orderings, it say we spend more on defense than the next 10 nations combined. But we are not spending it as effectively as we should be, as we must be. Spending $15 billion on an aircraft carrier that is vulnerable to a $10 million anti-ship missile is simply unwise.

We should innovate and invest in new technologies that can swarm, dominate and overwhelm adversaries and thus deter conflict. The United States has an unquestionable and sustained interest in enduring--excuse me, in insuring open seas. This leads me to the next and arguably the most important area in which the United States and China are already competing.

The rules governing emergency--emerging technologies such as 5G, artificial intelligence, semiconductors, quantum computing, biotechnology, and the internet of things. Unlike the world of 30 years ago, each of these new technologies, each of these new technologies has a national security application, and the technical and ethical standards of conduct in fields like cyber, outer space, internet, and in particular internet of things, have yet to be written and embraced. America's dominant position in technology and innovation has given us significant advantages in setting the stage for open, and interoperable systems that underpin the concepts of innovation, freedom, and creative development.

If that advantage instead slides and then shifts to an autocratic actor, who is designing and setting rules in different ways in these core areas, our ability to set the terms of interactions for everything, from business dealings, to social and political discourse based on ethical, inclusive and fair standards is foundationally at risk. Technology is a tool of national power, China is wielding to achieve its aims. The U.S. government and our tech industry should view this as a generational call to action. That's why I'm so determined to help shape our country's approach toward China going forward, and this issue is increasingly the focus of my legislative work on revitalizing U.S. manufacturing, protecting patent holders and patent essential standards and 5G and other emerging sectors, and supporting new technologies in my home state of Delaware and across the country.

The most important thing we can do to respond to China's rise is to strengthen our own capacity for innovation. We must reinvest in federally funded research and development, in STEM education, throughout all of our schools, we should improve coordination between the federal government, and tech hubs across our country. We should work with likeminded partners across Europe and the Indo-Pacific to regain a competitive edge, and lead efforts to form an international technology alliance and establish the rules, and regulations that will sustain, an enduring open internet and set the standards for the technologies of the future.

As we strive to keep the internet open, and the applications of these technologies ethical, we must understand some of these industries will require a degree of government protection. That's why Congress passed reforms to close loopholes in the review of foreign investment known in the United States as CFIUS. As CIS--CSIS think tank scholar, James Lewis, and others have pointed out, U.S. technological leadership has flourished by embracing openness, but this openness cannot be so lazy fair and unguided as to ultimately lead to our demise. I recommend notionally building a high fence around a small yard of our most critical insensitive technologies, but as we safeguard these crown jewels of technology, we also have to strike the right balance to avoid a situation where there is a decoupling of global tech industries between the United States and China. China has countered with forceful tariffs of its own creating uncertainty and shifting global supply chains.

To train foreign governments and how best to negotiate appropriate and better terms when engaging in BRI projects. We also have to offer an alternative. To create a modernized 21st century development finance corporation, an institution with an expanded scope and scale to provide a new tool in our toolkit and a meaningful response. The fourth and final area in which we are likely to compete with China is over values. As CFR scholar Elizabeth Economy has pointed out, under the rule of President Xi Jinping, the CCP is today using over 200 million surveillance cameras to roll out a social credit system that either punishes or rewards Chinese people for their everyday behavior. The number of foreign nongovernmental organizations operating in China has plummeted from roughly 7,000 to 400 in just two years. The CCP has not only repressed a million Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang Province, but has rallied a group of illiberal states to express support for its reeducation camps.

China has raised doubts about whether it will respect Hong Kong's autonomy, and the terms of the 1997 agreement it signed with the United Kingdom, and I think they should respect that agreement, not just in word, but indeed. And the United States should support the right of peaceful protestors in Hong Kong, and encourage China to do the same. We cannot underestimate the role of the United States as a beacon of hope to those around the world who seek to follow a more open and democratic path. I believe we have a profound interest in preserving democratic space in standard--excuse me, in societies around the world. We can do this by promoting standards of good governance, transparency, press freedom, and universal values in our conduct at home, as well as in multi-lateral settings at the United Nations and abroad.

Instead of viewing the UN as a burden that somehow infringes on our sovereignty the United States should reconsider its engagement as an opportunity to display American leadership. There's areas where we can and should collaborate with China, at the UN. The fight against climate change, or in the vital work against Ebola, and addressing nuclear non-proliferation or in UN peace keeping missions. The first time I met a Chinese flag ranking officer was in visiting a UN peace keeping mission in South Sudan. But we need to clearly define our interests in using the UN to preserve the values espoused not just in our own foundational documents, but in the universal declaration of human rights. Since the Trump Administration has withdrawn, from UNESCO and the UN human rights council, China has filled that void calling itself now the champion of multilateralism. And within the human rights council, China advocates for each country to choose its own model of human rights protection in the context of its own national circumstances.

This is a basic disagreement. I believe in the universality and desirability of our democratic system, and I think we need to remain true to our values here at home. And in doing so, demonstrate the system's strengths. The ways in which democratic government can produce strong and better results for its people. Elected officials should not attack or criticize the legitimate reporting of the free press. They shouldn't vilify dedicated career public servants. Instead, we need to roll up our sleeves and demonstrate democracy works by delivering bipartisan solutions on education, infrastructure, healthcare.

We shouldn't be afraid to address our deficit, which is on an unsustainable path, and represents a national security threat in and of itself. We have to be honest with ourselves about our own shortcomings in both domestic and foreign policy, and then address them in a sustainable and bipartisan manner.

In conclusion, I'm glad there wasn't a round of applause. In conclusion, we should use all the tools of U.S. diplomacy, capability and influence to keep the world free, and open and inclusive. Our strategy for dealing with China has to be more sophisticated than simply saying, BRIs a debt trap diplomacy, and China's treatment of the Uighurs is bad. China's theft of intellectual property is wrong. We must have a more complex, broad and deep strategy with regards to China.

While I agree with these three concerns, sentiment is not a strategy. It's an attitude, and I'm concerned it is an attitude based on fear, and a sense of our own insecurity. It is unrealistic--it is profoundly unrealistic, to think that merely repeating our view of why we don't like China's behavior will somehow cause China to change. Xi Jinping and the CCP are redoubling their dedication to their core model, and they believe they have a legitimate case to make to the rest of the world that their model of development works better.

So frankly, I think we should exercise some humility, and be realistic about our prospects of changing the CCP. Today, I've tried to lay out an alternative approach. To be vigilant and clear eyed about what China's doing. To express our disagreements with them, frankly. But, to not allow that to be our sole focus. We have to articulate and demonstrate why our ideas, our standards, and international practices are better for all nations. We need to approach our role in this century with confidence in the American way, in our model that reflects the dignity of the individual, promotes freedom of navigation, fosters economic openness, innovation and competition, through freer and fairer trade, and a model that promotes the free press and free exchange of ideas across an open internet.

QUESTION: Yes. Well, today many analysts would say that China is going to dominate--

LITWAK: Need a microphone.

QUESTION: --providing electricity. They're good at it. They already have a large number of nuclear power plants in their own country. We haven't built one in 30 years. And have no real prospect of doing it.

So, my point is this simply, that I think they're going to go very, very heavily into nuclear power, civil nuclear power, and capture that giant market. 4 billion of the 10 billion people there will be on the earth in about 30 years, will be getting their electricity, their lights and all of the other beneficiaries of nuclear power; automobiles, primarily as you described that sta--Stape.

They're onto something and it makes great sense. But it's going to shift political patrol as controlled, as well as they penetrate these markets.

FREEMAN: had wanted to add a footnote to Stape's comments. The only country that responded to our call for ships to join us in protecting tankers in the Persian Gulf, after the attacks on a Norwegian and a Japanese freighter, apparently by Iran, those are allies of the United States.

And after the uptake in Khurais oilfield were attacked, was China. It wasn't--it was a tentative offer, if it was an offer at all. Of course, in the current atmosphere in Washington, they've got no response at all.

Point I'm making is Stapes correct. Of the drive--the drive on the part of the Chinese to address their vulnerability in energy, is going to have geopolitical consequences. And we're either going to work with the Chinese, or we're going to find them doing things that we don't like.

LITWAK: Well, we've had a rich full day of discussion on the U.S.-China relationship. Speaking for the Wilson Center, it's been a pleasure partnering with the Nixon foundation on this Hugh Hewitt. Hugh, over to you for a final word.

HEWITT: Just thanks to the three gentlemen, and to everyone who has been here either remotely via our live cast, or here in the auditorium. Nixon foundation and Wilson Center, hopes we can do this again. Thank you for being here today. Help me join the panel in thanking them.

(APPLAUSE)

Woodrow Wilson Center Holds Discussion On China And Global 5g

March 04, 2019 10:30 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEMICONDUCTORS INDUSTRY ASSOCIATION GLOBAL POLICY VICE PRESIDENT JIMMY GOODRICH

GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY'S U.S. - CHINA DIALOGUE ON GLOBAL ISSUES MANAGING DIRECTOR DENNIS WILDER

INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY COUNCIL POLICY SENIOR DIRECTOR NAOMI WILSON

WWC KISSINGER INSTITUTE ON CHINA AND THE UNITED STATES DIRECTOR ROBERT DALY

FPRI ASIA PROGRAM DIRECTOR JACQUES DELISLE

[*]DELISLE: I'm Jacques DeLisle, I'm the Director of the Asia Program at FPRI. And I want to thank my colleagues here at the Wilson Center, Robert Daly and the Kissinger Institute and Shakogoto (PH) and the Asia Program for being such generous and co-organizers and co-sponsors for a second year of our annual Asia Program Conference at FPRI.

Recently developments around the world, Scotland's referendum on independence from the United Kingdom, the rise of ISIS as a brutal entity exercising state like power over large loss of territory, Russia's annexation of Crimea, and the re-eruption of conflict between Israel and the Palestinian territories, have raised new doubts about the state of the state.

These have not been so prominent in East Asia, but those problems, those issues do exist in this region as well. Some of the issues that we'll be talking about today involve subnational entities, those with special international status or transnational ties, or those that have aspirations to such status, and maybe even established states that seek to demote their rivals from full state or state-like status.

These issues include Beijing's decision about the chief executive election in Hong Kong and what that tells us about the broader political development there. Concerns in Okinawa which remain a focus of long running controversies including disputes over the U.S. Military presence, and long simmering nationalist and ethnic sentiments.

In Xinjiang, where ethnic and religious unrest have been rising, prompting Chinese authorities to a certain links to international terrorism, and to move forward with a quite strict anti-terrorism law nationally, and the interesting historical controversy over the defunct kingdom--.

DALY: Good morning ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Wilson Center. Welcome to those of you who are here with us in the auditorium and also those who are watching online and via a live Facebook feed.

We are talking this morning about China and global 5G, although our topic is really a little bit broader than that. And the subtitle is trying to get the questions right, trying to frame the issues that you have been reading about probably every morning, which seem to be unfolding at a dizzying rate, trying the get the questions right about what is technology based, what is national security based, what is economic.

Over the past three--over the past five years, really, there have been three major changes in U.S. China relations all related. The first, is that a relationship that has always been both competitive and cooperative is now characterized more by contention, by adversity, than by engagement. There has been a fundamental shift to a more competitive or more contentious relationship.

The second major change, I would argue, is that this is now a worldwide competition. This is not just Beijing to Washington. The competition is playing out globally as these two nations compete to play leading roles in shaping security architectures, trading and financial regimes, norms and practices and value systems.

And then, third large change is that these nations are also competing to play a leading role in the development sale installation and regulation of new technologies. Much as Beijing and Washington disagree, one of the issues that both sides now seem to agree on is the innovation, mastery and leadership of 5G systems, the internet of things, artificial intelligence, quantum computing, robotics, merging biotechnologies.

The mastery of technology henceforth, is going to be the key to hard power, military power, economic power, soft power and global leadership. Beijing and Washington seem to agree on this. Already, this focus on innovation has caused major difficulties for Academia.

We spent a lot of time on this at the Kissinger Institute trying to help American universities, colleges, and the national institutions that manage them understand how they can remain free and open universities while responding to very real threats from Beijing and security concerns from Washington.

So, its interest--it's of interest to academics, but it's much bigger than that. I think what we see again, if you're watching the daily flow of news, is that our technophilia and our technophobia are merging with our Sinophilia and Sinophobia and to become a way of asking about our own national well-being and our place in the world.

This tech challenge from China is causing us to rethink some of our economic models, our defense models and our modes of governance. And this is true, not only in the United States, but in many leading industrialized nations.

And a piece yesterday in the Financial Times called, China Gains the Upper Hand Over Germany, the Author, Wolfgang Munchau, I apologize for slaughtering the pronunciation of his last name, put it like this. He said this is a fundamental, European problem.

Unlike in China, macroeconomic policy, industrial policy and foreign and security policy in Europe are run independently of each other. The Huawei 5G bid, shows that the EU is not well prepared to deal with a connection between security and industrial policy, nor have the Europeans paid much attention the impact of their fiscal rules, not least on defense and security policies.

China, by contrast, has an integrated approach to economic and foreign policy. And so, this is a new issue. It's--it touches on many aspects of our national well-being, and therefore, it's not surprising that we have been over reacting in some cases and have had difficulty framing these issues poorly.

As we said in our advertisement for this event today, there are at least three different levels that we see in our concern about 5G and Chinese technology generally. This tends to focus around questions of Huawei right now, but it's broader than Huawei.

One is the-- specific concern about espionage, about back doors and other means of spying through installed Chinese technologies, and also the vulnerability that the use of Chinese components may cause for various aspects of our national infrastructure.

So, there's a discrete espionage in security issue. Then there's the level of commercial competition. And you will often read in the same article, the same paragraph, that this is about keeping our national champions and our own companies at the lead of these new technologies, our need, our desire to dominate these technologies and retain our preeminence also plays into the reception of Chinese components, Chinese technologies.

And there's a claim, sometimes implicit sometimes explicit, that even if China's methods of competition were licit, and they played by fair rules, and there are many cases in which they seem not to, even if they were, that China's ambitions to technological greatness are somehow illegitimate or a de facto threat, even if the-- rules of the road were observed.

And then there's also the level at which the technological competition becomes the key to a competition for global preeminence. So, obviously, there's a lot of overlap between these three kinds of concerns. But the categories are often confused in our public discourse.

And it often reads as though the installation of Chinese made 5G routers and servers may be a key factor, not just in competition between global tech firms, but it often reads like a key factor in the historic struggle between good and evil. Some of this boils down to a who do you like? Who do you trust? America or China going forward.

So, today we're going to try to work out where we are. And we are delighted to have three leading experts of different aspects of these questions. We will hear first from Naomi Wilson, who is the Senior Director of Policy for Asia at the Information Technology Industry Council or ITI, where she focus on law enforcement and homeland security, cyber security especially with relation to China and Asia.

Before joining ITI, she was at the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, where she was most recently the acting Director for Asia Pacific, where she played a leading role in cyber security, law enforcement and customs cooperation issues as a Senior Advisor to then Secretary of Homeland Security, Jeh Johnson.

She also led the development and implementation of policy initiatives at the Department of Homeland Security for its engagement with China in the area of cybercrime and related issues and also worked on the U.S. China high level dialogue on cybercrime.

Prior to that, she was on the staff of the Senate Committee of Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs. And like all of our speakers today, is a Mandarin speaker, a Mandarin expert. Yeah, so that--that's sort of a key criteria for taking the stage today.

She'll be followed by Jimmy Goodrich to my left, who is the Vice President for Global Policy of the Semiconductor Industry Association. In that capacity, he works closely with all of the member companies, the administration here at the White House, Congress, domestic and international stakeholders, and also foreign government officials to try to advance the Semiconductor Industry Association's international policy agenda.

He is also an executive committee member of the United States Information Technology Office, where he represents the SIA. Jimmy has over a decade of experience working with Chinese and global stakeholders on tech issues and also served recently as the Director of Global Policy at ITI, where he worked on China, Asia Pacific Tech Policy issues related to cyber security trade and internet governance. Prior to that, he also worked on government affairs, Greater China government affairs for Cisco Systems.

Jimmy will then be followed by Dennis Wilder, who is, I think, probably known to most of you, he is assistant professor of the practice in Asia's--in Asian studies at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University, and also serves as managing director of Georgetown's Initiative for U.S.-China Dialogue on Global Issues.

Before coming to Georgetown, he served as the National Security Council's Director for China 2004 to 2005, and then as the NSC Special Assistant to the President and Senior Director for East Asian Affairs for '05 to '09, which took him to Asia many times including for the Beijing Olympics in 2008.

WILDER: Absolutely.

DALY: You had a seat in the stands.

WILDER: I did.

DALY: Very good.

WILDER: I got to see Mr. Phelps do his thing in the great bubble there.

DALY: Aahh.

WILDER: And it was tremendous. And, of course, the American dream team of basketball.

DALY: Which was the opening game.

WILDER: Which was the opening game and I must say, the Chinese audience cheered just as loudly for the American team as they did for the Chinese team that night.

DALY: From '09 to 2015, Dennis served as senior editor of the President's Daily Brief. This is the worldwide intelligence update which is produced under the Director of National Intelligence, which begins the day in the White House.

WILDER: It used to.

DALY: Well, we talked about that.

(LAUGHTER)

We're not going to go into that today. From 2015 to 2016, he was the CIA's Deputy Assistant Director for East Asia and the Pacific. So, a great lineup today, again, thanks to all of you for coming. And I would like, in particular, to thank my colleague, Ray Joan (PH) at the Kissinger Institute who leads for us on following all things tech. It was a key driver in putting this together today. So, thanks to you, Ray. So, again, let's start with Naomi, and then we'll go to Jimmy and Dennis. Thank you.

WILSON: Sure. Well, thank you very much for having me this morning. It's great to see all of you and your interest in China and U.S. tech issues. So, I'll start off by saying, Robert, thank you for holding this event, in particular, your framing of the need to get the questions right, is especially important because we're in an environment with a lot of assumptions, a lot of assertions, and a lot of conflation where facts are--are not necessarily relied upon in the way that I think we would like to see them.

So, essentially, you can't understand the problem until you understand what question you're trying to solve for. So, discussions like this are extremely helpful. There's a definite need to have informed discussions to talk about threats and risks and what they mean in the context of the U.S. and China and tech and how and whether threats can be mitigated.

Just to say, it's China, therefore, it's a threat, is not sufficient in a global economy. And it's not instructive as we look to see how the U.S. can advance in technological innovations and compete with China going forward.

So, at ITI, which is my association, we pride ourselves on working with the public sector to develop fact-based and rigorous analysis of problems and assessments and try to find out what is the right policy solution going forward.

So, in my opening remarks today, I'd like to outline a few things. First, is how the U.S. government and industry view challenges with respect to China and tech. And I'll be pulling a little bit from my background at DHS as well as my current position at ITI working with tech companies.

I'll also speak a bit to how the U.S. government perspective has evolved over the past few years and into the current administration and the need for public and private sector partnership in order to identify these questions and work together to resolve them.

So, with that, with respect to the U.S. government and industry concerns, I would say that they are similar, yet, there are differences in tactics and approach. And obviously, for the U.S. government, in particular, there is a heavy emphasis on what constitutes a national security threat.

I will say that I feel very fortunate in the private sector that the tech industry has such a good relationship with the U.S. government especially with issues that are of greatest concern regarding China's tech policies. The U.S. government has been great at listening to industry input and concerns in terms of understanding the dynamics of that market.

So, industry concerns should come as no real surprise. These are long standing concerns involving market access, foreign companies' inability to obtain licenses and compete on equal footing with Chinese companies, data localization requirements, force partnerships with Chinese companies and security review regimes that are ambiguous to say the least.

DALY: To add to localization requirements break that down a little bit?

WILSON: Oh, sure, that would be fine. I did not use an acronym though. Do I get points for that? So, data localization is an issue that we see, not only in China, but around the world. Tech companies, and not only tech companies, any modern day multi-national company relies on the flow of data across borders for purposes of serving their customers.

And it's not only customer data, but it's also cyber security data, for example--example, sharing vulnerabilities to determine whether certain systems are affected and how to patch those vulnerabilities.

So, that instantaneous real-time flow of information is essential to doing business and to maintaining network security. China and other countries have taken to instituting, or at least drafting policies that require data to be maintained in country.

So, companies are required to build servers that house the data in country, the idea being that if it's closer than law enforcement, government has greater access to it or easier access where they can control it to a better degree. Those are all false assumptions, but that's another conversation. So, I'll stop there on data localization.

So, in terms of the U.S. government concerns, currently we see an array of concerns. And I think this is emblematic of policy makers and U.S. citizens trying to come to terms with the competitive and cooperative dynamics between the U.S. and China. And to what extent economic security also effects national security.

So, we've seen a lot of blurred lines between these two elements that used to be dealt with pretty distinctly. And I want to make clear also that when we--when we talk about security and especially national security, I know that often there's a number of characterizations in the media of big tech companies and putting the profit first.

I want to make clear that tech companies take national security and security of systems in general extremely seriously. It is part of their livelihood. It is what they stake their name on and their consumers trust in them on. So, it's really not an either-or situation from a tech company perspective. And I want to make that clear.

In terms of what we hear most often from the U.S. government regarding their concerns, it's a mix of economic and security. A lot of them mirror our own concerns along the lines of market access and unfair Chinese tech and trade policies. And these are being dealt with currently in the context of the 301 investigation, which is led by USTR and the ongoing trade talks.

We also see concerns with respect to the economic impact of IP theft as well as what it means to have an unfair technological advantage and what risk that poses in the future. Chinese investment in the U.S. is another security concern that the U.S. government has worked on over the past year.

We've seen the reform of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S. or CFIUS, which was reformed via legislation last year as well as attention to export control laws which control the export of potentially sensitive technology for national security purposes. And commerce is working on implementing an updated process of that right now.

Then we see the various supply chain concerns. And this varies from respect to specific companies or the desire to move supply chains back to the U.S. And we see it seems like on a weekly basis, new bills coming out of the Hill that have this--this focus on what does the supply chain mean to security and to American economic status generally.

And finally, there's the big question of technological competitiveness and is China winning in the race for AI and 5G? So, as the U.S. government is trying to deal with all of these things, and as the private sector is trying to keep up with their efforts to deal with all of these various policies and inform that process.

I think it's also important to take a step back and to look at the evolution of the current USG concerns. So, over the past decade, the U.S. government has become--become somewhat used to China gaming the system and playing by its own rules.

There had been a general thought that bringing China into the fold, into the international system would help normalize Chinese practices over time. And this has worked in some respects and not others. I think we've seen pretty dramatic changes outside of the realm of--of tech in China's approach to climate change.

But with respect to their alignment with the WTO, not so much. So, there is a general acceptance, as you mentioned, Robert, in your opening remarks of the competitive and cooperative relationship between the U.S. and China. And I think that is still true and that needs to be constantly reinforced because China's not going anywhere and we're not going anywhere. And our relationships are so intertwined that it behooves us to make sure that that relationship functions.

So, in the current administration, I've seen the U.S. become increasingly fed up with China's behavior and beginning to respond in a more assertive way. And this--this goes back to the previous administration.

There was definitely a shift towards the end of the Obama Administration of being more assertive, tolerating more friction in the relationship and excepting that China might be embarrassed by certain things, and react.

So, we might no longer have a cyber dialogue between the two countries. And so, China responded to a number of U.S. actions including indictments of Chinese PLA hackers, public--increasing public criticism of China's theft of IP via cyber hacking including right up to the runup of President Xi's 2015 state visit with President Obama and sanctioning Chinese companies for violations of U.S. export controls.

So, in the current administration, and in Congress, there's increasingly heightened concerns and tech seems to be more and more at the center. There's even less tolerance for Chinese behavior and empty commitments. And I think there's a lot of validity to that sentiment.

So, right now, we see the administration and, in particular, USTR Ambassador Lighthizer, coming down harder on China's unfair trade practices. We see new supply chain policies and legislation, many of which have named specific companies and intend to ban those companies, export control reform.

And this is all led to increasing--an increasing and I think, troubling drive to wall off U.S. tech in order to safeguard it and to protect our crown jewels that may be used for national security purposes and or for competitive advantage.

And there's been a lot of talk of bringing the supply chains back to the U.S. Can't you just get out of China? Why don't you make things in the U.S.? It would be so much better for the U.S. economy. Never mind that we're in a global economy with intertwined supply chains, and restricting exports of our valued technology.

So, policy makers are asking a lot of big, complex questions that will have significant ripple effects for the tech sector for the economy and for U.S. technological competitiveness. And I think now is a really important time to step back and unpack those questions and unpack the assumptions that are leading to those questions and the potential policy solutions on the table.

And this is where the private and public sector partnership is essential. And I'll take an example of cyber security so that--to be clear. So, with respect to cyber security, the U.S. government is not on private sector networks. So, they rely on the private sector to tell them what is going on, especially with respect to hacking for economic purposes.

The U.S. government certainly has its own tools, and insights, in terms of general espionage practices, but they don't have the whole picture and neither does the tech sector and the companies. So, in order to understand the problem and ask ourselves the right questions, we really need that full picture.

So, it's essential that the private sector and the public sector collaborate, compare notes and come up with the right solutions. And we can start by acknowledging that there are security concerns. There are risks. But we have to insist that any concern be dealt with in an evidence based and rigorous process-oriented approach.

So, from my perspective, we look at what is the risk? Can the risk be mitigated? What are the current tools available? And how do we scope the tools or create new tools to avoid unintended or adverse consequences?

And speaking for ITI, we have worked extensively with Congress and the U.S. government in terms of CFIUS reform as well as export controls reform, hoping to shed some light on how to scope these important policies that are clearly geared towards a national security need appropriately, in a way that we are not jeopardizing our own innovation and technological progress going forward. I will stop there.

DALY: Thank you, Naomi. Jimmy.

GOODRICH: Sure, thanks. Naomi, I think, framed it really well in thinking about the broad picture between balancing security and economics. And when we say, well, the private sector can do it, my second home, my vacation home is in Chautauqua County, New York, the poorest county in the state.

You want to talk about rural cyber, come to my county. Half the county doesn't have anything but dial up service, still. So, the private sector is not doing a fantastic job in many rural areas of the United States on this. So, I'm not so sure that leaving this all to the private sector is, necessarily, the answer to these questions.

We created the interstate highway system for a reason. And it was highly successful and General President Eisenhower did it because, as a young soldier, he took a road trip across the United States and realized that there were no good roads in the United States. I wonder, in the cyber realm, whether we need to rethink, again, this aversion to industrial policies.

And I'll leave it there.

DALY: Okay, well thank you. Please raise your hand, if you have a question and do wait for a microphone. Yes, right back here.

QUESTION: John Owen (PH) with McClarty Associates. During the Cold War, although it was cold comfort, we had something called mutually assured, mutual assured destruction, MAD. Is there anything analogous in the cyber sphere, is there some point at which an action on one side will trigger something that would, ultimately, be a disincentive for that actor?

DALY: So, this is about threats, infrastructure, early cyber warfare. Dennis, do you want to take first?

WILDER: Sure. I actually was listening to former Director Woolsey talk about this the other day and I'll give you his point of view. And that is that the United States needs to demonstrate, more fully, our offensive cyber capabilities to the Chinese, that we need to be more up front. That if we wanted to, we could do a lot to them.

That, I guess, would be in your category of a declarative mutual third destruction strategy. John, to be honest with you, I haven't thought this question through enough, mutually assured destruction strategies are pretty extreme. But certainly, I think, I guess what I'd say is the Chinese need to think about this.

We are capable of a lot. Without going into detail, there are several books you can read on what we've done in a certain foreign country that was quite dramatic in this regard. You know, we have cyber command, we are developing offensive capabilities for use in wartime. So, I think, if the Chinese push us to this point, there may well be some point of decision to go in that direction, but I haven't seen it yet.

DALY: You talking about Stuxnet?

WILDER: I didn't say that word.

GOODRICH: I would just add to that, I think there's, also, the economic realm. We should think about the mutual interdependence, itself, should be a deterrent towards greater bifurcation of the systems. And I think, as you see, if you see an inability to contain the security concerns, you're going to see greater bifurcation or splintering, as some say, of the global ICT infrastructure.

And that would be devastating for both countries, given that, you know, if you look at the revenue model of any global tech company, China's critical for them, and China, today, and they have a very long road to go before they're completely independent and they may never will be. So, they need access to all these systems and components, just like anyone else does.

So, the more they push on this front, the more that we push. The greater economic cost it's going to inflict on both countries, and you know, that in the past has also been another form of deterrents towards some of the most unfavorable outcomes.

DALY: Okay, over here.

QUESTION: Yes, I'm Dr. Sam Hancock of EmeraldPlanet, EmeraldPlanet TV. And this goes to Dennis, your statement about many of these rural areas. You know, there's about 48 million Americans that don't have access, really, to the internet. And Actually, in some ways, that's growing. But also, if you look at the inner city, you go to Ward 8 or Ward 7, here in Washington D.C., you have some of the same thing. So, you have many of your inner city, these legacy cities do not have, you know, the high-speed internet.

How do we bring this about in going to, you know, Jimmy's earlier comments on, you know, access and technologies and all that? How do we bring this to the people and then, are we avoiding using what's called TV white space that may be a way to easily and inexpensively bring this type of connectivity? But as we expand the technologies in this competitive world, we have to have all these people, these 48 million people are important to the economy and they're locked out.

DALY: Thank you. Maybe, after Dennis's comment, also, Naomi, is there anything you see that the public sector can do to incentivize the private sector to go into these areas that haven't been deemed profitable?

WILDER: Well, I hate to sound like some of the democratic presidential candidates here, but I think there is a socioeconomic divide in this country in terms of cyber. That is a real inequality that we don't look at. You know, I think many of us in higher socioeconomic classes in this country simply assume that everybody has what we have, and they don't.

And there are barriers based on price and there are barriers that we've talked about based on infrastructure. This is why I-I-I really reject the notion that government doesn't have a role to play, here. I think government has a big role to play and we just need to find what that role is because I agree, it is outrageous that that many Americans are not being brought into the 21st century, right now.

WILSON: So, in terms of incentives, I agree with what has been said, thus far, that government does have a role in terms of incentivizing technological development and incentivizing students to be able to and to choose the path of learning of higher technology and engineering.

I will say, I do think that the burden is on tech companies with respect to this specific problem set. And I say that because tech does not have the best reputation, right now. And to the extent that tech can demonstrate that there is societal benefit, that they care about the rural communities and those that are not as well served as the upper, middle-class communities.

I think that is to the tech sector's advantage. So, I don't know if there's an incentive that the government can or should create in that area but I, absolutely, see it as a worthwhile endeavor for the tech sector, at large. They have the capability and we need to start demonstrating, more publicly, that there is real societal benefit to these new technologies.

GOODRICH: I'll just add one point there. I think, you know, there are ways that we can, and we have actually been successful in order to spur demand. I think, you know, government policy is good when we can think about how do we get more people using the devices, the technology across a greater swath of the economic spectrum.

And in a way, that's technology neutral so that whichever way the government stimulates that demand, it allows the private sector to fill a void. One good example we have right now, obviously, we could do better, hence your example in New York, is the Universal Service Fund where, you know, everyone pays a, literally, in your cell phone tax, your phone bill, goes back to a fund that the FCC manages to help subsidize rural broadband development in communities. And we, also, had an increase in that in the stimulus package in '08, as well. And that was during 4G and 3G deployment.

So, you know, the--obviously, the scale isn't big enough if we still have a gap there. But that's one way government can, actually, help bring technology to impoverished communities and that's, in a way, that's technology neutral, we're not picking winners. It's simply stimulating the demand side.

And incentivizing these carriers to give the technology areas where there may not be that financial incentive, to date. One other thing is, on the technology perspective, actually 5G, in some ways, will help alleviate part of the problem in that it really gets the user off the fixed network because the signal goes a lot further. It can go through a lot more buildings, get through a lot more roadblocks like mountains and other things.

So, the technology, also, will bring improvements on that front.

DALY: And is it not, also, true that Huawei and other Chinese companies are offering to help bridge this gap because they bring in lower cost components, everything from the handsets to the routers and servers. So, this has been part of their pitch in Africa and South America and around the world that they can, actually, do this at cost and fill the gap if they are permitted to.

WILDER: Yeah, many small providers in the United States use Huawei equipment because of the cost factor.

DALY: Okay, come right down front, sir.

QUESTION: Chris McRay (PH). So, I wanted to build a bit on that a bit further. I mean, Americans are, presumably, 7 percent or 8 percent of the world's population. If we think about, sort of 5G for human development and if we go back to what Kissinger would, himself, was saying, in November 2016, you know, what do countries like India, as well as China, as well as Africa, actually want from 5G. In some ways, Huawei is actually nearer the on the ground things like education and health and agriculture.

I mean, maybe the problem is different sectors and I understand why some sectors are really confidential for Americans but it would be a terrible shame for the whole of the world, I think, if we get all these things modeled up and don't realize that, in some ways, distributed technology, as far as I understand it with 5G which Norway and China's, you know, more massively done across huge continents also is incredibly valuable for the future.

So, I'd just like to know how you see that side of things.

DALY: I think the panel, so far has been really careful to acknowledge this and really not to vilify Huawei's action, globally. Does anyone have anything to add. It's well said, anything to add on that?

WILDER: I-I-I think that, in the third world, Huawei products and ZTE products are incredibly important at this point. We don't make handsets that are as cheap as what a Huawei or a ZTE does. We don't make these things. So again, I think one, we get back to this question of risk benefit. And from the point of view of many third world countries, the risk of having Huawei potentially cooperating with their government is less of a concern than getting these kinds of goods and services to their people.

And so, different countries are going to make different calculations on the risk benefit scale.

DALY: But just a little pressure on that. When they begin, some countries in considering making different calculations, have heard threats from us that, if you cooperate, if you have Chinese systems, that that may limit cooperation's of certain kinds with the United States. Does anybody want to comment on that as sort of a policy or pitch?

WILDER: I think that's most important in NATO and with our allies. Because the-the question at that point becomes, how do you share sensitive information over telecommunication systems if you can't do that. Now, I will say, there is another factor that somebody brought up to me the other day that I'm still working through in my own head.

And that is allowing China influence over you. In other words, if you go Huawei, and then you do something with Taiwan that Beijing may not approve of, are you going to find that your supplies from Huawei are mysteriously delayed. You know, there is a question of, once you make this choice, have you put yourself in a position where you might be the subject of undue influence.

Again, that's a hypothetical but we certainly have seen Chinese economic sanctions against people who did things, particularly, in relation to Taiwan that they didn't like.

DALY: Thank you, Naomi.

WILSON: I'll just add on the intent versus capability side. So, from my perspective, this is another area where we have to be careful about making assumptions and what that leads us to conclude. So, even if a Chinese--if we accept the fact that a Chinese company may be directed by the Chinese government to do something, that does not mean, in and of itself, that they have the capability to do that.

And, or that it poses a threat and cannot be mitigated. So, those are all subsequent questions that we have to ask. To me, the can a company be influenced by a government is a very political question. And there's nothing to stop any company, really, apart from standing on its principles and its economic life, to stop a company from being influenced by any number of parties.

Any company of any origin could be influenced by an entity that seeks to buy it off. So, just to say that because a company could possibly be directed by a government, I think, is not sufficient in terms of what do we do about that from a policy perspective.

DALY: Over here, microphone.

(OFF-MIC)

QUESTION: One argument I have heard is that Huawei has a big advantage over most other competitors in 5G, a year or two, in fact, I've heard. Is that correct or not, just a factual question. Thank you.

GOODRICH: There's no doubt that Huawei is extremely competitive in telecommunications technology. It's the largest in terms of revenue and they also, now, have the largest spend into research development, surpassing their peers, particularly, from their European competitors.

So, and in many aspects, Huawei is looking to vertically integrate their technology eco system to be able to produce even some of their own chips. Now, they're not able to do everything they need but some of those, they're very competitive or even more competitive than some of their competitors.

So, I mean, Huawei is absolutely a global giant and that's--that's not something that's going to change in terms of, you know, are they ahead or not. I think one interesting benchmark to look at, again, is R&D. And if you're not able to reinvest your profits back in the research and development, if you have to, you know, pay off debt loans, restructure your workforce in other countries, those are things that Huawei, right now, is not under pressure to do, unlike their other competitors.

And so, they just have a lot more capital to spend whether it's into their people or technology and, unless that changes, it's going to be very difficult for their competitors to maintain their competitiveness with them. That being said, you know, it's not a one single winner takes all across the entire technology spectrum, you know. As I mentioned before, 5G is really an eco-system of technology and there are areas in which each telecommunications hardware vendor does things that others don't in terms of comparative advantage.

And so, some of the European vendors have very strong and excelled, the core network, these big backend data centers that process all the data from all the phones and the data. That's something really, traditionally, the European vendors have had a lot of strength in, whereas, a lot of the Chinese telecommunication vendor experience comes in the radio network which are the base stations that send the signals out to the phones and other devices.

And so, I think there's compliment--there are complimentary advantages that each has but that Huawei still, from a scale perspective, is surely ahead.

DALY: Okay, yes sir, in the middle.

QUESTION: My name is Jose (INAUDIBLE) from, I'm a graduate student at American University. And my question has to do with what, regarding the conference in Barcelona that happened a week ago. Some press had characterized as Huawei as the architect of the 5G infrastructure. So, given that fact then, Dennis mentioned the different extenders that Chinese companies have, and the Chinese government also has and all the different times that policy has regarding this technology like 5G, IOT, RAI.

Are democracies and market economies ready to deal with this--with this competition with having a competitor like China? Are our systems, are democratic institutions ready to go with these kinds of technologies?

DALY: Who wants to go first, you want to go ahead?

WILDER: I'll give it a shot. I think you asked a really excellent question that we're struggling with. As Jimmy was talking about and I think it's an important point, one of the things that Huawei has is very deep pockets. They are able to access capital and they are able to go into markets and bid very low because they have, essentially, the backing of the Chinese government.

Our companies in democracies don't get that particular advantage, right. Our companies have to figure out how to do this on an economically efficient level and I have, when I was at the White House, and you know, I would have American companies come to me and say, we can't compete in Africa. We come in with a bid and Huawei always under bids us. And they can do that because they can take a loss that our stockholders aren't going to let us take, right.

If an American company were to go out and do a bunch of loss leaders in Africa, think what happens to it. So, there is this problem. There's no question that there is a real difference between our economic systems and our political systems that makes it hard in various markets to compete. And we haven't figured out that problem and so, I do think that this is an enormous advantage for the Chinese companies.

That said, I also think we still have enormous advantages in innovation, creativity that they don't have because one of the things that happens when you have such deep pockets is your incentive to be efficient and creative and innovate, is decreased. But I'll let Jimmy speak to that.

GOODRICH: Yeah, I think that, you know, brings us to the broader question of, you know, in terms of competitiveness, having a fair market place is really critical for the success of U.S. companies. That's where we've thrived and, you know, the--it's a well-known fact that the Chinese government certainly provides a whole lot of capital that's non-market based to their companies.

And we need to do something to figure out what are the new rules going to be because, clearly, the, you know the World Trade Organization, the organization that governs a lot of these rules, particularly around subsidies hasn't done its work that it should have because we're here, today, and none of that was every really challenged or disputed in the WTO.

And that's because the current rules where they sit are really perspective in that a country can actually challenge subsidies that were given, say, to China's domestic telecom vendors. But you have to wait until you're harmed. And so, if you're already harmed, it's basically a coroner's inquest. You're trying to get reparations for the damage that was done to you.

And so, right now, actually, the United States is working with its allies. Right now, it's just the European Union and Japan, to try to rewrite those rules because they don't want that to happen again. We all share that common goal of trying to ensure that China, you know, they want these industries, but they have to ensure that they don't destroy them in the process of creating them.

And that's really, I think, ultimately bad for innovation, too. If you look at whether it's electric vehicles or solar or some lithium batteries. China's making huge government investments into these sectors. They might drive the cost down in terms of the commodity but they, also, cut off the innovation because they lead to a lowest common denominator of product in terms of pricing.

And so, that really squeezes out an ability to invest into future technologies, diverse technologies, for different applications. So, I was talking to a panel of experts on solar technology and saying, actually, there's much better, more efficient, higher powered solar panels out there but because the market's been crowded out by cheap imports from China, they can't compete against them.

So, I think ultimately, how do we change the rules so this doesn't happen again and, thankfully, we're thinking about it but still a long way to go.

DALY: Naomi, any final thoughts?

WILSON: I see, right now, different dynamics in the international system and I think Jimmy is absolutely right that there are certain rules within the WTO that are no longer functioning as they should, no longer necessarily applicable. And to your point about democracies and market-oriented economies versus those that are more top down, I do think we're at a point in time where the world economy is trying to reconcile those different systems and we still do very much need agreed upon norms and rules of the road but it's fairly obvious that the ones we're currently working off of are outdated.

DALY: Well thank you, and thanks to all of you for joining us. Please do stay tuned with the Kissinger Institute and the Wilson Center as a whole will be paying increasing attention to this question of security, espionage, commerce, tech, with relation to U.S., China relations broadly and we hope you will join us again, soon. Thank you to Dennis Wilder, Naomi Wilson and Jimmy Goodrich for your time today. Thanks.

(APPLAUSE)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, September 16th.

Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

We are waiting on the Fed. We will get the very latest commentary and rate decision this afternoon. A lot of focus on Fed Chair Jay Powell what he says about supporting economic recovery. No expectation that we will see any more stimulus or a change in the zero percent rates.

The strength of the American consumer also on the table this morning. August retail sales numbers out at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We will have those numbers as soon as they hit the tape and show you the impact on markets.

I know that CFIUS is looking at this and you've got representatives from Treasury and Commerce so we'll wait to see what it says but you -- you answered the question exactly what I expected.

Real quick Senator, is there any negotiation going on now for another stimulus bill or is that dead in the water? It certainly doesn't feel like there's any real negotiations going on. Am I right about that?

BLACKBURN: Well, the little bit of daylight on this is that now you have a hundred House members who are pushing Pelosi. And you've got a lot of these suburban women that won. And now they are pushing back at her and saying what are you doing?

Because we put a great deal on the floor in the Senate last week. It would have covered the liability, the schools, the testing, and the PPP, the UI Plus Up (ph) and the Democrats said no. It even had post office money in there. They were so concerned about the post office.

They want the American people to suffer. And to suffer from now to November. I think that is despicable.

BARTIROMO: Wow. It certainly sounds disgraceful. Senator, it's good to see you this morning.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Thank you very much.

BLACKBURN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching. Senator Marsha Blackburn --

BLACKBURN: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: -- this morning.

Coming up U.S. business is relying on Chinese Cotton. Once CEO weighs in on that.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Rising tensions with China heightening. The Trump administration announce new restrictions on Monday on imports of apparel, hair products and technology goods from certain companies in China's Xinjiang region. This after, of course, the news of force labor and other human rights violations in the region where you've got one million Uighurs locked up in camps.

Bob Nardelli, the worry here is that banning things like cotton are going to impact American companies. But they're being made in this region by Uighurs who are locked up. Your take.

NARDELLI: Yes, Maria. I've said several times now, one of the biggest challenges we're facing right now in the economy is getting the supply chains back in order.

To your point, a number of companies that I'm personally experiencing or hearing from their concern over supply chains. A recent CEO survey said 45 percent of the CEOs are concerned about supply chain. One, because of the issue you just mentioned. Number two, because of the tariffs. Number three, some of the reductions in tariffs whose timing now is running out and therefore the tariff number will go back on.

So I'm seeing inundation of request to move from China to other areas whether it was onshore or other countries is that are very favorable towards production, labor, material cost, et cetera whether it is in Vietnam or some of the local countries there.

So this is a big, big challenge. I think a lot of us went offshore not by design but because we're trying to compete globally, because we were disadvantaged with corporate tax. We saw that with this administration as a tremendous help. So we saw a lot of onshore and I think we're going to see a lot more of that, Maria, as a result of supply chain.

Se see some of the largest industry, the automotive industry still suffering from supply chain availability.

BARTIROMO: Well, this is a really good point because the whole -- movement in the Trump administration to moving supply chains to America. Will we see retaliation? Will we see an impact to the companies involved?

Nancy Lazar over at Cornerstone Macro counts more than 100 companies that have already moved their supply chains and yesterday we had Ken Cuccinelli on, acting deputy secretary of Homeland Security who said these extraordinary human rights violations demanding an extraordinary response. This is modern day slavery. What's the answer?

NARDELLI: You know, I think a lot of this Maria, from again my experience when I was at General Electric or Home Depot and Chrysler, you know, we had a very deliberate organization that would go over and personally inspect the facilities to make sure that we were not involved with child labor or some of the issues. We look for safety and we look for quality. We look for humanitarian requirements.

So again, I think corporations, businesses have to be very diligent before they sign up for that. Or if they're there today they better go back and recheck all of it. But you certainly feel you get blindsided and I think we all have to be thinking about supply chain. We need to shorten supply chain. The advantage of that is less work and capital, we have less inventory on the water. And again, just the ability for continuity.

I think the street, Wall Street is going to have to reward companies who have addressed the supply chain just like they're looking at ESQ (ph) Maria. They've got to look at it. Either prices are going to go up, right or markers (ph) are going to go down. So we've got to look at that as corporate America and how we're going address it.

BARTIROMO: All right. Coming up, a programming note. Join me Friday at 8:00 a.m. Eastern, for our power panel hour.

Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, "THE FIVE" co-host Juan Williams and "The Hill" reporter Joe Concha will all weigh in on the hottest topics making headlines. That's Friday 8:00 a.m. Don't miss it.

But first Aston Martin introducing a new way you can drive in your living room. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Time for "The Morning Buzz".

First up, "The Material Girl" on the silver screen. Madonna is going to co- write and direct a film about her life. She says there's no one better to tell her story and the focus will be on the music.

Dagen, you're going to go see it?

MCDOWELL: I would see it. She's co-writing it with Diablo Cody who wrote one of kind of the great coming of age films "Juno". I think she won an Academy Award for that.

What is better than movie potentially is Madonna is on social media doing videos of her working during the pandemic shutdown with Diablo on the script. And let's just say it's interesting. So that might be better than the flick.

BARTIROMO: All right. Next up getting behind the wheel of an Aston Martin without actually leaving your home. The automaker unveils a driving simulator to give you a sense of what it is like to race.

Bob, you're a car guy. It will cost you. The simulator has $74,000 price tag. What do you think?

NARDELLI: Yes. I'm a car guy. But you know, I think they advertise that as privilege gamers, which I don't fit into that category for $74,000. Maria, I'm sure it would be exciting, but I got to believe it is a pretty limited market out there.

They probably should have taken that Apple approach on having some opening price points to get people behind that wheel of the simulator.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, I think that when you're talking about an Aston Martin, I frankly don't want to do it in my living room. I mean this is really going to be a seller? I think for a car -- you know what I mean Dagen? When you're a car person, and I know you are as well, I've heard all your stories about the Beamer. But you know, you want to be on the road, right Dagen?

MCDOWELL: BMW did write and replace the automobile by the way. So I have to give them immense amount of credit for stepping up quickly without any real pressure from me on that.

But here's the issue, when you buy a high performance car you really need to kind of -- kind of let her loose. Need to take it to a track. So you can't just go out in your high performance car and hit, you know, a 150 on the interstate because you'll go to jail.

So this is a way of kind of you get the experience if you own say an Aston Martin which I never would, you could get the experience of what it's like to drive it. So I kind of understand this because and again it will keep you out of the hoosgow and you avoid getting arrested for driving recklessly or, you know, getting a speeding ticket.

BARTIROMO: Driving a 150. You've never gone that fast?

MCDOWELL: Me? Of course not. Never, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. I like to see. I'D like to see you driving on THE road in your beamer one OF these days. I know people recognize you in that car too. Recognize driving your BMW.

MCDOWELL: One, there is an I-8 that I drove which has got gold wings and it's a gas/electric hybrid. That's very recognizable. And yes, people would tweet say did I just see you driving down I-81. That actually happened.

BARTIROMO: That's funny.

All right. We're waiting on August retail sales number this morning. We're going to get to that number as soon as it hits the tape in about 30 minutes' time 8:30 a.m. Eastern.

Markets are rallying this morning. Dow Industrials up 135 points right now.

Plus don't miss my interview with White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany. She's coming up next on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, live on Fox Business.
