DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 31st.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

The 2020 race tightening up. Joe Biden back on the campaign trail heading to Pennsylvania. President Trump heading to Wisconsin tomorrow with a message on crime and justice.

Later this hour, former Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker on the controversy surrounding the president's visit to Kenosha. The current governor says don't come. What does the former governor have to say?

At 8:30 a.m. Eastern, assistant to the president for trade and manufacturing, Peter Navarro, on tensions with China, including the latest hurdles in a TikTok sale.

Apple and Tesla stock splitting today. What it could mean for their record- breaking runs this year.

Looking at futures. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq kicking off this day, the final trading day of August, in record territory.

A new look for the Dow 30 today. Salesforce, Amgen and Honeywell replacing Exxon, Pfizer and Raytheon.

The Dow, Nasdaq and S&P on track for their fifth straight month of gains.

We get physical with Amazon's new fitness tracker, Halo, and it can do more than just count your steps.

Sylvester Stallone, meantime, taking a new swipe at Rocky and Ivan Drago's big battle in the ring.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA live right now.

Checking global market action. European markets are in the green. The French and German markets to the plus side. London's FTSE is closed for a holiday.

In Asia overnight markets mostly lower but Japan's Nikkei bucking the trend, closing up in the green north of 1 percent to the plus side.

Warren Buffet's Berkshire Hathaway announcing a $6 billion investment in five Japanese companies, including Mitsubishi and Mitsui.

Meantime, the coronavirus hitting China's largest state-owned banks. They're reporting large profit declines as they increase provisions against bad loans.

Some of the top stories we're watching this morning, more unrest in Portland.

Cheryl Casone has the details.

Hey, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Dagen, rough weekend. The violence following a clash over the weekend between supporters of the president and counter protesters. One person was shot and killed.

Meantime, a war of words breaking out between the president and the mayor of Portland. President Trump calling Mayor Ted Wheeler a fool. Wheeler firing back, blaming the president for Portland's riots and violence.

Well, holding off. Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers asking President Trump to reconsider his visit to Kenosha tomorrow. Protests in the area not letting up just one week after the shooting of Jacob Blake by police officers. Evers say he's concerned that the visit will, quote, hinder their healing.

Well, new restrictions from China slowing talks to sell the U.S. operations of TikTok. The rules issued Friday affect the export of artificial intelligence technology and reportedly are aimed at delaying, but not banning a preliminary deal. China will reportedly have to approve any deal. TikTok's parent company ByteDance now in talks with Microsoft, Walmart and Oracle. Shares of all three companies trading lower in the pre-market. Walmart down almost 4 percent. That is a Dow component.

Well, the head of the Food and Drug Administration reportedly is willing to fast track a Covid-19 vaccine before the end of phase three trials. Stephen Hahn telling London's "Financial Times," that decision would be based on the science and the data, not political pressure from the White House. The FDA recently approved the use of convalescent plasma for Covid-19 patients after President Trump accused the FDA of deliberately slowing down its work to approve new treatments and vaccines.

Well, United Airlines announcing it will no longer charge travelers $200 change fees on domestic flights for good. And American Airlines is cutting capacity by 55 percent in October as the coronavirus pandemic continues to hurt travel. The airliner announced earlier this month the plans to suspend service to 15 U.S. cities. That starts October 7th. Both American and United are higher in pre-market trading, Dagen.

And those are your headlines.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl, we'll see you at the bottom of the hour.

Joining the conversation, meantime, all morning long, Lee Carter and Cabot Phillips. We'll hear from you in just moments.

Right now it's time for the "word on Wall Street."

Joining me now, Bulltick Capital Markets head of global research, Kathryn Rooney Vera, Michael Lee Strategy's Michael Lee, and the Bahnsen Group's CEO and managing partner David Bahnsen.

Futures are pointing to gains ahead of the last trading day of the month. The Dow finishing its best August in more than 30 years as markets bounce back from the coronavirus pandemic. That gauge seeing a 57 percent rise since March.

David, your take on these markets right here, right now?

DAVID BAHNSEN, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, THE BAHNSEN GROUP: Well, it's certainly been a very robust August and I think that what you have to see next is that leadership democratized. You need a broader penetration, get past just the big tech and see it move into other sectors.

It started to do so, but that gap between those five companies and the other 495 is still too big. We want to see that come in a bit and we think that it will. We think the financials are deeply undervalued. Energy, same story. And you're going to see continued market strength with a lot of Fed support and recovery out of these lows of the Covid moment.

MCDOWELL: Turning to TikTok. A deal to sell the apps' U.S. division reportedly stalling over new Chinese restrictions on exporting artificial intelligence, or AI. TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, in talks with companies, including Microsoft and Walmart and Oracle. The Trump administration set a mid-September deadline for the deal.

Mike, is this a hurdle that can't be overcome? What do you say?

MICHAEL LEE, MICHAEL LEE STRATEGY: You know, Dagen, the irony here should be lost on no one that the Chinese Communist Party is worried about proprietary technology being exported. It's important to remember the gentleman last week at the Republican National Convention said that the Chinese Communist Party is not just the enemy of America, it's the enemy of humanity. And this -- the reason we're in this situation is TikTok is essentially a spyware app on teens and preteens as the Chinese Communist Party seems to -- seeks to become the Saudi Arabia of data.

So I think this story has got lots of twists and turns and it may be -- end up being banned here in the U.S. I think China is a little bit worried that once the U.S. gets our hands on it, they'll do an accurate damage assessment to see just how much they've exported from there. So I think there's going to be daily news coming of out, this leading up to September 15th.

MCDOWELL: Well, Michael, that's the issue is how do you -- how do you separate China and the communist government and a Chinese-based company and, you know, cut off the U.S. division? How do you separate the data, the code, and then the people? How do you really protect the asset that you're buying, so-to-speak, and protect the users in the future?

LEE: Yes, I'm not -- I'm not hopeful for a -- for a deal to get done. Like, if TikTok goes away, I mean, it's a nice little business. It's cool for the young kids to play with this and it's funny to see those little videos, but if it just didn't exist tomorrow, would anybody's life be seriously set back? No. I mean this is just antics on the side. It's a nice revenue opportunity for either Oracle or Microsoft or whoever gets their hands on it. But, in the end, national security and putting a hard line in front of the Chinese Communist Party, in my mind, is much more significant.

MCDOWELL: The August jobs report is due out on Friday. The estimate right now is pointing to a job creation of 1.4 million jobs during the month of August. The unemployment rate falling to 9.8 percent.

Katherine, what are your expectations for Friday and please explain the disconnect between markets and an economy that we haven't even recovered half the jobs lost in February, March and April.

KATHRYN ROONEY VERA, HEAD OF GLOBAL RESEARCH, BULLTICK CAPITAL MARKETS: Well, the disconnect can be explained, Dagen, by the aggressive hand of the federal government and the Federal Reserve. The Federal Reserve is effectively propping up the markets and moving them to record highs while we have 20 million people unemployed. And 30 million people, there's a disconnect between unemployed people and those who are collecting unemployment benefits because the unemployment benefits have been made far more generous and the requirements to attain them have been loosened.

So I expect a moderation, Dagen, this month. I expect less than market consensus. So between 1 and 1.4 million, which, of course, would be less than the previous month. We are on track to drop the unemployment rate, but it's still going to be in double digits. So this is a spectacular phenomenon where you have the -- as one of your other guests said, the five biggest companies really smashing records in terms of new wealth created.

And let's not -- let's not forget, Dagen, it's public information what the Fed is buying. The Fed is actually subsidizing the national champions. This reminds me, as an emerging markets strategist in my -- in my history, of an emerging markets country. You have the BNDES in Brazil which does effectively exactly the same thing. So I think it's to the detriment of small and medium enterprises where the government is effectively crowding out the private sector.

MCDOWELL: It's really incredible. And small businesses have gotten virtually no help from anyone. And particularly in -- not to bring it back to these cities that are in flames, but these businesses are just being destroyed. And who's going to help them.

VERA: They're being walloped.

MCDOWELL: Right.

VERA: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: Who's going to help them recover?

Katheryn, great to see you --

VERA: Thank you, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Along with Michael Lee and David Bahnsen, Katheryn Rooney Vera. Great to see all three of you.

Much more ahead this morning. Up next, Ohio Congressman Brad Wenstrup reacts to Maria's interview with DNI Ratcliffe on election security.

And former Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker talks the latest on the riots in Kenosha and the president's planned visit.

Next hour, former White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders is here on the shape of the 2020 race.

And the office of trade and manufacturing policy director, Peter Navarro, talks the economy, China, TikTok and more.

The sports world's new direction. We're looking at who is boycotting protesting and walking off the field, walking off the court.

Amazon keeping you fit. The new fitness tracker can track more than just your steps. How about your tears?

Plus, the old college try. Students looking for new ways to get paid as classes shift to remote learning. You don't want to miss a moment of it.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on ox Business.

MCDOWELL: Protecting national security. Director of National Intelligence, John Ratcliffe, announcing that he's scaling back in-person congressional intelligence briefings, accusing Congress of leaking classified information for political gain. Ratcliffe saying that the leaks are meant to portray Russia as a greater threat than China. Congressional Democrats say the move is meant to downplay Russia's involve in the 2020 election. Ratcliffe defending his decision to Maria Bartiromo in an exclusive interview yesterday on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX HOST, "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES": Tell us why you're making this change to change the way you brief Congress on security matters.

JOHN RATCLIFFE, DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE: I reiterated to Congress, look, I'm going to keep you fully and currently informed as required by the law, but I also said, we're not going to do a repeat of what happened a month ago, when I did more than what was required at the request of Congress to brief not just the Oversight Committees but every member of Congress. When I did that, Maria, I said, my only condition is that you treat this information with the respect that it deserves and you keep it private. And yet, within minutes of that -- one of those briefings ending, a number of members of Congress went to a number of different publications and leaked classified information.

We've had a pandemic of information being leaked out of the intelligence community and I'm going to take the measures to make sure that that stops.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now, Ohio congressman, House Intelligence and House Ways and Means Committee member, Brad Wenstrup.

Congressman, what do you make of this? It's surely going to become a lightning rod for criticism from the Democrats.

REP. BRAD WENSTRUP (R-OH): Well, it probably will be a lightning rod for them. But the real lightning rod is what they have been doing for the last several years. Keep in mind that Director Ratcliffe was on the Intelligence Committee and he knows firsthand how we would have classified briefings and apparently members of the other party were leaking. Someone was leaking on a routine basis. Sometimes while we were even still in hearings. So he's very familiar with the behavior that has taken place.

And I look at situations where even last week "The New York Times" was calling me, asking me about something that happened during a classified briefing. And we always tell them, we don't talk about anything that happened in a classified setting.

You know, former acting Director Grenell has stated that former staffers, people that worked for both sides of the aisle as far as administrations had told him, don't go to The Hill if you don't have to because they're going to misconstrue things that you said and leak it.

I remember going to a CNN reporter two or three years ago during all the Russian collusion narrative and I said, you know, if you really want to be an American patriot, you might reveal who's doing the leaking. And he just grind and said, oh, I can't do that, and walked away.

You know, we're the committee that's supposed to be seen and never heard from. And that goes throughout Congress if you're in a classified setting. And what has been taking place over the last few years is really despicable and it's really made a shambles out of the Intelligence Committee in Congress and it's got to stop.

And I think that the director made a good decision. They can't say that they're not being informed. But they can't just run out to the swath of reporters that are sitting outside of briefings and go ahead and reveal information that they shouldn't be talking about.

MCDOWELL: Lee Carter, jump in here.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND PRESIDENT, MASLANSY AND PARTNERS: Well, I -- the thing that I'm really curious about is how do you navigate the -- I mean, obviously, putting things in writing is going to be very, very important. But everything that we talk about, everything that's said is misconstrued and we -- how do you define your own narrative for yourself when it's constantly being twisted?

WENSTRUP: Well, it's very difficult because at the same time that someone is doing that, twisting the narrative and going out and making it public, we're respecting what -- we're respecting the oath that we took, a signed oath that we took, as a matter of fact. So it does make it challenging. And I think that it becomes very important for Director Ratcliffe to take an action like this and let the country know why he is taking it because the American people need to know that, one, not only are these people that aren't -- that these are people that aren't adhering to their oath, but they are misrepresenting an people need to be aware of that misrepresentation and keep that in mind when they hear certain things that are coming out through leaks.

MCDOWELL: The stimulus stalemate, let's talk about that, Congressman. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows blaming House Speaker Nancy Pelosi for stalling negotiations for the next round of Covid-19 relief.

Is there any way, ever, that the Democrats get on-board with stimulus and more rescue money this close to an election?

WENSTRUP: I don't think they -- I don't think Speaker Pelosi wants to do anything that would make the president look good and make the president look like he's reacting to what the American people need, which is what he has been doing and is doing. And same with the Senate. And so she has stalled. We have not been engaged with conversations as far as the House of Representatives go. Republicans have been shut out. And as far as I know, most of the Democrats have too. It seems to me that Nancy Pelosi and -- and her staff have written any bills that have come forward. And -- from -- from their side.

So it is -- it is a stalemate. She plays politics as hard as anyone and puts the American people second. That's what's taking place. We should be addressing the needs of schools as they reopen. We should be addressing reopening and we should be addressing some of the glitches we found in the programs that we did put in place that have helped the American people. And she doesn't seem willing to do that. It's all about the election and it has been for the last couple of years, at least, especially since she took control of the House as speaker and it's a shame because most of us went to Congress to try and take care of the American people and guide our of country in the appropriate fashion.

MCDOWELL: She also called you an enemy of the people, so we have that. I'm talking about Republicans, the one in the White House and the ones in Congress.

WENSTRUP: Yes. Well, as somebody -- as -- that was one of the most despicable things I've ever heard. You know, what motivated the man who shot at us on the baseball field? Her rhetoric and the rhetoric that had been coming out of the Democrat Party from Bernie Sanders to -- to Joe Biden now and -- and Speaker Pelosi. That drove that man to try and assassinate us that day. And so that -- that statement there by itself is - - is shameful and way beneath the dignity of the office of speaker of the House.

MCDOWELL: Congressman Brad Wenstrup, good to see you. Thank you, sir.

WENSTRUP: You bet.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, a terrifying ride. A toddler airborne. The accident going viral. Oh, it's getting buzz this morning.

Plus, get in line. Apple ready to release its newest iPad. We're taking a look straight ahead.

MCDOWELL: We're less than two weeks away from the kickoff of the NFL season, but the looming question remains how will the coronavirus affect the game?

Cabot, we've seen how the pandemic has impacted the NBA and Major League Baseball. The NFL has had more time to prepare. What do you think?

CABOT PHILLIPS, EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, CAMPUSREFORM.ORG: Well, the problem is they're not able to do this bubble situation like the NBA did because of the size of their rosters, the prominence of injuries and the season is a lot longer than some of the other seasons with the condensed NBA season, condensed MLB season. There's going to be a much longer season, more opportunity for players to get sick.

And you've got to look at what's going to happen if some of these marquee players get sick. On a Sunday morning, if Tom Brady tests positive for the coronavirus, is the NFL going to seriously say, well, we're going to roll the team out there without Tom Brady, maybe on a Sunday night football game. You're going to have -- start to have serious questions there about what they're going to do when some of their marquee players go down and if this is going to be able to last into flu season. The playoffs are scheduled for January and February. What's going to happens if we have a resurgence of the virus there as these players are traveling around more.

I love the NFL. I hope it's able to stick around. I hope that, you know, everything goes well, but I'm not entirely optimistic that they're going to make it a full season.

MCDOWELL: Yes, with the NBA, I saw -- and this is not about the protests, but a friend of mine posted something on Instagram about how the NBA, oh, they had made this great sacrifice to play basketball and they were putting their lives on the line. I'm like, it's called risk/reward and they get paid to take on that risk. And I was like, maybe you say that about nurses and doctors and healthcare workers or even people who were running registers at grocery stores to make sure we were fed during the height of the pandemic, but not handsomely paid basketball players.

I digress.

We're looking at more than professional sports. A controversial situation developing in Ohio where high school football is ready to play but the state's top college team, Ohio State, excuse me, The Ohio State University, won't be hitting the field. The Big Ten delaying the season but other college teams in the state are playing.

Lee Carter, what do you make of this?

CARTER: Listen, I think that it's all so tough to follow. I think that everybody's got such different opinions about what's appropriate and the risk/reward of different things.

You know, I -- I feel like schools not playing sports is a really big deal for these kids. This is so much of their life. It's so much of their future. They're all counting on it to happen. I think that we've got to do whatever we can to get the kids back as safely as we can.

And when you think about the equipment these kids are wearing, how close are they getting to each other, when you think about football players, or you think about these kinds of things. I think sometimes common sense has to prevail.

MCDOWELL: Cabot, final word to you on The Ohio State University and high school ball.

PHILLIPS: Well, it's ironic. They -- they're allowing students on campus to play intramural sports, but they're not letting the football team play football. And I think also you've got to look at how a lot of these athletes are actually safer when they're on campus. They're following all sort of health protocols, CDC regulations. If they aren't playing football, they're going to be spending a lot more free time hanging out with their friends, maybe going back home, transmitting the virus there. I think this is a short-sighted move. They're a lot more concerned with liability, which I understand. I just don't think this is a solution to keep them from playing this fall.

MCDOWELL: Great talk, fella and lady.

Next up, former Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker is here to talk about the ongoing unrest in Kenosha.

Plus, the old college try. Students looking for new ways to make money as classes shift to remote learning.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Welcome back. I'm Cheryl Casone. Some headlines making news this morning, '404 error page not found.' That was the message many on the internet and gaming systems got yesterday when service provider CenturyLink went down. Many users were not able to access Amazon, Hulu and Xbox live.

Connection issues were not only reported in the U.S. but also across Europe. Service to the sites and apps have since been restored. Well, Hertz already filing bankruptcy reportedly wants to pay the company's CEO and other executives $5.4 million in bonuses. That is after the company paid out more than $16 million in retention bonuses to keep executives from leaving.

Hertz raised $29 million through stock sales, only to suspend the sale of the Securities and Exchange Commission risk questions about that deal. There's Hertz in the premarket. A buck 52, its share's up more than half a percent.

Well, Apple will reportedly unveil the new Apple watch and iPad in an event in mid-September. Leaked images of what is believed to be the new iPad Air have been circulating on social media for a few days and now MacRumors is reporting that the tech giant registered several versions of the new Apple watch and iPad with the Eurasian Economic Commission.

Taking a look at premarket trading ahead of Apple stocks split. Here we go today. It is up by more than three-quarters of a percent but that's like what, today at the opening bell and then there's this dramatic finish to that BMW Championship.

Jon Rahm sinks a crazy 66-foot putt at Olympia fields to defeat Dustin Johnson after he made a 45-foot putt that forced a play-off of Rahm's but his longest of the season was good enough to give him his second one of the year. After making that play Rahm said he still can't believe what just happened.

And a lot of people that love golf couldn't quite believe it either. Dagen, those are your headlines.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Thank you so much Cheryl. Love that. President Trump planning to visit Kenosha, Wisconsin tomorrow. Wisconsin governor Tony Evers urging the president to reconsider saying this," I'm concerned your presence will only hinder our healing. I am concerned your presence will only delay our work to overcome division and move forward together."

Joining me now former Wisconsin governor Scott Walker. Governor, should the president visit and is that a political statement being masked as something that's well heartfelt?

SCOTT WALKER (R) FMR GOVERNOR OF WISCONSIN: Well, I think the president should absolutely go to Kenosha, first and foremost because I think people want to thank him. His leadership last week, dramatically changed it back after three nights of violence and sadly two deaths and we finally saw local and state leaders responding to the president's request or his offer I should say for more assistance.

But not only that, I think it's really important when you think about so many of the businesses that were boarded up and some that were even burnt down early in the week, I think it's important for the President to hear from those employers and find out what the federal government can do to partner with local leaders there, both elected leaders but more importantly employers to get this great community back up on its feet again and help improve it for everyone. The President can do just that.

MCDOWELL: Is it important for the president to meet with Jacob Blake and his family? Is that a possibility?

WALKER: Well, I think right now the important thing is Wisconsin has an independent investigation and this is the Kenosha news - newspaper locally that historically endorses Democrats went after the very governor who put that letter out, attacking him for really inflaming the situation until it got to the point where the rioters came and that's because he jumped to a conclusion here.

Seeing the video I know many Americans myself included, were disturbed by what we saw but there's a process to look into this. And day after day, as we hear more information that's a process that should be handled by the Wisconsin Department of Justice. That's not something the president should be involved in.

He denounced what happened to George Floyd as did the vice president, others, rightfully so. In this case, we need to have all the facts but the community itself needs to heal. Thankfully the president's leadership brought us back to a sense of calm and some peace in terms of ending the rioting, providing the force that was needed to support the local law enforcement.

Now the next step is making sure and - and for example Congressman Brian Stiles has been putting this together so it's a perfect time to bring people together, business, community and civic leaders to figure out what do we do next to help Kenosha move forward.

And in terms of the unrest and the violence and the just outright mayhem that you've seen in places not just Wisconsin but particularly in Seattle and in Portland, why is it so difficult for these governors and local leaders to understand their basic constitutional, not only right to provide safety but their obligation to protect those people who they govern?

It's the tenth amendment of the constitution. Why is this so difficult for people to stand up and do what is - what is in their charge under our constitution?

WALKER: What is politics and it's unfortunate because the number one responsibility of the government at any level is to protect the public. Public safety in the truest sense of the word and they're feeling in these communities and unfortunately what we saw early on was a governor who'd first didn't even return the a call from Mark Meadows after he branched out, tried to get help from the federal government.

And they reached out and then they finally did but remember, it wasn't till later on Wednesday and I sadly, I think more than anything it was probably because focus groups came back and found out that the president offered to help but the presidential nominee, Joe Biden for the Democrats didn't say anything about the violence until after the three nights of riots after the two sad deaths.

You saw the same time the governor, a Democrat; the Attorney General, a Democrat; all put out statements on Wednesday. I have to believe, it was because of focus groups and polls. Donald Trump doesn't need a focus group to stand up and do what's right to protect people be it in Kenosha; in Madison, Wisconsin; in Seattle, Portland; Chicago or anywhere else across the country.

What he's saying is just reach out, let us know if you need assistance. It will be there and that's what we expect out of a President, someone who actually doesn't focus on the focus groups but focuses on the safety of the American people.

MCDOWELL: It's called craven self-interest when it's the polls that wake you up, not the actual underlying violence and destruction of people's lives and livelihoods. Scott, I want to ask you about the police reform, I mentioned earlier. Just as a reminder that with the Senator Tim Scott bill, the Senate Republicans tried to open the floor debate on that bill in June.

All the proposals would be guaranteed an up or down vote, both Democrats and Republicans and the Democrats voted filibuster and wouldn't even send it up for debate.

WALKER: Tim Scott obviously talked about this in his remarkable speech he gave last week at the national convention. As you know, he's been working on this for years and he rightfully is upset with Senate Democrats who as he said and I believe he's right, cared more about a political point, using this as a political issue, going into the November elections as opposed to actually passing and enacting meaningful reform.

It can be done, I know again because I signed the law years ago, the very first independent investigation law in the country we can do it but we got to set politics aside and we got to make sure that we not only protect against horrible situations like what happened in Minneapolis with George Floyd but at the same time we then protect the good and decent honorable men and women who every day law enforcement are protecting us and keeping us safe. There can't be that balance.

MCDOWELL: I'll just point out that Senator Kamala Harris last week said, the Republican Convention is designed for one purpose to suit the Donald Trump's ego. What a slap in the face to all the people who spoke, especially Senator Tim Scott. Scott Walker, good to see you.

WALKER: Good to be with you. Have a great morning.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you. Coming up, college students getting resourceful. Many finding new ways to make money as classes shift to remote learning plus I got to break it to you. I must break you again rather. Sylvester Stallone taking a new swipe at Rocky and Ivan Drago's battle in the rank. You're watching Mornings with Maria live on Fox Business.

MCDOWELL: Putting skills to work. College students faced with a somewhat decimated job market, doing what they can to make money. Gerri Willis shows us how they're changing course, Jerry.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey good morning Dagen, that's right. Those RA jobs, waitressing, bartending, all that stuff is gone, right? So most of the students are getting really, really creative. Studies show that a third of students lost their job because of the pandemic.

Tamarek Sweat is one student who has tapped her creativity to pay the bills. The sophomore at Texas A&M has started a custom clothing business which she runs from her apartment near campus. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TAMAREK SWEAT, TEXAS A&M SOPHOMORE: I do have to pay rent and I have a light bill and I have to also juggle that and school, stuff like as far as books and access codes and this other stuff that college requires so I knew I needed money and I knew I needed it fast and so I just found a way to get money.

WILLIS: Her cousin lent her the money to start her venture and in July she bought a machine to cut cloth and a heat press. Tamarek takes orders from students in over 30 universities, most of her business is done on Instagram where she sells sweatshirts, T-shirts, hoodies and masks. She's made about $2000. Listen.

SWEAT: So it started off for financial reasons but now it is truly something that makes me happy. I enjoy seeing everyone when they get their stuff and they take videos and they tag me on Instagram and Twitter.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: Among the things, college students are doing door to door sales, customer research. Some of them are selling homemade Ramen noodles and one young woman is reading tarot cards Dagen. I got to tell you, some folks are saying this is a new generation of entrepreneurs because they're looking what seemingly might be chaos in finding opportunity.

MCDOWELL: Go Aggies is this I'll say to that, industrious young woman. Thank you so much Gerri. Cabot, how are students harnessing technology to create these money making opportunities?

CABOT PHILLIPS, EDITOR-IN CHIEF, CAMPUSREFORM.ORG: Yes well, I've seen this first-hand at CampusReform, we have a team of college students that write for us. We've had a huge increase in the number of students that are coming forward and saying, hey, I need some extra money. How can I get paid to write for your website? Can I learn the trade of writing and journalism.

I've seen this first-hand. Also my brother in law. He got laid off from his job at Applebees. He's a student at Oregon state. You know what he did? He took a pickup truck, he started his junk removal business in Scappoose, Oregon so he could make some money to get by.

That is capitalism. That's the beauty of America and so for the next generation to get to see, hey, capitalism actually isn't that bad. I can go out, I can use my talents. I can work hard. I can provide a service for people and like that student in the video earlier said, I feel good that I'm helping people.

This is a great entry way for people and the next generation to realize that in America, you have the freedom to start something. You don't have to sit around and wait for other people to give it to you. Hopefully we can change some people's minds about the beauty of the free market in the next generation.

MCDOWELL: And Lee, it really is easier than ever nowadays to start your own business, particularly if you're selling something online like they awesome T-shirts and sweatshirts that this young Aggie was making?

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, POLLSTER AND MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Yes, it's amazing. I mean the very entry is nothing. I mean these kids seem to know how to harness technology but one of the things that I think is so fascinating too and looking at studies is how much innovation is accelerated over the last six months.

Things that we never thought would happen with virtual work, with virtual connections and these kinds of moments really breed innovation and entrepreneurial spirit so I can't wait to see what innovations come out of this time, as hard and challenging it is, American spirit rises up and great things can happen. I love seeing these kinds of stories so more to come.

MCDOWELL: Great stuff, guys. Coming up, a terrifying ride, a toddler goes airborne. The accident goes viral. We take a look and that little lady is OK. Plus Amazon keeping you fit. The new fitness tracker contract more than just your steps.

MCDOWELL: It's time for the morning buzz. First up, Rocky Balboa and Ivan Drago getting a rematch sort of. Sylvester Stallone making a director's cut of Rocky IV to celebrate the film's 35th anniversary. One thing we do know about the bizarre poly robot is being removed.

Someone says the robot is going to the junk yard for ever. Cabot, do we need a director's cut of Rocky IV?

PHILLIPS: Well, if they say if it ain't broke, don't fix it. I don't think we need to change a thing about this movie. I remember watching this as a very young kid, elementary school, getting fired up by it. I wanted to go fight the Soviets, my parents had to tell me that the Cold War was long over. I didn't need to worry about that but I think that also the thing you got to keep in mind here is at least we're not getting a new Rocky completely.

Don't put it past along to come out and say he's just going to film a new one even though he's a little bit advanced in age. We've seen him revamping Rambo. I wouldn't be surprised if we saw an entirely new Rocky film in the next couple years but this is an absolute classic. No need to change it though I'm excited to see what Stallone has to add.

MCDOWELL: So speaking of that, I'm watching Terms of Endearment on show time over the weekend and there's a scene where Aurora and Garrett, Shirley MacLaine and Jack Nicholson first kiss out in the water in the Gulf of Mexico and he grabs her in an appropriate way and she fights back and runs off.

That was edited completely out of the version that's on showtime with no warning so I'm just raising the question of like who said it's sensitive that they couldn't watch that and make a judgment about it themselves and why would showtime cut that out. Very, very disturbing if you ask me.

Next terrifying moments, watch this. Captured on video, a three-year old girl caught in a kite and taken up about a 100 feet into the sky. Look at that. This is during a festival in Taiwan. The crowd got the girl down and she reportedly only suffered some scratches but isn't it amazing that this child wasn't seriously injured and as a mom, relatively new mom, it makes you worried about like situations your child can get into.

CARTER: You just can't imagine how terrified that family was. That little girl, she's 28 pound, three-years old. I have a 16 month old. I am devastated just watching that video. Thank the Lord that she just came out with scratches and the goodness of all the people that come together and try and help her but my Lord, I cannot imagine. I cannot imagine.

MCDOWELL: So - so here's a quick story. My brother - well, my mother was standing at the window at the kitchen sink and she was looking out in the backyard and just saw this hatchet flying up in the air and my brother at three had gone into the shed and gotten a hatchet.

And was playing like hatchet toss and throw it in the air. I think it took my mother 20 years to recover from that so finally I - little boys you know. You got a little girl. Be grateful. Finally a love for the ages. Ecuador is home to the oldest living married couple with a combined age of about 215 years.

Guinness book of world records certifying that 110-year old Julio Cesar and his wife Waldramina, nearly 105 years young. Couple married in secret in 1941 because their families did not approve. Lee, I guess the parents got it wrong and they look so beautiful and handsome.

CARTER: Can you just imagine, what they have been through and endured and seen together? Gosh, they should give us all, some tips. That's amazing almost - almost 80 years, I mean that's beautiful. In 1941. Think of all that's happened in the world since they've been together and what they've seen.

MCDOWELL: And Lee, Cabot just got married.

CARTER: Amazing. Congratulations.

PHILLIPS: I'm four months in. I'm going to do some research on what the tips were here and you got to think that at a certain point, they're just continuing to relish in proving their family is wrong and I'm sure their families have come along at this point. they probably have so many children and grandchildren. I love stories like this. I have a lot to learn though. I'm very excited.

MCDOWELL: You only need to learn two words Cabot. 'Yes dear.'

PHILLIPS: I've learned that one very quickly.

MCDOWELL: Yes dear. Can you go and change the tires on the car? Yes dear. Still ahead everybody, former White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders is here on the shape of the 2020 race. That's next and the office of Trade and Manufacturing Policy Director Peter Navarro talks the economy, China, TikTok and more. It all begins next hour on Mornings with Maria, live on Fox Business.

MCDOWELL: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, August 31. Your top stories at 8:00 AM ET. The 2020 right tightening up. Joe Biden back on the campaign trail, heading to Pennsylvania today. President Trump heading to Wisconsin, tomorrow with a message on law and order, crime and punishment. Later this hour, Assistant to the President for Trade and Manufacturing, Peter Navarro on tensions with China.
