Jim Banks (R-IN) is Interviewed about Rising U.S./China Tensions and the Stimulus; Unrest in America; Country Music Stars Coming to the Drive-In2020-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTKeith Fitz-Gerald, David Bahnsen, Linda Duessel, Jim Banks, Michael Lee, Alli McCartney, Emily Jashinsky, Walter KinzieNEWSInternational072402cb.231Word on Wall Street; Rep. Jim Banks (R-IN) is Interviewed about Rising U.S./China Tensions and the Stimulus; Unrest in America; Country Music Stars Coming to the Drive-InDagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Byron York

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, July 24th.

Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern.

Breaking news overnight, China ordering the closure of the U.S. consulate in Chengdu. The move comes after the U.S. demands China shut down its consulate in Houston today.

U.S.-China relations putting pressure on global markets. Futures are off this morning, a 48 point loss on the Dow futures. The Dow and Nasdaq erasing gains for the week yesterday. The Dow on pace to end its three-week winning streak.

Coronavirus stimulus delayed. Republicans pushing the release of a new stimulus plan to next week. The fallout ahead.

Coronavirus hitting the Republican National Convention. President Trump canceling events in Jacksonville as cases spike in Florida.

Meantime, the CDC pushing for the reopening of schools, saying it's critically important for our public health.

And unrest in America. Another night of protests in Portland, plus demonstrations erupt in Chicago outside the mayor's home.

And, play ball. The baseball season finally gets underway with a wild pitch from Dr. Anthony Fauci.

And a week-long look at Instagram stars comes to an end with the people behind some funny and popular memes. Co-founders of My Therapist Says join us live with the secrets behind their viral posts.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA live right now.

Checking global markets.

Growing tensions between the United States and China leading to losses around the world. Europe is in the red territory this morning. Losses down more than 1 percent in England, France and Germany. In Asia overnight there were also losses. The Nikkei closed for the holiday. Shanghai losing almost 4 percent.

Joining the conversation this morning, Alli McCartney, Emily Jashinsky and Michael Lee.

Welcome one and all. We'll see you shortly.

Meantime, China ordering the United States to shut down a consulate in Chengdu.

Lauren Simonetti has the details.

Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Dagen, good morning.

This is one of five U.S. consulates in the country. The tit-for-tat move as the U.S. demands China shut down its Houston consulate today, calling it the epicenter of American research theft.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo calling on every nation to demand transparency from Beijing.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, SECRETARY OF STATE: We want to have a free 21st century, and not the Chinese century of which Xi Jinping dreams. The old paradigm of blind engagement with China simply won't get it done.

When it comes to the CCP, I say we must distrust and verify.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: China has until 4:00 p.m. to close the Houston consulate.

Protests erupting in Chicago. Hundreds gathering outside the home of Mayor Lori Lightfoot last night -- look at that -- demanding the city defund police as the White House announced plans to send federal agents to the windy city and other cities across the nation to help combat the recent surge in violence.

And, overnight, this iconic statue of Christopher Columbus was removed from Chicago's Grant Park. It was taken down by the city, not the protesters, who tried to tear down the controversial statue last week.

To the latest on the coronavirus.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is delaying the release of the next round of the relief package. It will be rolled out next week. McConnell saying the White House wanted more time to review final details.

The $1 trillion package is expected to include $105 billion for reopening schools this fall, $15 billion for daycare center assistance, $16 billion for coronavirus testing and tracing.

Johns Hopkins University finding more than 4 million cases in the U.S. and over 144,000 deaths.

Amazon is accused of stealing ideas from start-ups that it invested in before launching competing products itself. That according to "The Wall Street Journal." Amazon's venture capital fund took a stake in a tech start-up called Defined Crowd and gained access to its finances and other confidential information. Well, "The Journal" says, about four years later, Amazon rolled out an artificial intelligence product very similar to one of Defined Crowd's products. Amazon denies any wrong-doing but shares are down $25 ahead of the opening bell.

Dagen, back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Lauren.

Lauren Simonetti.

Time for the "Word on Wall Street," where top financial analysts are here to help you and your wallet.

Joining me now the Fitz-Gerald Group Principal Keith Fitz-Gerald, Federated Hermes Senior Equity Strategist Linda Duessel, and the Bahnsen Group CEO and Managing Partner David Bahnsen.

Great to see all of you.

Keith, let's start with you.

Futures under pressure on global tensions with China. This follows the selloff yesterday largely led by big tech. Intel reporting better than expected results yesterday but the shares are slipping after a drop in third quarter outlook.

What do you make of tech's tumble? Is it the --is it the air coming out of a bubble?

KEITH FITZ-GERALD, PRINCIPAL, THE FITZ-GERALD GROUP: You know, I wouldn't use the word "bubble" because that brings to mind connotations of 1999. I think it's a decided concentration of risk. It's a concentration of funds at work. People are simply taking their foot off the gas. To me, it's, so far, normal. The selling isn't panic driven. It's simply a lot of money coming off, they've decided to sell, and I'm not reading a lot into that yet.

China, on the other hand, does concern me.

MCDOWELL: What else are you watch -- well, let's talk about China because we had Zach Cooper (ph) on last hour and he said something very interesting. And -- he said that closing -- by China closing the consulate in Chengdu, that that is actually a de-escalation of tensions because it's not really an important consulate and so it was a message that they're trying to take their foot off the gas somewhat, so-to-speak.

But how do you see it?

FITZ-GERALD: Well, I tell you, respectfully, I've spent nearly 30 years in that part of the world. I've done a lot of business in mainland China. I have exactly the opposite impression. I think Chengdu is a significant operation because it's near and dear to the manufacturing community, it's been a presence for the United States basically since World War II. I think that we have got a significant number of chips on the table. So I read that as not a de-escalation, but very much a tit-for-tat. Houston was important to the Chinese. We hit them where it hurt. They're going to do the same to us.

MCDOWELL: But we can't back off now, can we? We can't stand by, which we did literally for decades, and allow the Chinese to steal our intellectual property and some of America's greatest resources?

FITZ-GERALD: Oh, I agree with that. I think that, you know, we've had 40 years of failed policy. In fact, the only thing we've gotten correct with regard to China over the last 40 years has been that we've under-estimated them. They've changed psychologically, just like the Soviets did, from an animal that's looking for food and love, to an animal that believes it can survive once it gets outside its cage. That makes it very, very dangerous. And the futures reflect that.

MCDOWELL: The next coronavirus stimulus package, a work in progress. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell delaying the release of the Republican stimulus plan.

David, what is the market impact here? It's like -- Ron Johnson, the senator, has an editorial in "The Wall Street Journal" today saying, we don't even know where the first $3 trillion went.

DAVID BAHNSEN, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, THE BAHNSEN GROUP: Well, I think that the market has to sort of process two realities at once. One is that it's going to be a little bit ugly getting a deal done. There's going to be a lot of back and forth. And it's not two parties negotiating anymore. This is not Democrats versus Republicans. It's House Democrats, it's Senate Republicans, and it's the White House. And there's a sort of tri-party element that makes it a bit more complicated.

But do I think that the market believes that there's any question they're going to end up getting some deal done, even if it's a little bit awkward along the way and delayed, no, the market knows a deal's coming and we're sitting around debating if it's going to be 2 trillion or 1.5 trillion. It's going to be massive. It's going to have some good things in it and it's going to have some awful things in it.

MCDOWELL: It has helped, though. Let's be clear. The money that has flowed specifically to consumers, those who are working, you get the checks and then the enhanced unemployment benefits. The housing market, we have the new home sales report out later today. But June existing home sales topped 4.72 million in sales in June. It was the highest record -- it was a record for the month and boosted by low mortgage rates, but also money in people's pockets.

Linda, what do you say?

LINDA DUESSEL, SENIOR EQUITY STRATEGIST, FEDERATED HERMES: Housing is a huge piece of our economy and that is really one of the big positives that we can point to as bulls, we at Federated Hermes are bullish. So the 30 year mortgage rate now I think is maybe the lowest that it's ever been. And a lot of people are taking advantage of this. This also has to do with people moving out of the cities more into the suburbs and some new home buyers and first time home buyers. So that's all really good news as we work our way through fits and starts, which you normally would do in the summertime with the market.

MCDOWELL: But do we need -- do you think we need $2 trillion in additional stimulus here to keep the economy and businesses propped up until we can get a vaccine?

DUESSEL: Yes. Yes, unfortunately, the really bad -- the really bad thing out there is the unemployment situation. The unemployment claims again yesterday I think -- we're now maybe 17 weeks in a row where you've had ridiculously high unemployment figures come out. These are brand-new unemployment claims, people that were not unemployed before. So throughout this whole time period, people who lost their jobs were getting that $600 - - extra $600, they knew it was a temporary loss. Now they're wondering if it's going to be a permanent loss.

So this is something that really needs to right itself. We see great news from the housing side. We see lots of people still losing their jobs. People losing their jobs are the lowest income cohorts out there. And those are the ones that really need the lifeline. And I believe very much, particularly in an election year, you will see new monies flow to those people and new monies flow to the PPP program.

MCDOWELL: Linda, great to see you. Thank you so much.

Linda Duessel, Keith Fitz-Gerald and David Bahnsen, thanks one and all.

Much more ahead this morning.

Next, Indiana Congressman Jim Banks on growing tensions with China as Beijing closes a U.S. consulate in a major Chinese city.

At 8:00, former senior adviser to President George W. Bush, Karl Rove, on the 2020 race.

Former New York City Police Department Commissioner Howard Safir on his take on the unrest hitting major cities across the country.

And it's the end of Insta-star Week. We're look at one account making fun of life's everyday worries. You don't want to miss it.

But first, back-to-school. The CDC issuing new guidelines on how students should return to the classroom. Details ahead.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

MCDOWELL: Tensions between the United States and China rising. China ordering the closure of the U.S. consulate in Chengdu overnight. This in retaliation to the U.S. forcing the closure of the Chinese consulate in Houston over intellectual property theft.

Joining me now, Indiana Congressman and House Armed Services Committee member Jim Banks.

Congressman, the timing might be awkward for our economy, our market, but this is necessary, is it not?

REP. JIM BANKS (R-IN): It's absolutely necessary, Dagen. And -- and this is a sign of probably much more of what's -- what's to come in the months and years ahead. We finally have a president, after 40 years of presidents who have turned a blind eye to the activities of China, we have a president and a secretary of state, by the way, who have ventured to do something about it.

Yesterday, Secretary Pompeo gave, I believe, the most pivotal speech of the entire four years that he -- that -- that this Trump administration has been in office, in talking about uniting the free world against communist China. And what you saw in closing the consulate in Houston is a necessary step, is a hub of intellectual property theft on behalf of the Chinese and United States of America, but there is so much more to do.

MCDOWELL: Speaking of the secretary of state, let's listen to a little bit of what he says. He doubled down on his hard line against China, announcing the end of blind engagement with the communist party.

Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, SECRETARY OF STATE: The old paradigm of blind engagement with China simply won't get it done. We must not continue it. We must not return to it.

If the free world doesn't change, doesn't change, communist China will surely change us. We can't return to the past practices because they're comfortable or because they're convenient.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We also need to point out, just in recent days, the U.S. indicting two Chinese nationals or allegedly hacking American firms involved in coronavirus research. And, again, this is a virus that has killed hundreds of thousands of people around the globe that came out of China, that China lied about for weeks, if not months.

BANKS: That's exactly right. And this is just skimming the surface. This is what the American people are becoming awakened to more than ever before because this administration is exposing something that has largely been hidden from us for decades in the past.

But this is just skimming the surface. And that's why Kevin McCarthy and the House of Representatives formed the China Task Force. And by October 1st, we will -- we will release an extensive whole of government approach that the administration can take and Congress can support in how we deal with China moving forward.

This is the issue of our time. This is the greatest existential threat that America faces today. And thank God that we have a president and an administration with those like Secretary Pompeo are doing something about it.

I contend that this is what's at stake on the ballot in November when we vote as well, will we continue to put pressure on communist China for another four years or will we backtrack to the times of past -- with Republicans and Democrat administrations -- where we turn a complete blind eye to these activities. Thank God we have a president who's doing something about it.

MCDOWELL: But four years ago President Trump really clearly connected China and all of the jobs and the economic malaise, particularly in rural parts of America. So that has to continue to -- because people have to feel. And if it's not the virus, then it's certainly the economic impact of all those jobs being shipped overseas for literally decades.

I want to get your take on this, though.

GOP leaders have delayed the release of their ideas about the next coronavirus aid package. The long awaited plan is now expected to be introduced next week following days of negotiations of what should go into the bill. It doesn't look like a payroll tax cut is going to go into that. But I'll point this out, one of the sticking points is that extra $600 a week that people are receiving in unemployment benefits and that effectively will end in many states this weekend.

Where do you stand on it, because you can't hold this up?

BANKS: Yes, I serve as chairman of the Budget and Spending Task Force of the Republican Study Committee. I can tell you that later today we're going to release a letter that will include a majority of House Republicans saying enough is enough, we can't keep adding to the national debt. We have to address it. And we can't keep incentivizing people to stay home and not go to work.

I hear from businesses in northeast Indiana, which I represent, every single day talking about this being the greatest challenge that they have, how do we get employees to come back to work if the federal government is incentivizing them to stay home. So there is a debate within the Republican Party, a larger debate within our country, of how -- where do we go from here?

I'm not giving up on the payroll tax cut. It should be something that should be included. And I stand -- I stand with President Trump on that. I hope we don't back off of that -- that debate. And there have been -- there have been some signs that the administration is still fighting for it. But I can tell you that -- that many House Republicans, like myself, are fighting for it too.

MCDOWELL: In terms of the 600 supplemental, the extra $600 per week, be specific, are you in favor of reducing it or getting rid of that extra $600?

BANKS: Yes, I believe it's unhealthy all together. We should eliminate it. It should not be included in a future package. We need to -- we need to find ways to incentivize Americans to go back to work. That's what will make America's economy healthy again, by reopening our economy, getting America back to work, not to reward people, incentivize people to stay at home instead.

MCDOWELL: Well, America needs to be healthy in order to go back to work. And given the -- certainly the rising number of virus cases in some states, that's not a possibility. So you're not in favor of giving those people who can't go back to work, their businesses aren't open, you see this jump in jobless claims for the week that came out yesterday.

BANKS: Yes, understood, Dagen. I have three daughters who are 10 and under. Their generation is going to hold the bag for the $3.2 trillion we've added to the national debt already. Another package that would add trillions more, that -- that will impact the economy for a lot longer than the -- the short-term pain that we're feeling in this economy at the moment. That -- that's what I'm concerned about. We can't do -- we can't do more harm to our -- to our kids and our grandkids' future by growing this national debt even further.

And that's why House Republicans like myself are going to be releasing in a letter shortly addressing that --

MCDOWELL: Right

BANKS: And putting our foot down, saying enough is enough.

MCDOWELL: Well, on the other side of that you've got to take care of those children today and parents will tell you they need that extra money to literally put food on the table and clothes on their backs.

Congressman Jim Banks, thank you so much for being here.

We'll be right back.

BANKS: Thank you.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We believe many school districts can now reopen safely, provided they implement mitigation measures and health protocols.

But every district should be actively making preparations to open. Again --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: President Trump urging schools to resume in-person learning this fall. The CDC releasing its long awaited guidelines for reopening with a heavy emphasis on getting students back into classrooms. The new guidelines include this, implement mitigation strategies which include social distancing, masks, and hand hygiene, clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces, take into account community transmission, repurpose spaces to increase classroom space, keep students in pods throughout the day and develop plans for positive tests and case tracing.

Mike, your take?

MICHAEL LEE, MICHAEL LEE STRATEGY: Yes, look, Dagen, I think kids need to be back in the classroom. There's no evidence that children pass this to adults. We've had no confirmed cases from that worldwide. The U.S. is one of the only countries in the world pushing back on sending kids back to the classroom. I think this is led by the teachers unions in a political effort to get Trump. I think teachers with underlying conditions that are really at risk are more at risk from getting it from other teachers and should be offered an opportunity to take a year off and get paid on disability until a vaccine is available. There's a lot of workable solutions.

But there was a doctor from Johns Hopkins on Fox last night saying that calls to social services are down 75 percent. Considering what we've been through since March, with all the stress and all the children locked inside and a lot of parents that aren't able to handle this, you'd think they'd be up 75 percent. So there is a real public health problem happening from kids being out of school. They need to be back in the classroom in August as soon as possible.

MCDOWELL: Alli, do you agree?

ALLI MCCARTNEY, PRIVATE WEALTH ADVISER, UBS FINANCIAL SERVICES: Look, there are two things going on here. The first is that everything that we've been through in the last number of months clearly points to the divide in terms of the lack of progress and sufficiency of our system. We need to get kids in school. We need to figure this out.

The second is from an economic point of view. We just talked about the $600 benefit, which if it doesn't materialize is going to be quite a negative surprise to the market. But you cannot get working class people back in school -- back to work and the economy going and unemployment below 11 percent if you don't have children in schools.

So this -- this is one of those issues and it's going to continue to highlight a lot of the divides we see socially, economically and politically, but we have to work towards getting kids back in school for their health and for the health of the economy.

MCDOWELL: I read a quote, it was in "The Wall Street Journal," Emily, that said that without education and schools, that women particularly, if they have to stay at home without child care, without schools being open, it will wipe away a generation of gains for women in the workplace. Really astonishing.

EMILY JASHINSKY, COMMENTARY WRITER, THE FEDERALIST: Yes, and -- no, that is a really good point because we have to think about all of the sort of like tangential or the downstream impacts of something like this. And women absolutely will bear the brunt of it in terms of families. And, you know, these guidelines, I think, are really innovative. I think when you look at polling, you know, we say that AP poll yesterday found around 60 percent of the country believes that schools should be open with either major changes or minor changes in the fall. We can't really even comprehend how -- it's - - because it's not just what they're learning in the classroom. And we know that it's tough for kids to learn over Zoom. But it's also the socialization aspect of it, being around other children as you learn and grow. So I think, you know, we can't even understand the impact that closing in the fall would have totally. And that's why it's so important to find innovative ways to keep the schools open.

MCDOWELL: Well, we've heard from the American Academy of Pediatrics, the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine weighing in on this of how important it is for particularly children with special needs or kindergarten through third grade to be in schools around one another in classrooms because that's when you're developing the skills to regulate your behavior, attention, emotions.

You couple that with the way our elderly are being isolated in nursing homes and hospitals and the dementia and literally the delirium that results from that and these are the long-lasting consequences of how we've chosen to fight this virus. And it will change us as a nation potentially forever.

Coming up, changing course. President Trump canceling RNC plans for Jacksonville, Florida, as coronavirus cases rise.

Plus, concerts adapting to a new normal. The changes coming to live entertainment during the Covid-19 pandemic, ahead.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, July 24th.

A look at your markets at 7:30 a.m. Eastern.

Losses across the board there, 88 point loss on the Dow. Futures, at the moment, as U.S.-China relations are putting pressure on the -- on stocks. Futures pointing to a lower open here.

And if you look overseas, it's the same story. You have losses across the board in Europe, north of 1 percent in England, France and Germany.

And then look at the Asian markets. The Nikkei closed but there are losses there across the board as the -- as China closes the consulate in Chengdu in retaliation to what's going on in Houston here.

President Trump's former fixer heading back to home confinement.

Lauren Simonetti has the details.

Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Hey, Dagen.

So a federal judge in New York has ordered the release of Michael Cohen, saying his recent return to prison was retaliatory because he was writing a tell-all book about President Trump right before the November election. Cohen was taken back into custody earlier this month after he refused to sign an agreement barring him from publishing that book. Cohen is serving a three year sentence after pleading guilty to financial crimes and lying to Congress.

Baseball made its return last night. The Yankees took on the World Series' defending champion, the Washington Nationals. Rain forced a two hour delay before the game was eventually called with the Yankees winning 4-1. Before the game got underway, Dr. Anthony Fauci threw out the first pitch. Let's watch it. He threw the ball way outside. There we go.

Also playing last night was the San Francisco Giants and the L.A. Dodgers. The Dodgers beat the Giants 8-1.

And yesterday President Trump celebrated opening day by welcoming baseball Hall of Famer Mariano Rivera, along with several little league players to the White House. The president said he's been invited to throw the opening pitch at Yankee Stadium next month.

And let's take a look at what's trending this morning on foxbusiness.com.

First, the FDA expanding its hand sanitizer recall to roughly 75 cleansers after they tested positive for methanol. A majority of the products appear to have been manufactured in Mexico.

Next week's anti-trust hearing on Capitol Hill with tech CEOs Jeff Bezos, Tim Cook and Mark Zuckerberg will likely be postponed due to the memorial service for the late Congressman John Lewis.

And wealthy millennials are reportedly moving to the Pacific Northwest. The top three places adults younger than 35 making at least $100,000 a year are moving, Washington state, Colorado and south to Texas.

Dagen, back to you.

They are leaving New York, by the way. About 6,000 people in the most recent year, rich millennials left New York.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Lauren. Good to see you.

Unrest across the country. In Chicago, hundreds of protesters gathered outside Mayor Lori Lightfoot's house last night demanding that she defund the city's police department and decrying President Trump's decision to send in federal agents.

Meantime, President Trump telling Fox News that he would also send a CBP team to Seattle as protests in the Pacific Northwest have expanded outside of Portland and both cities are anticipating riots this weekend.

Joining me now, chief political correspondent at "The Washington Examiner" and Fox News contributor, Byron York.

Byron, the messaging gets nuttier every day. So, in Chicago, where people are being murdered every single day, they want to defund the police to stop crime?

BYRON YORK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: It's -- it's so -- it just makes absolutely no sense. And, you know, from the very beginning of the most recent attention to this defund the police idea, critics have said, well, what happens if you defund the police and there's a murder or an armed robbery or any -- all sorts of violent crimes that take place? And the proponents of that have never had a good answer.

Now, on this Portland stuff, Seattle stuff, Chicago, the guiding principle for federal involvement is some threat to a federal facility. That's what's going on in Portland are nightly attacks on the Hatfield Federal Courthouse. And federal law enforcement from the Department of Homeland Security are protecting the courthouse. So if you saw something similar in another city like Seattle, you would have some more federal intervention.

But in cities that have just seen a crime spike, like Chicago and New York, if there were federal intervention, it would not be the same as all. It would be sending more agents, FBI, DEA, ATF, to do what they already do, which is assisting local law enforcement.

MCDOWELL: That is exactly right, Byron. And that's what's happening in Chicago. These are agents that are helping with investigative work, say ATF using special technology to study ballistics evidence.

YORK: Right.

MCDOWELL: And if it's a federal crime being committed, which is a drug crime, if it's gang related, chances are it's a drug crime. Eighty percent of gang activity it's drug related. Drug offenses are federal offenses. The feds don't need any permission to go into a city to address a drug or racketeering related crimes. These are federal crimes. And if they're charged in federal court, they actually could carry longer sentences.

So what if -- what if, in Chicago, this actually works?

YORK: Well, we've seen this before. Here, again, the important thing to say is, federal agents are already in Chicago, in New York, in cities around the country, as part of the everyday work supporting local law enforcement. That's what's going on. So if you -- if you send more of them, because the problem has gotten worse, that is not a federal takeover, that is not an invasion of the city, that is not a first step toward Marshall law, which some on the left are talking about these days. That's none of that. This is a continuation of existing practices and also a realization that things, for whatever reason, have gotten worse in recent days and need to be address.

MCDOWELL: You said -- used the phrase "martial law." And I want to raise an issue, something you were talking about on Twitter. I -- I follow you religiously. It's the language from the left, from progressives and even Democrats in power. But then that language is then being picked up and used throughout many corners of the media, and it's really insidious. And it shows a lack of critical thinking and, quite frankly, a laziness on the part of members of the media. And I would use the phrase "martial law." The insistence that these protests are peaceful when we see -- when we see the city burning, or fires outside of a courthouse. Nancy Pelosi used the phrase "storm troopers." The -- here -- here is one of my -- oh, secret police, I think that that was one that -- that you mentioned. The insistence that these are -- that these federal agents are anonymous, that they're not wearing their names. Well, of course they're not, it's because -- to -- it's to protect their families.

But here was the one that really made me angry. The Portland -- here's the headline, the Portland mayor tear gassed by federal agents. You saw that everywhere. What do you make of that?

YORK: Well, it's just more -- first of all, the protesters, the tear gas was used to respond to protesters who were throwing burning bags of garbage over the fence toward the federal courthouse because they've been trying to start fires around there for days and days and days. This is day 54 or 55 of their protest. So the Portland mayor kind of joined the mob that was throwing this garbage and he was there for the tear gas as well.

But you're right about this phraseology. "Secret police" is particularly nutty because they're from the -- these law enforcement officers are from the Department of Homeland Security. DHS holds press conferences about what they're doing. Various officials have come on TV to do interviews about what they're doing. They're simply not "secret police."

A growing one is martial law. You're seeing Ron Wyden, the senator -- Democratic senator from Oregon, said that we might be looking at martial law in the future if -- if this federal intervention in Portland, specifically to protect the federal courthouse, were to continue.

And now you're seeing on some -- (INAUDIBLE) of the left speculation that the president is planning a martial -- the imposition of martial law to cancel the election in November. And -- and I'm -- this stuff has been in "The Washington Post," it's been on MSNBC. This is not in the -- in the crazy nut fringes, this is mainstream media speculation.

MCDOWELL: Well, it's the same media that was speculating -- not even speculating, accusing President Trump of colluding with Vladimir Putin. So, again, that's why there's such a distrust.

YORK: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But it's very -- but it's a little more subtle with the use of language, the use of language like "secret police." It's to evoke a nation of Nazis. That's -- that's the whole -- the meaning of it.

YORK: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It doesn't quite go as far as Nancy Pelosi using the term "storm troopers," but it's -- it's -- it's planned and it's tactical by the media and the left.

YORK: You know, and you'll hear people in Portland, especially, and you can understand this, saying, look, Portland is not on fire. There's this big city and this is not going on everywhere in the big city. There's plenty of places you could be in Portland, you would never have any idea. It's going on in a very small place. But if it's a small, targeted thing, how could it be this national martial law imposition that people on the left talk about.

MCDOWELL: I just want to not get chased and harassed and robbed on my way to work. Is that too much to ask?

Byron York, good to see you.

YORK: In some cities, apparently it is too much to ask. But the -- look, the defund police movement, you've talked about it, President Trump talked about it last night on Sean's show, is this idea of redirecting funds, is - - is, in essence, defunding. If you -- if you -- if you take funds from Project A and redirect it to Project B, you've taken money away from Project A, you've defunded Project A. So if you take money from the police to move to public housing or mental health counseling or any of the other of programs that some Democrats have talked about, that is in effect defunding the police. It just is.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Byron York.

And, by the way, Joe Biden did say that like a week and a half ago in an interview or a couple weeks ago.

YORK: Correct.

MCDOWELL: He said -- talked about moving funds. Guess what, that's defunding police.

Sorry, I know, it's early, 7:43 in the morning.

Byron York, thank you. It was great to see you.

Coming up, concerts adapting to a new normal. How live entertainment is changing during the Covid-19 pandemic.

Plus, poking fun at life's everyday worries. The Insta-star making you laugh even when you want to cry.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

MCDOWELL: Blake Shelton coming to a drive-in near you. The country music star and special guests Gwyn Stefani and Trace Adkins performing for one night only as 300 drive-in locations across the United States and Canada tomorrow night. The drive-in concert is part of a series produced by Encore Live.

Joining us now, the CEO of Encore Live, Walter Kinzie.

Walter, this is the second concert you've produced. The first was with Garth Brooks. Tell us about the response from getting -- that you're getting from music fans to this -- to the last event and this one.

WALTER KINZIE, CEO, ENCORE LIVE: Well, we've had one concert so far. Our next one will be tomorrow night. Over 350,000 people showed up to see Garth Brooks at the end of June. And we've amassed over 12 billion, with a b, impressions throughout media online in the last 30 days.

And so the world is talking about it and we're the only ones producing live entertainment on -- with scale. So it's a -- it's no wonder that everyone's talking about it.

MCDOWELL: Who else can we expect to see performing the rest of the summer?

KINZIE: Well, I'll tell you, we have a big announcement coming next week that you're not going to want to miss. (INAUDIBLE) --

MCDOWELL: Well, we're not waiting till next week, so you just better tell us now.

KINZIE: You have to wait until next week. I'm so sorry. But it is -- we're -- we're -- we're all focused on tomorrow night. We -- we're expecting several hundred thousand people to come out across the United States and Canada to see Blake.

But I will tell you with confidence, a major announcement is coming out next week and -- and --

MCDOWELL: OK. Give me a hint. Well, give me a hint, is it a rock band?

KINZIE: You're intuition is very sharp. It's a --

MCDOWELL: Foo Fighters. Foo Fighters.

KINZIE: That -- that -- it's going to be a really big show, I will promise you that, by one of the greatest bands of all time. And -- and we fully expect we'll have hundreds and hundreds of thousands of people from around the country and around Canada come out to see the show.

MCDOWELL: So -- my guess is Foo Fighters. We will check back in with you next week.

One -- one quick thing, though, because these concerts are shown in -- in drive-ins. Are you seeing -- I guess there's a -- there are a dearth of drive-ins in the United States. Are there more -- there's some abandoned screens around where I grew up. Like -- are you seeing people actually try to move to open more drive-in theaters thinking this is something that will be lasting?

KINZIE: You know, I tell you what, the entrepreneurial spirit has been incredible across the country. We're talking to farmers that didn't get their crops in the ground and so they converted their farms into movie theaters. Abandoned drive-in theaters from across America. When we realized in April that the rest of our industry thought we would be touring again by June and we're sitting there saying, what rock are you guys living under, we got really busy and we started acquiring these theaters across the country for exclusive content.

And now, today, we'll have Blake tomorrow night on over 398 showings and we're -- we're going to -- we're -- we have the content. We have the scale. And I've been very impressed in the resurgence in small town America and the entrepreneurial spirit.

About a week ago, or rather about three weeks ago, our team said, we have to capture this moment in time because nothing else is ever going to happen like this again. And so we actually have a pilot debuting next week where we're going to be talking about the building of this entrepreneurial spirit and the resurgence of small town America.

MCDOWELL: Awesome.

KINZIE: So it's an exciting time to be in the music industry.

MCDOWELL: Two words, Keysville, Virginia, look into it.

Walter Kinzie, thank you, sir. We'll see you soon.

We'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: Time for the "Morning Buzz."

First up, new season, new name. The Washington Redskins will now call themselves the Washington football team. This will be used until a new one is chosen in the future. The team posted new photos of the logos and uniforms. Still the same colors, but without the former logo.

Alli, I'm a long-time skins fan. I don't know about this.

MCCARTNEY: Well, last time I was on, this news broke about them potentially changing the name. You had some comments about the strength and capability and capacity of the management team. So I know you have some strong views on this.

I will say that anybody who knows me knows that this is the first and last time I will ever talk on TV about any professional sport. This -- wow, this just points to the politicism and divide in our country that the only name we can come up with is the name of the city.

MCDOWELL: It's better than the Washington politicians.

Next, take a walk with chicken. KFC and Crocs teaming up again with a limited edition of chicken clogs. Each pair is made to resemble and smell like the iconic KFC fried chicken. They clogs, the Crocs, are available next week for $59.

Emily?

JASHINSKY: OK, first of all, ridiculous price point. Second of all, I don't understand why they have to smell like chicken. But what's interesting is that Popeye's has a clothing line as well. And so KFC, I think, saw what Popeye's was doing and said, let's put the chicken on a clog that was made by Crocs. And I think it's just -- it's really just a beautiful American creation.

MCDOWELL: I would rather men wear Crocs than flip-flops, even if they do smell like chicken. I'm against men in flip-flops as a rule.

JASHINSKY: And they're practical.

Let me get to this story. Finally, Bill and Ted are back. The long awaited third film from -- "Bill and Ted: Face the Music" will be released on demand in September. Alex Winter, Keanu Reeves are reprising their roles as the dynamic duo, taking a time travel adventure.

Mike, I'm a huge fan particularly of the first one. What do you say?

LEE: Hey, Dagen, I'm with you. I saw the first two in the movie theater. And I've got a countdown clock to September 1st to watch this to see the triumphant return of Bill S. Preston Esq. and Ted Theodore Logan as Wyld Stallyns. This -- this will be another opportunity for my wife to stare at her phone and roll her eyes at me as I'm laugh historically on the couch to extremely sophomoric humor. So, September 1st, here we come.

MCDOWELL: It's still got Keanu Reeves and the guy is still killing it, even -- well, even now. He does not age.

Still ahead, poking fun at life's everyday worries. The Insta-stars is making you laugh when you want to cry, next hour, on MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.
