James Lankford (R-OK) is Interviewed about the Stimulus; Biden's VP Decision; Starbucks Surges: Shares see a boost as stores reopen; Attacking The Police: Protesters cause $997,000 in vehicle damages; Rudy Giuliani: Democrats want crime in order to defeat President Trump; Rite Aid used secret facial recognition systems at hundreds of locations in U.S.; Beer Without The Buzz: Anheuser-Busch rolling out alcohol-free "Bud Zero".2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTRudy Giuliani, Rebecca Walser, Katie Stockton, Scott Martin, James Lankford, Philip WegmannNEWSFinancial072902cb.231Word on Wall Street; Sen. James Lankford (R-OK) is Interviewed about the Stimulus; Biden's VP Decision; Starbucks Surges: Shares see a boost as stores reopen; Attacking The Police: Protesters cause $997,000 in vehicle damages; Rudy Giuliani: Democrats want crime in order to defeat President Trump; Rite Aid used secret facial recognition systems at hundreds of locations in U.S.; Beer Without The Buzz: Anheuser-Busch rolling out alcohol-free "Bud Zero".Maria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Judge Andrew Napolitano, Dagen McDowell

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, July 29th. Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the nose.

It is a big day in Washington this morning. Big tech on The Hill. CEOs of FaceBook, Amazon, Google and Apple will all appear for an anti-trust hearing this morning. What's at stake for these industry giants coming up.

Plus, the battle over stimulus is on. We are looking at the differences between the Republican and the Democratic plans this morning and how they impact your wallet coming up.

It is also Fed day. Investors listening closely to what Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell has to say about the economic impact of the coronavirus after the central bank announced it is extending its emergency lending program. We'll hear from Jay Powell this afternoon at 2:00 p.m. Eastern.

A fiery hearing, meanwhile, on Capitol Hill between William Barr and Democrats. The hearing appeared to have more questions than answers, at least that were allowed. But as he was grilled, the AG had a question of his own, how long will we let our cities burn.

Meanwhile, federal agents pulling out of Seattle. Other cities could follow despite ongoing violence throughout. Former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani is here this morning joining me live at 7:30 a.m. Eastern with more on the unrest in America and battling rising crime.

It's another big day for earnings. Dow component Boeing set to report any time. Meanwhile, General Electric posted results. It said it expects to return to positive cash flow in 2021. Health insurer Anthem with a double beat this morning. People delayed non-essential procedures due to Covid-19. All three of those stocks are trading up this morning.

The rest of the market, meanwhile, looks like this. Take a look at futures indicating a fractional move at the start of trading. It is positive. Dow futures up 7 points, Nasdaq futures up 47, and the S&P right now higher by 5 points.

Stimulus uncertainty and the economy hit companies -- are taking -- due to the coronavirus, fueling losses on Wall Street yesterday. DowIndustrials were down 205 points yesterday, The Nasdaq was down 134, and the S&P down 21 at 4:00 on Wall Street.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live right now.

And global markets this morning are mixed. Take a look at European indices with the FT 100 up 13, the CAC quarante up 35, the DAX index in Germany is lower by 14 points right now.

In Asia overnight markets were mostly higher. Coronavirus cases are rising in Hong Kong. Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam warning that the city is on the verge of a large scale community outbreak and that the hospital system could face collapse. The price of the Hang Seng index was up a half a percent nonetheless. The Shanghai composite the best performer, up 2 percent overnight.

Gold prices this morning working their way toward $2,000 in price. Now 660 this morning again. It's been on a huge run. Gold sitting at $1,970 and change.

Joining the conversation this morning, Dagen McDowell, Philip Wegmann and Scott Martin.

Great to see everybody this morning.

SCOTT MARTIN, CIO, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: Hi.

BARTIROMO: And some of the top stories that we are watching this morning, President Trump says that he does not 100 percent support some provisions in the next coronavirus stimulus relief plan, calling them semi-irrelevant during his briefing yesterday. He added that the Democrats want Republicans to go with their needs. Meanwhile, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says liability protection is a top priority.

The GOP is proposing a second round of $1,200 checks for Americans making less than $75,000 a year. Also in the plan, that $1 trillion plan of the GOP cutting the amount of the federal government pays in unemployment benefits from $600 currently to $200 a week. Democrats are looking for those payments to go up to $6,000 per household. They want to keep the $600 a week unemployment extension intact.

Sparks flying on Capitol Hill as Democrats spar with Attorney General Bill Barr yesterday during a heated House hearing. Democrats grilling Barr on the long list of topics yesterday, including his handling of the civil unrest in Portland. Barr fired back, accusing Democrats of turning a blind eye to ongoing violence across the country.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL: Federal courts are under attack. Since when is it OK to try to burn down a federal court? If someone went down the street to the Prettyman Court here, that beautiful courthouse we have right at the bottom of the hill, and started breaking windows and firing industrial grade fireworks in to start a fire, throw kerosene balloons in and -- and start fires in the court, is that OK? Is that OK now?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Barr also denying accusations that he's carrying out President Trump's political wishes. It was a big show in that hearing yesterday. All for show.

Grim, new milestones, meanwhile, in the Covid-19 pandemic. Six states reporting one-day records for deaths yesterday as Texas becomes the fourth state to pass the 400,000 Covid case mark. Dr. Anthony Fauci now warning parts of the Midwest, there are early sign that a coronavirus outbreak could be brewing in Indiana, Ohio, Tennessee and Kentucky.

Well, big tech is on the hot seat today on Capitol Hill. CEOs from Amazon, Apple, FaceBook and Google will testify by video before the House Judiciary Anti-Trust Subcommittee. They're expected to be grilled over their growing influence and the impact on competition. The testimony could help build public pressure for government action.

In separate statements, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and Sundar Pichai all emphasized competition that their companies face, as well as their contributions to the U.S. economy. Take a look at big tech in the pre- market. This morning we are looking at money moving into technology stocks once again. They are all up across the board.

Time for the "Word on Wall Street" where we look at what's driving markets and the economy. A major focus on earnings today.

Joining me right now is Kingsview Asset Management Chief Investment Officer Scott Martin, Walser Wealth Management President Rebecca Walser and Fairlead Strategies Founder, Managing Partner, Katie Stockton.

Great to see everybody this morning. Thank you so much for being here.

First up, futures are higher, fractionally so, ahead of a big day in earnings. We are waiting on Boeing, General Motors, General Dynamics, other companies as well, all expected to report second quarter results before the opening bell.

Rebecca, how has the earnings period been so far from your standpoint and what are you expecting?

REBECCA WALSER, PRESIDENT, WALSER WEALTH MANAGEMENT: I mean I think it's been good so far. Obviously we've had some surprises. Starbucks yesterday was a surprise with a 7 percent, you know, same sales -- store increase. It shows that people are still willing to buy a seven -- you know, a $5 coffee. Obviously, you know, we're always -- we're expecting everything to be mixed. Some are down, some are up. It depends on what specifically is going on with that specific stock. Obviously cloud services, computing, Amazon buying, those kinds of things all this week. We expect, you know, sales to look good, robust. Cloud computing obviously robust.

But it's a mixed bag of retail. Obviously very hard hit. All of the travel very hard hit, Maria. So it's a -- it's a mixed bag.

BARTIROMO: All right. Gold prices, meanwhile, reaching a new all-time high amid the economic uncertainty in the market.

Katie, you're also watching Bitcoin. Your reaction to what's taking place in Bitcoin but, more importantly, gold hitting a record high.

KATIE STOCKTON, FOUNDER AND MANAGING PARTNER, FAIRLEAD STRATEGIES: Well, yes, I mean, both are positively correlated. Gold reached new all-time high, as you mentioned, clearing final resistance from 2011. And that breakout, if it's confirmed in price and time, bodes well for upside follow through. It's already a very well-established, long-term uptrend. But the gains have been very impressive. It was up, I think, about 11 percent from this month's low to this month's high. So really a pretty strong breakout for gold prices. And we're seeing the same from Bitcoin, which was up about 28 percent from this month's low to this month's high. That breakout there targets prices well above current levels, around 13,850 for Bitcoin. So some impressive breakouts there, irrespective of the drivers, the momentum is certainly behind gold and Bitcoin.

BARTIROMO: So in terms of gold, you would be -- you would be buying in here? Does this chart indicate this rally continues?

STOCKTON: Breakouts tend to be pretty actionable on the upside. I'd like to see them confirmed. And by that I like to see the securities fund more than just a day or two above a resistance level. So as long as gold can hold up above this 1920 level, which was that final resistance from 2011, I think that's a real breakout and it is something that is actionable from a long- term perspective, yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. Meanwhile, many investors rushing into money market funds, go figure with rates where they are, Scott. Is there a flight to cash?

MARTIN: Yes, I don't get it, Maria. Actually there has been. And I think that's just like a general de-risking that investors are doing. I mean at Kingsview we get a lot of inquiries every day about going to cash, which is a strange thing, to your point, because money markets don't pay anything and there's really no inflation, so you're not getting that erosion there. And also, I mean, the value of the dollar is dropping faster than, say, players on the Miami Marlins baseball team. So it's interesting as to why you'd want to hold cash here. So that's what I think is also boosting markets. And I think to the point that Katie made, it seems like gold and Bitcoin, Maria, may be taking that place of cash, at least in has in our portfolio, as a way to hedge or de-risk from equities and bonds.

BARTIROMO: There -- there is a reason to believe if you've got increasing cash levels, Scott, then you've got potential for this market to go higher because of all of that dry powder, right?

MARTIN: Yes, big time. You've got pent-up demand. And I think you get that FOMO trade going again, Maria, where you just don't want to sit in the money market because you're lucky to get 1 percent these days at the banks, or sit at your brokerage house. So as that money kind of starts to see these companies, Rebecca talked about the tech stocks and how well they've done, as those start to get boosted up in price, the money's going to chase those names for sure.

BARTIROMO: I like that. FOMO, fear of missing out. Good one.

Katie Stockton, Rebecca Walser, thank you so much.

Scott Martin, you're here all morning, so we appreciate you being here.

We've got a big show this morning. We'll slip in a break.

Up next, Oklahoma Senator James Langford is here talking the latest on the stimulus bill and this mysterious story, scenes reportedly from China ending up in your mailboxes. Oh, yes.

Then, former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani is here on the growing unrest in largely Democratic cities. We will zero in on that.

Next hour, Delaware Senator Chris Coons talking stimulus and his new manufacturing legislation.

And then Trump 2020 Campaign Press Secretary Hogan Gidley talking the latest on the race for the White House.

Plus, who is watching you. One prominent pharmacy secretly using facial recognition technology for nearly a decade watching you while you shop. Don't miss that coming up.

All that and a lot more.

But first, this programming note.

Fox Business will be covering today's technology hearing on Capitol Hill. You can watch it all live right here starting at noon Eastern, don't miss it, on Fox Business.

Then this, you've got questions, we've got answers. Our new segment "Ask the Panel" begins next month. Send in your video questions at maria@foxbusiness.com

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Stimulus struggles. The battle over the next round of Covid-19 aid rages on in Washington days after the GOP unveiled its newest version. Democrats and some Republicans not sold on the newest proposal. President Trump weighed in yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: All of the people involved, Steven Mnuchin's done a great job, keeps everybody together, both Democrat and Republican, and we'll see. We want to do what's best for the people. I want to do what's best for the people. I want to do what's best for the economy because that means jobs and lots of good things, all right?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Oklahoma Senator, Homeland and Governmental Affairs and Finance Committee member James Langford.

And, Senator, it's great to see you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

SEN. JAMES LANKFORD (R-OK): Good to see you again as well.

BARTIROMO: Where are the sticking points? Tell us. We understand that liability protection is real important and then there's a debate around the $600 unemployment benefit a week. Steven Mnuchin's plan to do 70 percent with the federal government adding 20 percent to the state's 50 percent, that would be about $200 a week.

What's your take on where we are in all of this today?

LANKFORD: Yes, you're right onto the sticking points there, Maria. Obviously liability protection's a key thing. Businesses can't reopen. Schools can't reopen until they know there's some basic liability protection that are there dealing with this pandemic.

Now, this is not about gross negligence. Obviously if there's gross negligence that company or that institute would be responsible for -- but for basic operations, we believe that there should be liability protections across the country. As you mention before about the unemployment insurance, I've been overwhelmed with the number of people that have contacted me and said I have jobs open. I've been trying to hire for a long time now and people are saying, I will return after the unemployment benefits go down but I make more now on unemployment than I do on employment so it's better for my family to stay unemployed than it is to go back to employment.

Obviously that's discouraging to people that are actually still working, that they're working and earning their money and other people are staying home and earning more. That is always a problem. And that breaks the basics of unemployment insurance. So the target here for us is to be able to present an additional amount to individuals but not to get to what their previous salary was. Obviously we have to have an encouragement to return to work. That's what unemployment is in the past.

Another piece you hadn't mentioned before was on schools. The plan that we have given some assistance to every school across the country, but those that open will need more assistance. And so those schools that reopen actually will get additional dollars because they're going to have higher expense as well. It's not just blanketing money out to be able to target to every school as if they're the same. Some will have higher needs than others. And we're trying to target those with the highest need.

BARTIROMO: What about some of your colleagues who don't want to vote for any new money and any new stimulus package? You've some people, like Senator Rand Paul, and Senator Ted Cruz who say, look, we've already got three stimulus packages, the last one still on the table with money yet spent.

LANKFORD: Right, there's still Paycheck Protection Program funding that's still out there. This new proposal changes some of the way that it happens, targeting towards the great -- the business with greatest need. They have to have 50 percent revenue loss for them to be able to get it. So I do see some companies that will need help to be able to survive this. There's no goal to be able to try to make everyone whole. But we're trying to do enough to be able to get everyone through this so we can still have an economy on the other side.

I see the virus moving health wise as it does economic wise. Some people get the virus, they really have no evidence on that. Some people end up in the hospital on a ventilator where there's mortality with it. It's -- the same thing happens to the economy. We have some segments of the economy and some companies that have thrived through this, that have had no effect or their business has gone up because they're in one of those businesses of highest need. Other businesses have had dramatic effects though this. So the main goal that I have is to make sure we're targeting funds towards those who need the help the most and not pouring somebody else's money, which is what tax dollars are, somebody else's money into individuals that don't need it or into companies that don't need it. so we have to have a more surgical approach than what happened in March.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right, because the PPP money in March went to some business who didn't need it, some big businesses as well. So I agree this focus on smaller business and those in need is really critical right now.

Where are the discrepancies with the Democrats? Is it just the fact that they want to have a much bigger package, $3.5 trillion? Are there specifics you can share with us in terms of where you're finding pushback?

LANKFORD: Yes, so there's significant pushback here. Take the unemployment assistance. That additional $600 per week that now goes away July the 31st, they want to take that $600 a week and extend it all the way into next spring, regardless if we have a vaccine, regardless of what it may be. $600 additional a week to everyone in the country, I think that's a terrible idea.

They want to also extend the economic checks that are going out to individual. They want to extend those to people that don't have a Social Security Number, those are people who have a tax ID and many of those people are illegally present in the United States. We certainly don't want to be able to do that.

They want to be able to change the way that we vote in America permanently and this has become suddenly a new proposal for them to be able to change voting, take away all voter ID laws across the country to federalize all elections. We look at that and say, well, what does this have to do with Covid-19 long-term.

And so there's lots of issues that they've got in their bill that we say that's absolutely absurd, we're not going to change all voting in America permanently. We're not going to do checks to people who are illegally present in the country. They have a lot of different proposal there on the environment, on things that would go OK, that that has nothing to do with Covid-19. So we want to try to keep the focus on issues that are actually related to health issues and to try to get through the economy, not to use this as a big wish list and over $3 trillion in a single bill is larger than the previous four bills combined.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. I mean the numbers that you're talking about, what your colleagues on the left want, it's like there's no acknowledgement whatsoever of the $21 trillion in debt that this country faces.

LANKFORD: Right.

BARTIROMO: I want to switch gears and ask you about what is a mysterious story to us. Americans across the country have been receiving mystery seeds from China in the mail. Officials are urging people not to open or plant these seeds. What can you tell us about this?

LANKFORD: Yes, this has happened all over the country. And it's one of those issues that everyone says, oh, my gosh, the Chinese are trying to sneak invasive seeds into us. I think it's actually more just typical Chinese fraud that is happening. It looks like it's called -- what's called a brushing scam where a retailer, an online retailer, will just mail out packages, mislabel them. They're labeled jewelry or they're labeled toys. They get to a real address and once they're delivered to a real address they then take that address, use a fake e-mail address and write a positive review on their website saying I purchased this toy or I purchased this jewelry, it was delivered and it can be verified that something was delivered to them, but then they write a fake review on it to be able to bump it up.

So, again, I go back to the most basic thing, don't believe everything you read on the Internet, even some of those reviews that are out there, because it looks like this company is trying to bump up their reviews.

BARTIROMO: All right.

Senator, wow, another scam.

Senator, good to see you this morning. Thank you so much.

James Langford joining us in D.C.

We'll be right back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I'm going to have a choice in the first week in August and I promise I'll let you know when I do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was former Vice President Joe Biden teasing his running mate announcement coming next week. Biden was also photographed yesterday showing talking points on California Senator Kamala Harris, a potential frontrunner.

Dagen, did he give it away with that Kamala Harris talking points? What was your reaction?

MCDOWELL: Maybe accidentally, but he needs to pick somebody who can be an effective not just fundraiser, Kamala Harris is, but also can be out there and campaign in public, in person, and that at least voters will feel comfortable with their ideas. Because, again, Joe Biden, he hasn't really proved that he is, well, all there, if you will. I think that there are definitely concerns about, again, his cognitive sharpness and he needs people not just his running mate, but people around him.

I think there's going to be pressure on him put to show who would be in his cabinet, who he's getting his ideas from, because he's already teamed up with Bernie Sanders. People who are still, you know, kind of left of center, not sure they would be comfortable with his, say, climate change program, which would send energy prices skyrocketing in the United States.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, that -- that unity document was something with Bernie Sanders. And like I have reported in the past, there's some on Wall Street who believe Elizabeth Warren will be a critical voice in his -- whether it's his cabinet, but a critical voice on economic policy.

Who is the person no one is looking at, Philip, that could get the VP nod? What do you think?

PHILIP WEGMANN, WHITE HOUSE REPORTER, REAL CLEAR POLITICS: Well, there's -- there's a universe of possibilities out here. To Dagen's (ph) point a second ago, the one thing that I would add on top of Biden needing a candidate who's going to help energize his base, who's going to help, you know, bring the party back together, both the more progressive side and the centrist, is that, you know, Biden needs someone who is going to be a loyal legislative lieutenant because if he does win the White House back, there's going to be a brawl with Senate Republicans and it's going to be a big fight to get anything to the finish line.

BARTIROMO: Scott Martin, real quick, what do markets want to see? What do you think investors are betting on when it comes to the Biden camp?

MARTIN: Oh, they're betting on higher taxes, Maria, and more regulation on Wall Street and they don't like it. So I think going into the election, you're going to see a lot of volatility especially if the polls continue to show trends that we're showing right now.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will keep watching that.

We're going to take a break. When we come back, former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani is here to discuss the growing unrest in largely Democratic cities.

And then caffeine jolt. Find out why Starbucks is seeing a jump in its stock this morning. It's rallying.

We're back in a minute.

Stay with us.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX NEWS HOST: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, July 29th. A look at markets right now 7:31 am on the east coast it is a big day in Washington, big tech CEOs are testifying there.

Futures right now up 17 points and NASDAQ up 45 and the S&P up 5.25 right now. Boeing is crossing the tape as we speak with an earnings miss on expectations. It was expected that it would report a loss of $2.54. It's actually reporting a loss of 479.

Revenue is also missing expectations as Boeing hits the tape right now. We're watching Futures to see if we get a larger reaction than just Boeing stock as we see the markets trading off this morning with the DOW up about 11 points. Losses yesterday on Wall Street yesterday as well take a look at 4:00 on Wall Street we had a triple digit decline.

The DOW Industrials are down 205 points and NASDAQ lower by 134 and the S&P gave up 21 points yesterday. Global markets this morning with a firmer tone. European Indices right now are mixed with FT100 up 5 points, the CAC Quarante up 37 but the DAX Index is lower by 7 and three quarters.

In Asia overnight markets were mostly higher, best performers once again China the SHANGHAI Composite up better 2 percent. Boeing is out as you just heard. Let's get more details from Cheryl. She's got the numbers Cheryl right now.

CHERYL CASONE, CORRESPONDENT, FOX BUSINESS: Well, first we were looking for a loss of 254 for the earnings per share Maria. We got a loss of 479. But if you look at the revenue, that was also a miss for Boeing. As you can see the revenue, 13.16 billion was the estimate. They came in at 11.8 billion.

But it's more about the commentary from the company that really Wall Street cares about right now. There goes the stock into the negative a couple things, the 737 Max, big area of focus right now for investors. Resuming production of the Max in May they already did that. But it's a very slow process they're telling investors right now.

They're also saying that this production of the 737 Max is coming in at low rates. Remember the FAA is still testing the Max right now. The Max has not been cleared to fly. We also heard the FAA say that they're going to actually have public comments on the Max.

The other issue is Coronavirus. They're saying that there is a big impact from Coronavirus and also officially ended production of the 747 and they're really slowing down the 787 and the 777. So it's a big production problem. Their numbers hurting GE earlier this morning because that's a jet engine maker, GE has a big engine business.

So a lot of triple - ripple effects excuse me from the Boeing numbers. As you can see, the stock is down and it's DOW component, down almost 1 percent right now. And also they're going to be talking in the call it looks like a lot more about employee retention rates and also staffing at the company.

We'll get more on the call from Dave Calhoun, the CEO. But again, we're watching Boeing stock in the red right now after reporting earnings. The only DOW component we're going to get this morning Maria.

Also I want to talk about Starbucks right now. We're watching this stock right now. They're saying that more than 5 percent increase, they were up more than 5 percent in the afterhours. Now the stock is up about 5.6 percent. 97 percent of their company-operated stores worldwide have reopened.

Good news here. That includes 96 percent of stores here in this country. 99 percent of stores are back in business over in China. As you know, that is a big market obviously for Starbucks. And then real quick Maria, I want to show you some of the stories that are trending on foxbusiness.com.

A new blood test can detect Alzheimer's disease with nearly 100 percent accuracy in 20 years before symptoms even begin, amazing. Netflix earning a record 160 prime time Emmy nominations the most ever for a single network and Dunkin teamed up with post consumer brands to create two new coffee flavored cereals.

So if you like to drink your coffee, you can now eat your coffee, Maria. A lot of news breaking in the newsroom but I'll send it back over to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl, thank you so much. Meanwhile Capitol Hill clashes, Attorney General Bill Barr delivering fiery testimony yesterday in front of the House Judiciary Committee. AG Barr going toe to toe with Democrats on a series of issues from Russia meddling to ongoing protests across the country. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Attorney General, the time is mine.

WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL: You waited to talk to me like this. You didn't need to wait so long.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. Attorney General, you did answer the questions.

BARR: Now you said under penalty of perjury. I'm going to answer the damn question. I asked another U.S. Attorney to look into the issue of unmasking because of the high number of unmasking and some that do not readily appear to have been in the line of normal business.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R-OH): I want to be clear. So there is another investigation on that issue specifically going on at the Justice Department right now?

BARR: Yes.

JORDAN: Can you give us that U.S. Attorney's name or is that something you're comfortable doing?

BARR: John Bash of Texas. Federal courts are under attack. Since when is it okay to try to burn down a federal court? The U.S. marshals have a duty to stop that and defend the courthouse of. That's what we're doing in Portland. We are at the courthouse, defending the courthouse. We're not looking for trouble.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Former Mayor of New York City, Personal Attorney for President Trump, Rudy Giuliani. Rudy it is always a pleasure to see you. Thank you so much for being here. What a state of affairs.

RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER NEW YORK CITY MAYOR: Nice to see you, Maria. Well, I'm looking at that--

BARTIROMO: Tell me how you see things? We had Barr yesterday. Yes, reaction?

GIULIANI: I see Attorney General Barr as one of our greatest Attorney Generals. Because he's being challenged in a way no Attorney General has ever been challenged and he hasn't backed off at all. The things he said yesterday in a normal America would be just okay, that's right, we have to defend a federal courthouse.

We can't let people loot. We can't let people steal from stores. We can't let people turn cities into war zones. The only people who seem to want that are the Democrats and it really is tragic because they want it in order to defeat Donald Trump. In other words, they want crime. I don't think they realize it.

They even want murder so that they can defeat him. Not one of them, not one of them spoke up for law and order. This isn't even a close question, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

GIULIANI: These cities - and these cities, the worst ones are all governed by Democrats. I can't imagine having governed New York City for eight years, and I took it over when I was in the worst shape possible, I can't imagine this happening in the 1990s. We were never even close to anything like this.

BARTIROMO: I know.

GIULIANI: This is anarchy.

BARTIROMO: I want to get back to New York because obviously NYPD is under attack. But let me just stay in Portland for a second. Because one thing that is just not even being acknowledged is the fact that you've got anarchists wearing gas masks going right up to the courthouse with a saw and the local police can't do anything.

They're told to step back and this is what the Democrats are calling peaceful protests. There are two agents right now who may not get their eye sight back. We are waiting to see what happens because the anarchists were shining lasers in their eyes.

Chad Wolf was with me on Sunday, he said we're waiting to see how they are. We hope that they get their eyesight back but they are now impaired. No recognition of the fact that what's happening in Portland is totally different than what's happening across the country in these cities. They're not going to send in the federal agents that they have in Portland to somewhere like Chicago because it's really about protecting the courthouse and the federal property.

GIULIANI: That's absolutely correct. And there are people who recognize what's going on? President Trump is the one who recognizes what's going on. Republicans recognize what's going on. And everybody else that isn't blinded with the sickness of hating Trump, President Trump so much that they don't care what happens to America.

I mean, you have to be blind not to - I'm sorry I used that because of the poor gentlemen that are suffering. I pray that that not happen. It broke my heart when I was Mayor--

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly--

GIULIANI: --police officers with injury.

BARTIROMO: --we're all praying for them.

GIULIANI: But this is a war--

BARTIROMO: Mayor de Blasio said we don't want anybody from the federal government coming to New York, the NYPD is under serious attack, Rudy, you know this. Violent protests in New York earlier this summer racking up a big bill for taxpayers there's that as well. This is costing a lot of money.

NYPD told the New York Post that nearly $1 million has been spent to repair more than 300 vandalized police vehicles. That's just the police vehicles, Rudy. In terms of what's going on in New York right now.

GIULIANI: Well, there have been close to what 1,000 police officers injured and the reality is the moron who is our Mayor doesn't know there are many, many federal agents in New York City right now. They called the drug enforcement administration, the FBI, alcohol, tobacco and firearms, the IRS.

I used to be in charge of them when I was United States Attorney more on. And they're enforcing federal laws. And I'm going to tell you one law that exists, it's the law against using drugs, illegal drugs, including for your knowledge, Mr. Mayor, marijuana.

I never prosecuted a marijuana case but the fact is that they have jurisdiction and one of my suggestions which I'll make openly is wipe out the drug dealers in the neighborhoods that have the most shootings and you will bring down those shootings by 50 percent. DEA can do that.

They should target two or three top areas for shootings and they should go in with federal agents and they should take out the people who are controlling those blocks like the little children that are shot, they get shot in cross fires with drug addicts. 70 percent of the shootings in New York--

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

GIULIANI: --have to do with drugs and the idiot who is our Mayor release them from jail because he doesn't consider it a violent crime. If you don't realize drug dealing is a violent crime then you're too stupid to be Mayor or you're too malicious to be Mayor or you're a communist who wants to see the overthrow of our of way of life.

Which is what is at stake here, Maria. They are trying to fundamentally change the nature of our country and I'll be damned if I'm going to let them get away with it.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, no wonder the police are saying, look, I'm out of here. They're not getting the support from the Mayor or the Governor. Look what's happening in terms of Milwaukee and the Democratic National Convention?

Police are pulling out of the DNC the Milwaukee Police Chief announced that dozens of law enforcement agencies have backed out of security agreements for the Democratic National Convention. This convention happening next month some are citing recent orders by the Milwaukee fire and police commission to stop using tear gas and pepper spray.

So Rudy they're basically saying to the cops, yes, we want you to protect us but we're not going to give you the tools you need, you can't use pepper spray or you can't use tear gas but still protect us. They said we can't protect ourselves in that regard, we're going to pull out.

GIULIANI: Well, go read the Marxist manifesto of Black Lives Matter and you'll find that one of the things they want to do is break the connection between us and the police. As well as do away with nuclear families. They don't like fathers.

They're at war with our way of life. When I went to the Democratic Convention four years ago, I was the one that discovered, because the Philadelphia police all came up to me and told me that Hillary Clinton would not have uniformed police officers on the floor of the convention because she didn't want police around.

Now it's gone to the point where they're trying to put these police in jail. Some of these Democratic Mayors have gone so far that they're almost like criminals. They're on the side of the criminals. I think people don't realize it because--

BARTIROMO: You hit on something that I want to ask you about before you go.

GIULIANI: --depressed - they're like criminals.

BARTIROMO: A lot of these cities are being run by Democrat Mayors and Governors. So what is it? Is it the policies that are making them vulnerable to all of this crime? Connect the dots for us in terms of the Democrat leadership.

(LAUGHTER)

GIULIANI: Two Ps, policy and pandering. I used to say that when I became Mayor. This isn't a question of atmosphere it's a question of policy. You have the wrong policies, you have the wrong results. We had that for 30 years in New York on the Democratic Mayors.

Number two, in addition to having the wrong policies, which is letting criminals out of jail, not really enforcing the law correctly, giving criminals benefits they shouldn't get, letting 8,000 criminals out like the idiot in New York did.

They also pander, pan decks pander, pander, almost like they have no backbone. Black Lives Matter says put our sign up but don't bother to read that we want to do away with families with fathers. Don't bother to read we want to do away with all private education, all parochial schools, gone. Don't bother to read that. These idiots go yes, yes, yes. They have no backbone.

BARTIROMO: It's an incredible moment, Rudy. Love getting your insights as always. Thank you so much, Rudy Giuliani. We'll see you soon. Rudy, thank you. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Watch out for secret cameras, Rite Aid deploying facial recognition systems at hundreds of its locations across the country. According to an alarming new investigation by Reuters the drugstore chain capturing customer faces for more than eight years, largely in lower income and nonwhite neighborhoods. And only recently did they stop this practice.

Joining us right now is Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano. Judge what a story. Obviously there are real privacy concerns here. We want you to tell us, is this legal?

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Well, good morning, Maria. It's a novel area of the law. There are a lot of problems with it. I'll startle you at the outset. The software was made in China. So you know where this information is ultimately--

BARTIROMO: I knew it.

NAPOLITANO: --ultimately going to be stored. So there are two ways to look at this. One is you don't have a right to privacy in public you willingly and knowingly expose your face. The other is you don't expect to be spied upon when you're in a store shopping.

By the way, this facial recognition software has a very high error rate and often misidentifies people. Stated differently, people were approached in these stores by store security who thought they were someone else who had already been thrown out of the store for attempting to shoplift.

The person approached was totally innocent, was not the other person. Now you have a false arrest case. So the whole thing is a mess. Apparently you're right it did go on for about eight years. The people who were actually harmed by it, those who were misidentified and suffered consequences because of the misidentification have a cause of action against the stores, against rite aid or whoever has been doing this.

BARTIROMO: You know, I've been told that there are trillions of pictures of all of us in government portfolios that government has our pictures as well. Look, the horse is out of the wagon on this one. Facial recognition is being used and how is it any different than, for example, Apple capturing fingerprints or clear using biometrics? We're being identified in a lot of ways.

NAPOLITANO: Well, when you give your finger print to Apple you're aware that you're doing it. You do it knowingly and voluntarily. When you walk outside the Fox building, you're picked up immediately by at least a half dozen, if you don't know where they are, they're easy to see, New York City cameras owned by the government.

We know that that stuff is out there. I disagree with this but the government has persuaded everybody that it's worth the loss of privacy in order to make it easier for them to find the bad guys. But when you go into a store and you don't know it's happening, when your privacy is secretly being violated, when you're being misidentified as someone whom you're not, that's a very serious issue. That will have economic consequences on the store.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a very important point, Judge. Thanks very much for making it. Great to see you sir. Thank you, Judge Andrew Napolitano. Stay with us. We'll be right back big hour coming up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back time for the Morning Buzz. First up, giving back billions McKenzie Scott formerly McKenzie Bezos, now the ex-wife of Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos giving away nearly $1.7 billion to charity intending to donate the majority of her money. Dagen, wow, what numbers?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, CORRESPONDENT, FOX BUSINESS: I know. Let's think about how she wound up with all that money. First, this is a giant monopoly that is squeezing smaller businesses out of business. Number one and two, raises the issue of how's the new girlfriend spending the billions or fiance or whatever they are?

BARTIROMO: Right, but yes. Yes. Well, she says McKenzie's giving it away which is great. We'll take a look at what charities they are. How about this beer without the buzz Anheuser-Busch rolling out Budweiser zero with just 50 calories, no alcohol, its geared towards the health conscience and apparently tastes like an actual bear.

The alcohol free beverage endorsed by former NBA player Dwayne Wade who helped design the packaging. So what do you think? Would you drink nonalcoholic beer?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Well, Anheuser-Busch is betting that people buy Budweiser for the taste. But I think that the virtues of Budweiser are that it's cheap alcohol and trying to sell a beer without alcohol, that's a bold strategy. We'll see if that will work out.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Scott (ph), what about you? Are you in?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, I'm in. I think it's one of those things where you're not going to notice the difference. You could give somebody NA beer; you give regular beer and Budweiser kind of tastes so bad anyway it is going to be all the same.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a break. When we come back, you've got questions, we've got answers. Our new segment, "Ask the Panel", begins next month. Send in your video questions, we want to know what's on your mind. Send them to maria@foxbusiness.com and we'll get them on the air. Much more ahead, next hour, right here. "Mornings with Maria" is live on Fox Business.

Matt Gaetz (R-FL) is Interviewed about CEOs Testifying on Capitol Hill; Shopify COO on E-Commerce2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTSteve Forbes, Mark Tepper, Jeff Saut, Dennis Gartman, Rick Scott, Harley FinkelsteinNEWSFinancial073002cb.231Word on Wall Street; Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL) is Interviewed about the Coronavirus and Stimulus; Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL) is Interviewed about CEOs Testifying on Capitol Hill; Shopify COO on E-CommerceMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, July 30th.

Your top stories right now, just before 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Big tech is in focus. FaceBook, Amazon, Google parent Alphabet, and Apple all reporting earnings tonight after the closing bell. This after their CEOs were grilled on Capitol Hill yesterday about anti-conservative bias, business practices, privacy and China. Highlights from the fiery hearing coming up.

Stimulus stalemate now. Lawmakers far from an agreement on the next round of coronavirus aid. This as the extra unemployment benefits, $600 a week, are set to expire tomorrow. The coronavirus effect on the U.S. economy today at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We'll get the first read on the second quarter GDP. It's going to be a tough one. It's expected to show a record breaking contraction of 34.1 percent. Plus, initial jobless claims are expected to rise for a second week in a row. All coming out in an hour and a half.

Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve not even thinking about raising rates now. Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell saying that the current economic downturn is the most severe in our lifetime, warning containing Covid is essential to protect our health, as well as the economy.

Stocks to watch today. UPS is surging after a big double beat this morning. The coronavirus leading to a rise in demand. The stock is up, as you see, about 11.5 percent. Qualcomm is also jumping after earnings, as well as reaching a long-term patent settlement with Huawei. That stock up this morning 11.5 percent.

Broader markets, meanwhile, are lower. Futures indicating a sell-off at the start of trading this morning. The Dow futures are down 264 points, the Nasdaq down 137, the S&P 500 down 36.

Markets rallied yesterday, meanwhile, following the Federal Reserve's decision. At the close yesterday, the DowIndustrials were up 160, the Nasdaq was up 140.

Meanwhile, unrest in America penetrates with violence raging in major cities. Federal agents will start leaving Portland, but the administration says, not so fast.

And then this, the NBA tipping off today. Players taking the court in a bubble at Disney World with empty stands.

Fanduel CEO Matthew King is here at 8:40 a.m. Eastern on how the virus is impacting gambling as well as sports in general.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live right now.

Global markets this morning are weaker. Take a look at European indices. Red across the board. FT 100 down 122, the CAC quarante down 80 and the DAX index lower by 374 points. That's because of economic data out of Germany today. The German economy shrinking a record 10.1 percent in the second quarter, due, of course, to the coronavirus shutdowns.

In Asia overnight markets were mostly lower, but really fractionally moving pretty much across the board.

Joining the conversation this morning, Dagen McDowell, Mark Tepper and Steve Forbes.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to with you.

BARTIROMO: Some of the top stories that we are watching this morning, another round of talks between the White House and Congress on a new Covid- 19 stimulus bill set for today with no compromise in sight yet.

Republicans are proposing a second round of $1,200 checks for Americans making less than $75,000. Democrats want to extend that $600 weekly unemployment benefit, but Republicans are pushing to cut the amount to $200 a week. Just to be clear how this works, the state will replenish 50 percent of lost earnings. The Republicans want to add 20 percent to that, take it up of to 70 percent replacement of earnings. That number roughly is $200 a week.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi rejecting President Trump's support for a short- term bill if the two sides cannot reach an agreement by tomorrow when those enhanced jobless benefits expire.

And the U.S. reaching a grim milestone in the coronavirus pandemic. The U.S. has now surpassed 150,000 deaths, now leading the world in death as well as in cases. Seven states reporting a record number of deaths in a single day, yesterday.

All members of the House of Representatives are now required to wear masks while on the floor after Texas Congressman Louis Gohmert tested positive for Covid-19. Attorney General Bill Barr was tested after being with Gohmert at Tuesday's House hearing. Barr tested negative.

And federal agents are expected to begin leaving Portland today as the city sees its 63rd straight night of unrest. The Trump administration, as well as Oregon leaders, reaching a deal yesterday to withdraw the agents after accusations of excessive force used against protesters. This as the White House announces the expansion of Operation LeGend, deploying agents to other cities, like Milwaukee, Cleveland and Detroit, to put an end to the violence and vandalism.

All right, time for the "Word on Wall Street." Joining me right now, former publisher and editor of "The Gartman Letter," Dennis Gartman is here, along with Capital Wealth Planning Advisory Board Member and Founder of Saut Strategy, Jeff Saut, and Strategic Wealth Partners President and CEO Mark Tepper.

Online shopping is surging. One company benefiting big time from the e- commerce explosion during coronavirus is Shopify, easily beating expectations with its latest earnings and revenue for the online retail platform nearly doubling from a year earlier.

Joining me right now is the chief operating officer of Shopify, Harley Finkelstein.

And, Harvey, it's great -- Harley, it's great to have you this morning. Thanks very much for being here.

HARLEY FINKELSTEIN, COO, SHOPIFY: Thanks for having me back, Maria. Great to be on your show.

BARTIROMO: So -- so, first, assess the situation for us, Harley. Tell me how good a quarter it was and what really struck you about this last three months.

FINKELSTEIN: Yes. Yes, I mean, Q2 for Shopify was great. Revenue was up 97 percent. GMV, meaning the sales on the platform was up almost 120 percent. But I think this is a story of independent retail and entrepreneurs and small businesses doing really well right now and during the pandemic. And I think what's happening is consumers are voting with their wallets that they want to support their small businesses and the entrepreneurs in their community and around the world.

And I think what we're seeing really out of this pandemic is a tale of two retail worlds. On one side you have the resistant retailers, those that are going out of business because they couldn't adapt fast enough. But there's an entire other side which is very exciting and I'm optimistic about, which is the resilient retailers, those that quickly pivoted their businesses, those restaurants that turned into wine shops, those brick and mortar stores that moved online very quickly. And most of them did that using Shopify. So it's been a really interesting time for us.

BARTIROMO: Well, if you don't have a delivery mechanism and you can't adapt easily to either delivery or park side -- you know, curbside pickup, you are at a serious disadvantage in this shutdown?

FINKELSTEIN: You are, which is why as soon as the pandemic hit, we threw out all of our plans for the year. We said that all your road maps need to be put on pause in terms of the folks that work at Shopify and we said we need to figure out a way to help entrepreneurs and small businesses not only survive the pandemic but also thrive.

So we got started quickly on doing things like gift cards so that service- based businesses can begin to collect money and get some cash flow. We added new curbside pickup and local delivery options for anyone that used Shopify point of sale in their brick and mortar store. And they did it. And then, again, the consumer decided that this is how they want to purchase.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FINKELSTEIN: We took e-commerce, remember, before the pandemic started, e- commerce was about 15 percent of total retail sales. Today, it's more than 30 percent. So we've had 10 years' worth of growth in e-commerce in the last three or four months and some of -- some of those businesses, those independent brands, have done really well. It's not going back to -- to a previous version. This is the new steady state.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and we spoke with Max Levchin last week about your deal with Affirm.

FINKELSTEIN: Right.

BARTIROMO: I know you've been striking various deals.

How important was the Affirm deal for you? Real quick. I want to get into this Discovery new series, but tell me about the Affirm deal.

FINKELSTEIN: Yes. Me too. I mean, look, we believe that any way that we can make it easier for consumers to check out online quickly, effectively and affordably is a great way to do it. And the partnership between Affirm and Shopify is a great way to do, you know, to do installment payments.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

So, Harley, you've got this new series premiering on The Discovery Channel. It's called "I Quit." What's the premise?

FINKELSTEIN: Well, first of all, we think a world with more entrepreneurs is a better world. I think you and I have discussed this on your show in the past, Maria, we both are big fans of small business.

But if you look at most of the content being created on television, for entrepreneurs, it really is around drama. It isn't necessarily an inspiring way to get more people to think about starting a business. And we felt that, right, honestly, Shopify is the entrepreneurship company. We want to create a show that inspires more people to become entrepreneurs. And so we're following five different companies -- five different groups of people that have side hustles but full-time jobs. They end up quitting their jobs and they end up full -- working full-time on their businesses and they do incredibly well. And we want to create an entire new generation of entrepreneurs through the show with Discovery.

BARTIROMO: I love it. Love that side hustle. We'll be watching it on Discovery.

Harley, good to see you. Thanks so much.

We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Time for the "Morning Buzz."

First up, claws out. "Tiger King" star Jeff Lowe and PETA in a legal battle over a Halloween costume. Lowe objecting to PETA's tiger king getup. The animal's rights organization rejecting a cease and desist, calling Lowe's claims absurd. The costume costs about $160.

Mark, what do you say about this?

TEPPER: Well, unfortunately, they just foiled my Halloween costume idea for this year, so now I have to go back to the drawing board.

Look, I'm surprised it was PETA that came up with the tiger killer costume and not Carole Baskin, because we all know about that ongoing quarrel between Joe Exoitc and Carole Baskin.

As for the lawsuit, what do you expect? We live in a litigious society. It seems a bit frivolous to me, but, you know, that's part of the course anymore.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I guess so.

All right, next up, Brooks backing out. Garth Brooks saying that he's withdrawing his name from Entertainer of the Year consideration at the CMSs. The seven-time winner of the country music honor says it's time for somebody else to hold that award.

Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Praise Garth not just for his music and his kindness, but for his self-awareness because we need more of that in the United States.

BARTIROMO: Sure do.

All right, and, finally, love and AI. Scientists using artificial intelligence to predict what makes a successful relationship. The new study says believing your partner is fully committed is key to romance. Appreciation and intimacy also rate high.

Steve, your reaction?

FORBES: You need scientists for that? I'm the father of five daughters. If you want to know about relationships, start reading novels by Jane Austen and take it from there. You don't need the scientist to get you into that.

BARTIROMO: All right, good advice.

Still ahead, former White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders is here on the stalled stimulus talks, the conservative bias on social media and the upcoming 2020 election, all right hour, right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Stay with us.
