urn:contentItem:5W8W-Y981-JB20-G1NH-00000-00Workday Inc at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Technology Conference - Final2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexis060419a12567864.764Workday Inc at Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch Global Technology Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Aneel Bhusri

Workday, Inc. - Co-Founder, CEO & Director

Conference Call Participants

* John Peter King

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - Research Analyst

* Kasthuri Gopalan Rangan

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - MD and Head of Software

Presentation

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN, MD AND HEAD OF SOFTWARE, BOFA MERRILL LYNCH, RESEARCH DIVISION: This is a really special day. So for some that have already heard this, sorry for repeating this, today is almost -- it is exactly my 25th year on the sell side as a tech analyst. And what better way to celebrate that by hosting Aneel Bhusri, back again. Truly exciting to have you back on. And I think we've -- I've known you for 20-plus years. I forget, mid-'90s.

ANEEL BHUSRI, CO-FOUNDER, CEO & DIRECTOR, WORKDAY, INC.: We've been friends for a long time. You continue to impress me with your wardrobe.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Thank you. Thank you. And you're very consistent. You're very consistent.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Well, you want to go from a hoodie last year? Was it a hoodie last year or the year before?

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: We keep changing. We keep evolving.

ANEEL BHUSRI: The hair stays the same.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: All right. Thank you. Thank you.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Congratulations, 25 years.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Thank you. Thank you so much. Thank you. And congratulations in all the successes you've had. Two great stories back to back. People stop and work. Every year, the story continues to evolve and takes on bigger and broader and bolder dimensions. And so thanks for all the value creation for shareholders. Everybody along the way. It's fantastic.

Questions and Answers

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: I want to touch upon just 2 things, get them out of the way because these are topical and on people's minds. Your thoughts on the trade war. How does it pertain to Workday? And secondly, the whole topic of regulation. Maybe it's not pertinent to Workday, but you saw the stock market really get impacted in a pretty good way yesterday. Pertinent to the [finance]. But maybe what's on people's minds is does it have any percolation effect in software. Maybe it doesn't, maybe it does. Just wanted to get your thoughts on these 2.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Okay. Well, on the trade wars, which continue to expand to new countries, I can say that we're not exposed to China. We're not exposed to Mexico, either. But our customers are. And that's the one thing that we have to pay attention to. But we don't sell directly into China. We've always been careful because of their lack of data privacy rules and our set of core values that we have to be in countries where data privacy and security are paramount. And I know that for in China, we couldn't guarantee that to our customers. So at this point, we sell to Chinese multinationals, like a higher Lenovo, but no other real exposure.

But I happen to be on the Board of Intel, and they're in the middle of all this. And so for companies like Intel and others, will it impact what they spend on enterprise, software and cloud software? I don't know. We haven't seen it yet. We haven't seen it yet. But I don't know.

In terms of the regulation, I frankly, I won't say welcome it, but we do need better data privacy rules in the U.S. And I am always second after Marc Benioff to remind people that our business model is protecting customer data. There are other companies who have business models that sell customer data. And just don't put us all in the same bucket because that's not right. We've been great stewards of our customers' data since we started the company, as has Salesforce, as has ServiceNow, as has all the enterprise companies, where we build systems to protect the data.

We're one of the, not only early followers, we actually helped the EU with the GDPR rules. And so we'd be delighted to help with the rules here. So I'm not sure we don't qualify as big tech, but big tech that's consumer oriented. I don't think it's the worst thing to get some regulation. And they could have been ahead of the curve. And instead, they're going to get it -- get told what to do by Washington, which I think is probably not the right way. But I think -- I still think they have a chance to get ahead of the curve.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Thanks. Market perspective. I just wonder if it's going to cost fund flows to benefit the software sector. Although it did seem that way yesterday.

ANEEL BHUSRI: No. We were down $12, no.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Certainly, not yesterday. I wanted just start off with digital transformation, which is something that you've been front and center very early. Your sort of company and a lot of other companies are starting to talk about it. As it relates to improving the employee experience, how does Workday -- because the mandate of Workday, the mission of Workday 5 years back was very different from what it is today. Or maybe it is not. But I just wanted to see how you would define digital transformation as far as the employee's concerned and how does Workday as a company describe its mission to empower the employee experience?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Well, I think to your point, it has evolved over time. But one of the founding principles was definitely to create a consumer Internet style user experience for employees to engage employees. When we started out, it was much more focused on core HR services. It's now expanded to recruiting, learning, performance, a whole host of other expenses. Obviously, financial management. And that focus on employee engagement and transparency, getting them the information to make better decisions has always been core to what we've been about. It's just that the areas we're doing it have expanded to a much broader footprint. But it's very simple. The most powerful systems don't necessarily have the most functionality. Although I think we're very good on that dimension. They're the ones that people like to use. And you don't wake up and look at a training manual for Amazon or eBay and you shouldn't have to look at a training manual for Workday. And part of this transformation is making systems very accessible.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Besides Bank of America, are there other customers that you could point out to and say these guys have done a fantastic job implementing the whole employee engagement cycle with Workday products?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Well, we've got 2,700 customers, about 70% are live. So there's lots of good stories out there. Coca-Cola's a great story. Amazon is going through deployment. Walmart is going through deployment. One of most fascinating ones to me is Walmart. We are live with Sam's Club, and they've got, without getting into the details, they've got several million employees and they're using Workday as a platform for not just an HR system, but for engagement because they don't have all the e-mail addresses. Turnover is high and they're trying to change the culture. Doug McMillon is one of the most impressive CEOs I've come across in a long time. And they're really using it to modernize the way that they deal with their people. So it's a very cool project.

All the big tech companies in the Valley, Google, Facebook, Adobe, Salesforce, they all use Workday, and I think they do it in a nice way. Oracle doesn't use Workday, but that's about it. I think they're the only one.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: You've got to work hard on that one. I know you and I talked about the misperception that the TAM, total available market, for HCM is defined by the old lens. And you've always believed it or you've grown to increasingly believe that the TAM for HCM is a lot larger than people think. Just drill us with that notion back again, why do you believe that HCM TAM is a lot larger than people think?

ANEEL BHUSRI: We're all a function of our past lives in history. And historically, HCM was an administrative system around HR, payroll and benefits. But what's gotten sucked into the HCM platform includes performance management, now recruiting, learning, and each of these are huge categories. Now there's health and wellness as an emerging category. Broader integration into the benefits platform is an emerging category.

When I sit down with CEOs 20 years ago, they didn't talk about HR. Today, they all want to talk about talent and their people and how did they recruit the best, how they retain the best, what's best-in-class from compensation perspective, from rewards perspective. So it's definitely just -- the category has just gotten a lot bigger. And one day, we're looking at it and say all the data is around HR payroll benefits, but the category's a lot bigger than that because we're selling into a lot more areas. So it's always been a 2:1 difference between Financials and HR. And I think, actually, HR is now 1:1. I think the market size for HR is...

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: 2:1 meaning financials.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Was twice as big, and I think it's actually 1:1. I mean we're still early in the cloud journey. And we were pretty successful at PeopleSoft, but we peaked and -- at a much smaller revenue number that was a license base revenue number than we are today and I still feel like we're still in the early days of HR [product].

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: The way rapidly compared to -- even the midpoint of the PeopleSoft cycle just kind of grew through and you didn't see back then. Last year when you were here, you talked about a long-term plan to be a $10 billion revenue company. There's also the view that you could go from wherever you were to 5, for the most part, organically. Then after that, you would have to make some acquisitions. Help us understand what are your refined thoughts on that long-term journey for Workday to be a $10 billion revenue company.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Robynne, can I talk about this? Our CFO is in the audience. It's our internal goal -- we haven't really talked about it publicly. It's our internal goal that somehow became external. When I look at the categories that we're in, HR, financials, planning, analytics, there's no question that there's enough there to get us to a $10 billion revenue run rate. The question is how long does it take?

And do I think we could use a fifth pillar? Possibly. It could be Workday Cloud Platform as our fifth pillar. It could be a new area that we decide we need to acquire into. There are not that many areas that are that -- that are open that fit the cross industry model that we have. I feel very confident that we've got enough products and breadth of offerings to get to 5 and then 10. Might we do something inorganic to accelerate that? I mean if we find something like Adaptive, we would do that again. Maybe that was -- acquisitions are hard, large acquisitions in particular are very hard. That one has worked out really well.

But the CEO is one of my best friends, completely complementary technology, very similar corporate cultures. Space was hot. Cloud. I mean there's a lot of things that -- that came through a very tight aperture for what makes a good acquisition.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Maybe since you mentioned Adaptive, I'm just curious. This is the new start of the fiscal year. You've had Adaptive for 2 quarters, start period of last year. As you post this new fiscal year, what are the things that Workday could be doing with Adaptive that you could not quite do last year? Go to market, product, customer reach?

ANEEL BHUSRI: We just continue to refine the go-to-market piece. I would say that the first thing we decided to do was really just not get in the way of their business momentum and they're best at bringing -- selling into their core markets, which is probably more SMB and medium enterprise than our core market. And the leverage has been from, they had 6 or 7 enterprise sales reps. As you know, we have hundreds for large enterprise. It's been to put the product into the hands of our large enterprise sales representatives to either sell it as an add-on to Workday, HR and Financials or as part of a larger deal. And that has worked, I think, even better than we had hoped. So that's where -- I was talking about synergies and an acquisition scenario. And the synergy came from leveraging Workday's customer base and sales channel to the high end of the market where Adaptive really wasn't playing and it has worked out the way we thought.

So going into this year, we're really not going to change it that much. They're going to continue to sell into their market with their -- the Adaptive standalone team. We're trying to really let them run as a standalone sales organization.

We'll continue to drive it up market. But over time, you can see it -- you can already see it going from financial planning, which is their strength, to workforce planning into a whole host of other planning categories. And it's a huge market. People ask me all the time about Anaplan. The market's definitely big enough for both of us. It's just Anaplan and Adaptive and the cloud planning space. So we tend to be more focused on financial planning and now workforce planning and they tend to be more focused on sales and operational planning. So the fact they don't butt heads that often. But it's been great so far.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Yes. Excellent. I was surprised to see that you had, what, 50 deals, platform deals that included Adaptive. And how broadly trained is the Workday sales force selling Adaptive? I know that you got the specialist that came from Adaptive.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Yes. If you remember, we had our own planning product that was probably 2 or 3 years behind Adaptive. So they were -- they sold a lot of it, which tells me that they're really good at selling a product that wasn't quite ready for prime time. And then once we figured out it wasn't ready for prime time, we bought Adaptive. So sales force was really well trained on the planning space, especially the financial -- the financials specialists. Planning is just a core part of any accounting solution, and they really know how to sell it.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Is there a potential upsell to that installed base that bought the Workday core planning product? Or do you get that for free since you already made the commitment and now you've got Adaptive?

ANEEL BHUSRI: So for all the Workday Planning folks, they are all transitioning to Adaptive. We have basically sun setted the Workday planning product, and we're doing it on our -- they don't spend anything. They're already subscribed to the Workday Planning product.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Yes. Yes. So the notion that Adaptive was mid-market-ish and a plan was high end, the scalability is different. Where are we in that plug in that scalability gap that exists or used to exist between...

ANEEL BHUSRI: I think the scalability gap was much more a sales and marketing issue than a product issue. There were definitely areas for Adaptive that they needed to invest in. But when I look at our base -- so could they do financial planning for Walmart at this point with 1 million SKUs? Probably not. We're not selling financials to Walmart at this point. So it's not really an issue. When I look at our core markets for Financials, there's no company we look at to say they couldn't use Adaptive. Adaptive scales to very large companies. And frankly, I think it was more of an issue of investments in sales and marketing that they only had 7 enterprise sales reps.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Seven?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Seven. Yes. And most of the market, the motion they had was geared towards the SMB and medium enterprise. And so we're taking these into -- this last quarter, we sold to Airbus. We sold to AstraZeneca, H&R Block. These are large Fortune 500 companies. And we went through their performance criterion. We have no concerns at all that it won't scale for them.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Are we likely going to see -- was there a question there? I'm sorry. If there is a question, just raise your hand and we'll get to you. Can you point to any nice go-lives on the planning side, a big Fortune 500 customer?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Well, Workday went live in less than, well, how long was that? 2 months? 2 months. So that was our guess. And now dozens. I couldn't...

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: You're a Fortune 500 company, right?

ANEEL BHUSRI: No, pretty close. Pretty close.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Maybe next year. Maybe next quarter [for run rate].

ANEEL BHUSRI: That's what I'm closest with. No, go-lives in the Adaptive world are different than they are for ERP and for HR. It's a month to 2 months, right? So these are fast go-lives. It's not as complex as a business process transformation. It's really getting the data in and getting the financial processes that you want in place. So they're at the same place we are. 2/3 of their customers are live and they're selling new customers pretty regularly.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Would you say that there's so much awareness of planning that there's pent up demand? Or is it more of Workday bringing some marketing products there and convincing customers? Is it something you got to do?

ANEEL BHUSRI: I'd say it's a bit of both. There's no question that planning is a hot category unto itself. And still even with the legacy planning systems that were out there, there's lots of companies we come across there using Excel to do their planning. And they need a better tool. They need a more secure tool. They need one source of truth. And the cloud has made planning just a lot more accessible to lots of companies than they might have been in the legacy world.

So I think we definitely market and sell it. But there are people on the receiving end who know exactly what they want, and they're in the FP&A group or in the workforce planning group and they're looking for tools like Adaptive. So we're not in the create awareness as much as making sure people realize we're in the space.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: I remember covering Hyperion back in the day and a few other planning companies, Cognos acquired a planning company. Informatica acquired -- not Informatica, but BusinessObjects were quite a planning company as well. There's a big installed base. I mean are you seeing replacements of old legacy?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Absolutely. Yes.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Is that a big base or not big enough...

ANEEL BHUSRI: Yes. In the Fortune 500 market or Fortune 2000 market, almost every company we come across has a legacy of planning. When you get below that, they might be on Excel. When you get to universities, you get to state local government, they might be on Excel. But for the Fortune 2000, they are largely on a legacy planning platform. And in the same way they're replacing human resources or accounting and moving to the cloud, planning is next. And frankly, I've said this before, knowing what I know now, I would have had Workday go into planning before we build core accounting. They're both now in the right place at the right time. But we were definitely swimming upstream with core accounting for many years where the planning market was already happening.

It's a really nice way to wedge into a customer opportunity without having to deal with any of the transaction systems. And if you do a good job on planning, it should lead to other opportunities.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Got it. Got it. I know that you've said that getting and implementing planning puts you in a better position to acquire the financials inside of the business. Now with Adaptive under Workday, is that thesis proving to be [a good one]?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Absolutely. Yes. So we have a pretty sizable HR base, 2,700 customers. 1/4 of those run Financials. So 3/4 are not running our Financials. We get planning in the door. And now they have HR and planning. When they do come to market for core financials in the cloud and 2 out of the 3 things are already run by Workday, I think it puts us in a really good position, especially because the planning piece has now gotten us into the office of the CFO, which HR doesn't. Planning definitely does. And again, if we do a good job for the CFO and we're so focused on customer success, I would hope that, that would bode well for core accounting. So far, it's only a couple of quarters, but the data is pretty positive.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Got it. Got it. To replace planning, legacy planning systems is one thing because that market is comprised of small companies that didn't quite hit the scale. But replacing Financials is a completely different ballgame. So when you look at -- we listened to 2 CFOs at your user conference, fascinating go-live examples, Fortune 100 companies. I'm curious, what do they replace while going live on Workday Financials? I was just stunned that there are 100 countries going live on Workday Financials. What did they replace?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Well, so our typical replacements are the same as they are in HR. It's PeopleSoft, SAP and Oracle. And it's usually because there's a business need. It might be a new set of requirements that they need to deal with. It might be mergers and acquisitions. It might be 606. It might be a whole host of things. And at the same point, they're facing a painful upgrade of the legacy system. That point they look outside. 5 years ago, honestly, for a lot of companies, we just did not have the functional footprint to turn off a legacy system. Companies aren't going to choose Workday and still run a legacy system. It has to be able to turn off the legacy system.

And now I feel very confident that for a typical Fortune 500 company, global, that was a big investment in our part, we can turn it off. And what the customer gets in return is a modern accounting system that deals with all of today's accounting regulations, a system that was built more to be a business partner than just an accounting hub. A system that stays current with all the regulatory and technology changes over time; way, way better analytics, embedded analytics, now integrated planning.

And so the promise of a new financial system is there for the CFO. I would say, historically, they don't like to change systems unless they have to. But now they're reaching end of life on so many of their legacy systems that it's a good time for us now.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: My colleague, John King, yes, he's -- my friend and colleague, John King, covers European technology companies. And he has a question for you. John?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Do you cover SAP?

JOHN PETER KING, RESEARCH ANALYST, BOFAMERRILL LYNCH, RESEARCH DIVISION: I do. (inaudible) that may or may not be related to the question. But just in terms of the verticals you currently address with Financials, will that be the same in 10 years' time, 5 years' time? Is there (inaudible) in the space [that you've seen]?

ANEEL BHUSRI: In 5 years' time, I think it'll stay pretty consistent. And the way to look at us from a financials perspective is our Financials work everywhere that's not manufacturing a retail. And I think over time, we'll get to retail. But manufacturing involves a supply chain and raw materials, and that is not really our goal at this point. And that is -- I think that is still the strength of SAP in particular. If in 5 years' time, that market still has not moved to the cloud, I don't think that market is ready to move to cloud right now. That could be the change between that 5- and 10-year time that we broaden out to be a full scale ERP company. But right now, we're looking at ERP for services companies, not product companies.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: More questions, John? Anything else in your mind? Okay. I want to get into a more mundane topic and get that out of the way.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Other than your outfit?

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Yes.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Does the shirt actually match the jacket?

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: I'm color blind. So...

ANEEL BHUSRI: Obviously.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: But I tried. It's so dark when I wake up. So anyway, I don't know what I'm doing.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Does it match? Is it okay?

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: I don't know. I don't know. Black and brown. The really deep question that I have for you is, is Salesforce going to print an okay quarter?

ANEEL BHUSRI: I sure hope so.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: The whole world is waiting because you guys put up an unbelievable quarter. That was just way beyond the wildest expectation. So there were some interpretations that maybe Workday communicated a shape for the rest of the year that was more back-end loaded. Maybe that was a wrong interpretation. I just wanted to give you the chance to clarify your thoughts again on how the year is likely to shape up. Is it just because you got -- as I look at 2016, you had some massive deals in the -- towards the end. So it's just the renewal cycle that...

ANEEL BHUSRI: I think every year, as we get bigger, our business becomes more seasonal and that's all. And really, what we're just trying to make sure is that all of the analysts are aligning their models with how we see the business unfolding. And it really hasn't changed for the last 6 months. I just think we just want to make sure everybody sees it the way that we're seeing it. We just want to be very transparent on it. But the pipeline is very healthy. I'd say, with Financials, Financials becoming a bigger part of our business. That is definitely more in the Fortune 500 segment, more of a Q4 -- Q3, Q4 business, and that's really all there is. Not -- another big question's about the macro slowdown. We might all see a macro slowdown from these trade discussions. We haven't seen -- we're not seeing one right now.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: That's very good to know. Very good to know. I joke to clients that in the last 10 years, we've had 10 recessions in software because certainly, a stock market have seen average correction peaking 20%, 25%, none of which is accompanied by estimate revision. Something I learned from my boss and he said, with this estimate revision downward, then you know the cycle is starting to go south. But we've not seen estimate revisions go the other way.

So we've had 10 recessions. These are all great buying opportunities.

ANEEL BHUSRI: No. I just think we're in a really interesting time, technology-wise. When I think about cloud and I think about it compared to mainframe and client server, all those technologies kind of petered out because something better came along. And the cloud is the first architecture where it absorbs the next generation, right? So if we're back in the client server days, the machine learning popped up, we have to start from scratch and rewrite everything. In the cloud, the way the architectures work, if you're a truly native cloud like us and Salesforce and ServiceNow, Amazon, Google, truly native cloud, you could have just absorbed machine learning into your foundation.

It's a lot of work. But you don't have to start from scratch and it's not going to replace legacy systems. So it gives the cloud platform a lot longer runway than I think people are used to from past technology cycles where they're worrying about what's next.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Very good point. Yes.

ANEEL BHUSRI: There's no question that machine learning is what's next. And in the old technology, it would have been the disruption that brought in a lot of new entrants. But in this case, all of the native cloud providers are just embracing it and building it into their foundation. So I still see room for startup to do it different, and we're doing it.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Talk about machine learning. There's a brief mention of it on the earnings conference call. How does it play? The next 4 to 5 years, I mean that we might have the data. You're going to be in a very, very good position. How does Workday look at machine learning and the opportunities that are presented to the company?

ANEEL BHUSRI: So I'm a big fan of this book called Prediction Machines. If you haven't read it and you want to get into the economics of machine learning, it's not about the technology, it's about the economics. It's a great read. It's written by 3 professors from the University of Toronto, which is one of the really early pioneers in machine learning and artificial intelligence. And the basic premise of the book and the way Workday looks at it is machines are really good at making predictions. Humans are not -- machines can absorb massive amounts of data and predict the weather. And now on your phone, it'll tell you it's going to rain at 7:18 a.m., and then it starts raining at 7:18 a.m. It's because the predictive capability with machines are so powerful. Humans have judgment, which machines don't have. And I just don't see machines having judgment any time soon.

So think about all the areas where you like your prediction and then a human take advantage of that prediction and make a better decision. My top salesperson is at risk of leaving. Machine tells you that, now you can decide what you want to do with that. You can automate things like audits where a lot of the audit stuff is routine. And you need a senior auditor to look at the exceptions while machine learning can do the basic audit and just flag the ones that require judgment to the senior auditors. Clear planning recommends your next job that you should take based on the thousands of people that have come before you and looking at their career paths...

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: What's the next job that I should take?

ANEEL BHUSRI: What's that? Fashion designer. Well, actually, if you don't know, he's also a great singer. And that's all serious. If you are Facebook friends with him, he does an incredible impression of Freddie Mercury. True. It's really eerie. You've got 3 of the 4 octaves. Is that right?

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Yes. 3 out of the 4 octaves that he has. Yes. But my latest is opera. I've moved on to opera.

ANEEL BHUSRI: So anyways, so coming back. So machine learning to me is going to be a core technology that in 5 years, if your system isn't run by -- we talked about cloud first and mobile first. I think it'll be machine learning first where the systems can make a prediction. Again, the native cloud providers who have all the data in one place have a huge, huge advantage to training the algorithms to get better and better over time. But in 5 years, your HR and finance system is going to predict what might happen and then you're going to make a decision what to do as opposed to having a whole bunch of business analysts trying to figure out -- trying to find that needle in the haystack from the data -- the machine's going to do that for you.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: All right. This is something that we discussed last year and the year prior. It's not something that I really was prepared to ask you. But just curious, we've had change in leadership at Google public cloud; former adversary, now running the show on that front. What is your assessment of Google now under new leadership?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Oh, I didn't know about Oracle. I still don't know. By all accounts, he's a very talented executive. And I look forward to meeting him. Google is a good partner and a customer. So I suspect that we'll get a chance to meet. I didn't have any interest in meeting him when he was at Oracle. So he didn't have any interest in meeting me. So I don't -- I think that Microsoft and Amazon are really well positioned for the enterprise cloud. I don't know as much about the consumer cloud, but for the enterprise cloud, they're really well positioned. And Google has fabulous technology and they just have to figure out how to bring it to the enterprise. And Thomas has the enterprise chops to do it. So we'll see.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Any thoughts as it pertains to -- I know you worked with Microsoft, you worked with more so with Amazon Web Services. Between the 2, how do you see them in the public cloud? I know they have their own revenues and sweet spots. Is there any change in the way the wind is blowing with respect to the public cloud between these 2? Or their positions has secure relatively changes that you see there?

ANEEL BHUSRI: So we work at this point exclusively with Amazon and the AWS platform. And I would just say it is a phenomenal technology platform. And contrary to what people talk about, well, we don't compete with Amazon. As a customer, they are a wonderful company to work with. Any things we bring up, any feature requests we have, we get a direct line into Andy Jassy and they build it out into the platform. It's an amazing platform. I don't know as much about Microsoft. But what -- I know about the Azure platform is that when I sit down with the CIO of a company and they're thinking about their movement into the cloud, they're both kind of settling on AWS and Microsoft as the 2. Very few companies are just going all-in on one cloud platform. Nobody wants to be just completely dependent on one. So they tend to go to 2. And if I were to -- you guys don't tweet in here, do you?

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: We're not allowed.

ANEEL BHUSRI: I think technology-wise, the best platform is AWS. In terms of enterprise, go-to-market, Microsoft is superb. They know how to go-to-market enterprise. And so the race is AWS becoming more enterprise savvy and Microsoft trying to catch up on the technology side. When you look at things like voice, machine learning, big data, the AWS platform is just phenomenal. It's just a phenomenal platform. There's almost nothing you can't do.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: That's really good to know. Really good to know. RPA came up on the conference call. And you said like you're still investigating the technology. Wondering if you have any updated thoughts there.

ANEEL BHUSRI: People have been saying that it cuts deployment times by half. That was aspirational coming from the startup vendors. There's no proof points to that. So we're partnering and investing in those companies. And we're going to say, okay, well, show us. And if they can show us how they reduce deployment times and how they can do some of this process automation, great. I'm not sure we need to be in this space, but we definitely need to be close to it. And so we've made a couple of investments. We're obviously a sizable investor in automation anywhere. We work with them closely. But we -- I just want to see more proof that it's actually paying the dividends that everybody is -- that all the vendors are talking about.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Yes. Yes. Fair enough. That's fair enough. I wanted also get your thoughts on benefits market. I know you mentioned that, that could be an area that could be more opportunistic for you, for Workday. Any thoughts there, benefits provider and automating that whole supply chain?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Yes. So right now, we're really a platform for benefits enrollment. We could definitely go further. We integrate into all the carriers. We call it the benefits exchange. We could definitely get into more of a model where that looks more like a BPO. Who knows if we go there. I'm not sure -- I don't think it's going to happen anytime soon. But almost every one of the HR-related services that we have our customers say, not just run the technology, can you actually run the full functional area for us. And to date, we partnered at a minimum. I think you'll just see more partnerships for us in that area. So I think like a PEO provider, like trying that great company. All those kinds of companies have an underlying backbone of technology and they're historically all PeopleSoft. And as those systems age out, I would hope that we could access some of the market through partnership or maybe more.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: We heard from Microsoft earlier today about their vision and ambition for the workflow automation market. ServiceNow has been talking about it for quite some time. What is in that market? You're one of the most experienced entrepreneurs in software and investor as well. What is this market that everybody is excited about? And what does Workday think about this?

ANEEL BHUSRI: I think it's a -- it's still unclear to me what exactly it is. Historically, standalone workflow companies do not turn into big companies. ServiceNow is different because they automate IT. They automate help desk and they're moving into areas like workflow. All of the vendors, Salesforce, Workday, we all have our own workflow platforms. I think as we roll out Workday Cloud, you'll see customers using us to extend workflows. But I don't see it as a repeatable standalone market. It's just an extension of what vendors are doing. And I think that's probably the way Microsoft sees it, too. The bigger thing we see out of Microsoft is their focus on teams.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: And tell us about that, I mean I'm hearing more and more about teams.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Well, so the product is gaining steam. And it's not necessarily showing up in Silicon Valley. Most of the tech companies still use Slack. But you go outside of Silicon Valley and you see a lot of deployments to teams. So we're working hard with Microsoft to...

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Are you deploying...

ANEEL BHUSRI: Well, we're not deploying yet. We might down the road. But we're working hard with Microsoft to tie our systems together so teams and our systems are seamlessly connected. And what we've done prototype-wise is really, really cool, and I want to [turn it to...]

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: [Doing that. I'm doing that] all over the place. I'm doing it. Yes. It's good to see.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Microsoft's in 17 different categories, right? I mean they're in all the different categories. I can just tell you this one is important to them.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Satya spent a lot of time on the conference.

ANEEL BHUSRI: Yes. And it's a product that was rough around the edges to say the least 2 years ago. And today, it's a really cool product.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: It's good to know. Final chance, John, anybody else with a question? Just raise your hand. If there aren't any -- John, yes, please go ahead.

JOHN PETER KING: Yes. Maybe just tell us, what's the big R&D focus right now for the business? What's going to make a difference to the TAM over the next couple of years that you're building out?

ANEEL BHUSRI: We continue to invest in our existing suite of products, HR, Financials, Planning. But I would say the 2 big areas are analytics and tied to analytics is a lot of the machine learning investment. And we are not building machine learning as a feature for a few applications. We're building it really into the foundational platform. That's a big investment. And then the Workday Cloud Platform, opening up the platform to our customers to extend Workday apps down the road to ISVs, and that's probably one of the bigger areas of investment.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Unless you have any closing thoughts, why don't we wrap it up a minute early?

ANEEL BHUSRI: Thank you. 25 years, congratulations.

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Thank you. Thank you very much. I really appreciate it.

ANEEL BHUSRI: You going to sing for us?

KASTHURI GOPALAN RANGAN: Cocktails at 5:00. Everybody, so I'm throwing a big party at 5:00. So drinks on me on the house. So please. And if I get a little bit tipsy, maybe I'll sing a few lines. Thank you again, Aneel. It's a real delight to be able to host you.

It’s Time to Start Regaining Their Trust2018-05-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisNEWSTAGWorking Fervently Toward the Bottom Line Is Isolating Consumers. It’s Time to Start Regaining Their TrustJoe Toscano

Since 2013 when Edward Snowden released documents about the NSA’s internal workings, the world has started to question the way their data is collected and used against them. Since then, findings by Pew Research Center show that 93 percent of adults believe it is important they can control who can get information about them, 90 percent believe it is important they have control over what information is collected about them and 93 percent have taken steps to remove or mask their digital footprints. But despite these numbers, 59 percent still feel like it is impossible to remain anonymous online and 68 percent believes current laws do not do enough to protect their privacy.

More recently, the abusive behavior of Big Tech companies and large corporations, in general, have only led to an even deeper state of distrust. This is especially true among millennials, who research has shown to hold a large amount of distrust in the traditional pillars of our world. But despite these facts, businesses have decided to carry on as usual, without consideration for the long-term impact this may have on their brand. In a marketplace of trust, this will not be sustainable. But how do we change this? The answer is simple: Optimize for trust.

For the longest time we’ve pushed businesses to focus on impressions, unique visits, lowering bounce rates and other forms of engagement in order to quantify success. This has become a standard in the new attention economy where data is king and has become the currency of the new economy. But if we really take time to think about it, this is exactly the problem. Focusing exclusively on getting the population glued to the screen so we can mine their data is one of the largest threats to the security of businesses—especially at this point in history where consumers are losing trust for those mining their data faster than ever.

Changing the public’s perception will mean ensuring clients are checking the boxes on the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and future regulations. The changes consumers want to see go beyond surface-level tactics and implementation. It will require making a change from the core of the company, from the brand level. And in order to help catalyze these changes, it’s time we leverage our role as digital consultants to push businesses forward. It’s time we figure out creative ways to not only measure success but also reimagine what it means to be successful in general.

An example of what this might look like is what Couchsurfing does. Instead of focusing solely on engagement or other common metrics, they use an equation that looks more like this:

(Number of Days Spent Together x Number of Hours in a Day) – (Time Spent on Site) = Good Hours spent with Couchsurfing

Obviously, there are some potential flaws to their system because time spent together doesn’t necessarily mean quality time. But they recognize this, and in order to ensure quality beyond traditional quantitative metrics, they also ask about how the experience was through long-form questionnaires. This combination of quantitative and qualitative analysis allows their business to pursue its mission without focusing on getting people to drain their life away glued to the screen. In fact, as you can see in their equation, time on site — or screen-based engagement — is actually considered negative to their business model because it’s also been proven to be damaging to society.

Similar actions have been taken by companies like Netflix who use their platform data to monitor binging and reach out to those who have been consuming content beyond healthy levels. This may not be best for Netflix’s bottom line, but it’s about the long-term relationship with customers, not the next quarter. By refocusing their mission to create a positive impact on society, these companies are actively working to gain consumer trust by creating a business model that not only drives revenue but also creates positive social impact and sustainable business practices.

For retailers, this may mean discovering ways to optimize the number of people who refer their friends after making a purchase. For travel businesses, this may mean focusing on how to optimize the number of the travel destinations, restaurants and experiences that get recommended and are both visited and enjoyed by the consumer. For educational programs, this might mean optimizing the number of students who graduate feeling confident in their skills and have become critical thinkers, not just test takers who get a certificate. These are abstract and not easy to quantitatively measure, but not everything that’s good is.

The idea of gaining trust is one of the biggest focuses of Tristan Harris and his new foundation, the Center for Humane Technology. It is similar to the story expressed by Airbnb co-founder Joe Gebbia in his TED Talk, “How Airbnb Designs for Trust,” and again by Rachel Botsman in her TED Talk, “The Currency of the New Economy is Trust.” The focus of all of these experts is to point out that while KPIs and other success metrics may give us a better objective understanding of what’s going on, it’s not easy to objectively define success. But only by exploring the limitations of these quantitative analyses can we begin to understand the real issues in a way that allows us to creatively pursue meaningful business models.

Working with companies to creatively figure out how they can optimize for trust will be one of the biggest challenges of this modern era we live in. Solving these issues won’t be easy and solutions won’t happen overnight, but discovering ways to win back the trust of consumers across the globe is where the real opportunity for innovation exists. It will no doubt become the key to keeping the doors open, and the agencies that are capable of creatively persuading their clients to strategically optimize for trust will be the ones that come out on top.

urn:contentItem:5RNW-3MX1-JBKM-D2J2-00000-00Work permits in limbo Spouses of H1-B tech workers might lose right to work in the U.S., which could spur some to leave the country2018-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisROP ZONEPg. D1Work permits in limbo Spouses of H1-B tech workers might lose right to work in the U.S., which could spur some to leave the countryRachel LermanSeattle Times business reporter

The day that Anushka Bishen learned she would be able to get a work permit, she sat down and cried with joy.

She had moved from India to the U.S. three years earlier to join her husband and had been unable to work the entire time despite having a master's degree in international public relations from Cardiff University in the U.K. and a background in communications and marketing at two companies in India.

She came to the country legally with a spousal visa, or H-4, granted to the wives and husbands of those who have H-1B, or high-tech, visas. But H-4 visas didn't allow a person to work in the U.S. - until 2015, when the Obama administration enacted a rule that opened the way for people with spousal visas to obtain permits known as employment authorization documents (EAD).

"It was such an emotional moment for me," Bishen said of the day she heard about the new rule. "It gave me my life back," said the Bellevue resident, who is now a communications specialist on the Eastside.

The relief of H-4 visa holders hasn't lasted long, however. Bishen and spouses who received the work authorizations are now in limbo since the Trump administration indicated it plans to end the program this year. If that happens before they can get new work permits, spouses of H-1B holders in the Seattle area will have to decide whether to stop working in the United States or leave the country.

Microsoft and Amazon are routinely listed among the top applicants for H-1B visas, each applying for thousands of the permits each year. The high-tech visa program allows about 85,000 people each year to enter the country after company sponsors prove their high-end skills cannot be found elsewhere.

Spousal visas allow H-1B visa holders to bring their partners with them to the U.S., women and men who are usually also highly educated. Because of the Puget Sound region's high concentration of tech companies, a large portion of those spouses end up here.

Some of them thought they might be able to get their own H-1Bs, but those are in high-demand and hard to obtain. Some assumed they could get permanent residence status, or green cards, once they arrived in the country. But obtaining that status can take years.

Green cards are capped each year, and no single country can receive more than 7 percent of the total. That makes it faster to get the permits for people from some countries - say, Norway, because there are fewer applicants.

Meanwhile, applicants from India, China or the Philippines, which generate many more green-card requests, can wait decades.

That meant that many H-4 spouses, usually women, who were used to holding corporate jobs couldn't work in the U.S. if they joined their partners here.

For Bishen, her first three years in the U.S. without a job were marked with depression and a loss of independence. She had to use her husband's credit card for everything, even to buy him a gift. She volunteered with nonprofits, but felt useless in a society that puts a strong importance on people's professions.

"It hurt me on many emotional levels," she said. "I didn't want to become a shadow of my husband."

That changed with the implementation of the Obama-era rule that sped up the work-permit process for spouses with H-4 visas. Once they applied for a green card with approved employer support, they could obtain an employment-authorization document, allowing them to work while waiting for a green card, which could take more than 10 years.

"These families are Americans-in-waiting," said Doug Rand, co-founder of Seattle immigration-technology startupBoundless, explaining the rationale for the program. Rand was the assistant director for entrepreneurship in the Obama administration and helped implement the 2015 rule.

Since it took effect, about 104,750 H-4 spouses have been approved for work authorizations, according to the latest data through June 2017 from U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services.

So far, a notice in a federal agenda is the only information about the federal government's plans to change the rule.

"DHS is proposing to remove from its regulations certain H-4 spouses of H-1B non-immigrants as a class of aliens eligible for employment authorization," it read. The agency has indicated it could propose details of the rule this month.

For now, it's unclear if people with current permits could keep working, or what form the new rule would take. A public-comment period would open before the new rule could take effect.

Representatives from the Department of Homeland Security did not respond to requests for comment.

The standing 2015 rule is the subject of a continuing lawsuit filed by a group that contends the Obama administration did not have the authority to enact the rule - that it should be up to Congress.

Attorney John Miano, a fellow at the Center for Immigration Studies who is representing the group, contends that spousal recipients of work permits should be counted against the country's H-1B quota, not given a separate allocation.

The upcoming rule from the Trump administration could help avoid "an Obama-created train wreck," he said.

"This is the first administration I can remember that's actually said it wants to do anything to protect American workers," Miano added.

The proposed rule change jibes with 2017's "Buy American, Hire American" act, which set out the Trump administration's desire to reform the H-1B visa program and focus on hiring workers who are U.S. citizens.

Not much has come of H-1B reforms, apart from whispers and speculation about the administration cracking down. A bill winding its way through the Senate would actually increase the quota of H-1B visas and guarantee some spousal work permits.

Unlike H-1B visas, the employment-authorization documents that H-4 spouses can obtain are not tied to a specific employer.

To Priya Chandrasekaran, that means spouses have largely been on their own in their efforts to protect the program. She runs the Washington chapter of an advocacy group, Save H4-EAD, that is lobbying lawmakers to keep the work-permit program in place.

"I'm super paranoid that I'll be asked to stay home and not work," said Chandrasekaran, who holds one of the H-4 work authorizations and is an accountant in Lynn­wood. "I'm worried about the financial stability of our family."

The wives and husbands do have some institutional backing, however, from their spouses' employers. Amazon and Microsoft both said they support the continuation of the spousal work program and are in contact with members of Congress.

"We've urged the administration to retain H-4 spousal work authorization, given its importance to our employees and their spouses who are stuck in a decades-long green-card backlog," Microsoft President Brad Smith said in a statement.

But there's no guarantee the backing from Big Tech will help, and the uncertainty of their employment status is adding to the anxiety of H-4 spouses.

Devayani Charde is weighing whether she will have to move to Canada in a few months. She'd prefer not to - it would mean once again going through a lengthy process of getting licensed for her job.

The 32-year-old was a licensed physical therapist in India before she immigrated to the U.S. in 2013 to join her husband, who has an H-1B visa. She spent two years taking equivalency courses in the U.S. to become licensed as a doctor of physical therapy. And after getting a work authorization, she got a job as a physical therapist in Seattle.

She doesn't want to stop working - especially after the investment she made in getting her U.S. license - and also doesn't want to live away from her husband.

"It's like my own identity," she said, explaining the importance of having a job. "When you're in this society or meet people, you are known for what you are and what you do. I felt like it was saying 'you're going to lose your identity,' " she said, referring to the threat of losing her work permit.

Spouses of H-1B recipients are often as highly skilled and qualified as their high-tech partners, said Amy Bhatt, an associate professor of gender and women's studies at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Bhatt, who earned a doctorate in feminist studies from the University of Washington, wrote a book about wives from India living in the Puget Sound region.

Before the 2015 work authorizations for H-4 spouses, many of the women she spoke with spent their time volunteering with startups to keep their skills sharp.

"We ended up with all these women in the economy but not necessarily being recognized as part of the economy," she said.

There was a strong push from tech companies for the 2015 rule, she said, because they wanted to keep their H-1B workers and attract more. Domestic-violence victim advocacy organizations also pushed for the rule, arguing that not allowing women to work made them more financially and emotionally dependent on their husbands.

It comes down to a feeling of self-worth, Bishen, the Bellevue resident, said. The women are legal immigrants, she pointed out, and want to contribute to society.

"I cannot even think about going back to those dark times" before 2015, she said. "There's much at stake."

urn:contentItem:5T19-TBN1-JD3N-537G-00000-00Work with us or die: Facebook2018-08-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 1Work with us or die: FacebookDARREN DAVIDSON MEDIA EDITOR, EXCLUSIVE

A senior Facebook executive has privately admitted Mark Zuckerberg "doesn't care" about publishers and warned that if they did not work with the social media giant, "I'll be holding your hands with your dying business like in a -hospice".

In extraordinary comments, Campbell Brown, Facebook's global head of news partnerships, indicated to publishers and broad-casters in a four-hour meeting last week that despite Mr Zuckerberg's view, she would help publishers build sustainable business models through Facebook.

"Mark doesn't care about publishers but is giving me a lot of leeway and concessions to make these changes," Ms Brown said.

"We will help you revitalise journalism â€¦ in a few years the -reverse looks like I'll be holding your hands with your dying -business like in a hospice." Facebook denies the comments were made. But five people at the behind-closed-doors meeting in Sydney on Tuesday, which was attended by more than 20 TV and publishing executives, have corroborated to The Australian that such phrasing was used.

Ms Brown is a former CNN prime-time host who was recruited by Mr Zuckerberg to improve rocky relationships with the news media.

Ms Brown issued a statement to The Australian saying: "These quotes are simply not accurate and don't reflect the discussion we had in the meeting.

"We know there's much more to do, but our goal at Facebook - what the team works on every day with publishers and reporters around the world - is to help journalism succeed and thrive, both on our platform and off.

"That means a new focus on building sustainable business models, and that's what the discussion was about." When contacted about the comments, as relayed to The Australian by the five sources, Facebook indicated the meeting was recorded, but declined to release a full recording of the meeting. Facebook's role in the media is coming under increasing global scrutiny as a high-powered investigation by the Australian competition regulator examines the impact of the tech giants on journalism and Mr Zuckerberg is blamed for the spread of fake news on Facebook after the 2016 US presidential election.

News media is suffering as people turn to Facebook and other big tech platforms as a primary destination for news and -information. The problem is that most money generated by news content flows largely to Facebook and Google, not to the journalists reporters and publishers.

Resistance from some publishers to Facebook's proposals exposes a clash of ideas about how to extricate commercially funded publishers and broad-casters from a worsening economic state. Ms Brown's comments, according to the five sources, contradict the message Mr Zuckerberg has given in interviews, speeches and hearings -before the US congress in April.Media P24

urn:contentItem:60C4-FYG1-JBHT-D3Y0-00000-00World: Apple, Ireland win 13 billion tax appeal in blow to EU2020-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSWorld: Apple, Ireland win 13 billion tax appeal in blow to EUBangkokFULL TEXT

A European Union court has ruled in favor of Apple in an appeal of an order to pay Ireland 13 billion euros in back taxes. The ruling complicates EU efforts to rein in tech giants in Europe.

Europe's second-highest court on Wednesday overturned a ruling ordering tech giant Apple to reimburse Ireland for 13 billion ($15 billion) in back taxes.

The General Court ruled in favor of Apple and Ireland in a joint appeal of a 2016 ruling from the European Commission, saying the US tech firm does not have to pay the sum.

"The General Court annuls the contested decision because the Commission did not succeed in showing to the requisite legal standard that there was an advantage for the purposes of Article 107(1) TFEU1," judges in Luxembourg said in a statement, making reference to EU competition rules.

"The Commission was wrong to declare'' that Apple "had been granted a selective economic advantage and, by extension, state aid," the statement read.

The Commission has two months to appeal the decision at the European Court of Justice - the bloc's highest court - on points of law only.

EU targeted big tech in 2016 ruling

A 2016 ruling from European Commission said the iPhone maker had benefited from illegal state aid owing to two Irish court decisions that allegedly artificially reduced Apple's tax burden.

The decision was part of a series of anti-trust cases that targeted major US firms including Starbucks, McDonald's and Amazon.

The Commission had ruled that tax deals struck by Apple and other companies with countries such as Ireland, the Netherlands and Luxembourg constitute illegal state aid, a violation of EU regulations.

Both Apple and Ireland appealed that ruling leading to Wednesday's decision.

Apple has had a base in the southern city of Cork since 1980, where it employs more than 5,000 people and through which it routes international sales, avoiding billions in corporate taxes.

Vindication for Apple and Ireland

"This case was not about how much tax we pay, but where we are required to pay it. We're proud to be the largest taxpayer in the world as we know the important role tax payments play in society," Apple said in response to the Wednesday ruling.

The government of Ireland said it had "always been clear" Apple received no special treatment, adding, "The correct amount of Irish tax was charged... in line with normal Irish taxation rules."

The country's biggest opposition party Sinn Fein criticized the decision, with spokesman Pearse Doherty saying it was "a bad day for the Irish taxpayer."

DW business reporter Arthur Sullivan called the ruling a "big blow" for the EU, but said it was important to distinguish between this specific case and the wider fight against tax avoidance.

"This case looked at the issue of illegal state aid. Did Apple's specific arrangements in Ireland amount to illegal state aid. The courts today said it didn't," Sullivan said.

"However...the competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager has been increasingly looking to tackle this issue. We're seeing the Commission is increasingly willing to use tools they've never used before, such as bringing in voting on changes to the corporate tax structure in the EU...If that comes in, that would mean the fight is still very much on."

Profit shifting under scrutiny

The ruling is a setback to the Commission's fight - led by Vestager - to reduce the practice of profit shifting whereby multinational companies shift profits from a high tax jurisdiction to a lower one.

"The Commission will continue to look at aggressive tax planning measures under EU state aid rules to assess whether they result in illegal state aid," she said, following the ruling.

The EU's lower court last year overturned a ruling that had ordered Starbucks to pay 30 billion in Dutch back taxes. In a separate case, the court threw out a ruling against a Belgian tax scheme for 39 multinationals.

The ruling is likely to be taken into account in pending cases against Ikea, Nike, and other international firms.

The decision comes amid an EU campaign to increase taxation and limit the power of digital behemoths like Apple, though some member states are opposed.

Ireland's economy has benefited from the presence of multinational corporations attracted by the country's low tax rates. Dublin is seen as unwilling to accept a ruling suggesting that its tax laws are too lax.

Source: DW - Deutsche Welle

urn:contentItem:60C4-3NN1-JB5P-J39X-00000-00World: Apple, Ireland win 13 billion tax appeal in blow to EU2020-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSWorld: Apple, Ireland win 13 billion tax appeal in blow to EU

A European Union court has ruled in favor of Apple in an appeal of an order to pay Ireland 13 billion euros in back taxes. The ruling complicates EU efforts to rein in tech giants in Europe.

Europe's second-highest court on Wednesday overturned a ruling ordering tech giant Apple to reimburse Ireland for 13 billion ($15 billion) in back taxes.

The General Court ruled in favor of Apple and Ireland in a joint appeal of a 2016 ruling from the European Commission, saying the US tech firm does not have to pay the sum.

"The General Court annuls the contested decision because the Commission did not succeed in showing to the requisite legal standard that there was an advantage for the purposes of Article 107(1) TFEU1," judges in Luxembourg said in a statement, making reference to EU competition rules.

"The Commission was wrong to declare'' that Apple "had been granted a selective economic advantage and, by extension, state aid," the statement read.

The Commission has two months to appeal the decision at the European Court of Justice - the bloc's highest court - on points of law only.

EU targeted big tech in 2016 ruling

A 2016 ruling from European Commission said the iPhone maker had benefited from illegal state aid owing to two Irish court decisions that allegedly artificially reduced Apple's tax burden.

The decision was part of a series of anti-trust cases that targeted major US firms including Starbucks, McDonald's and Amazon.

The Commission had ruled that tax deals struck by Apple and other companies with countries such as Ireland, the Netherlands and Luxembourg constitute illegal state aid, a violation of EU regulations.

Both Apple and Ireland appealed that ruling leading to Wednesday's decision.

Apple has had a base in the southern city of Cork since 1980, where it employs more than 5,000 people and through which it routes international sales, avoiding billions in corporate taxes.

Vindication for Apple and Ireland

"This case was not about how much tax we pay, but where we are required to pay it. We're proud to be the largest taxpayer in the world as we know the important role tax payments play in society," Apple said in response to the Wednesday ruling.

The government of Ireland said it had "always been clear" Apple received no special treatment, adding, "The correct amount of Irish tax was charged... in line with normal Irish taxation rules."

The country's biggest opposition party Sinn Fein criticized the decision, with spokesman Pearse Doherty saying it was "a bad day for the Irish taxpayer."

DW business reporter Arthur Sullivan called the ruling a "big blow" for the EU, but said it was important to distinguish between this specific case and the wider fight against tax avoidance.

"This case looked at the issue of illegal state aid. Did Apple's specific arrangements in Ireland amount to illegal state aid. The courts today said it didn't," Sullivan said.

"However...the competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager has been increasingly looking to tackle this issue. We're seeing the Commission is increasingly willing to use tools they've never used before, such as bringing in voting on changes to the corporate tax structure in the EU...If that comes in, that would mean the fight is still very much on."

Profit shifting under scrutiny

The ruling is a setback to the Commission's fight - led by Vestager - to reduce the practice of profit shifting whereby multinational companies shift profits from a high tax jurisdiction to a lower one.

"The Commission will continue to look at aggressive tax planning measures under EU state aid rules to assess whether they result in illegal state aid," she said, following the ruling.

The EU's lower court last year overturned a ruling that had ordered Starbucks to pay 30 billion in Dutch back taxes. In a separate case, the court threw out a ruling against a Belgian tax scheme for 39 multinationals.

The ruling is likely to be taken into account in pending cases against Ikea, Nike, and other international firms.

The decision comes amid an EU campaign to increase taxation and limit the power of digital behemoths like Apple, though some member states are opposed.

Ireland's economy has benefited from the presence of multinational corporations attracted by the country's low tax rates. Dublin is seen as unwilling to accept a ruling suggesting that its tax laws are too lax.

Source: DW - Deutsche Welle

urn:contentItem:5Y80-PK21-JB5P-J366-00000-00World: Artificial intelligence: How is the EU planning to make up ground on US and Chinese firms?2020-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:44ZLexisNexisGENERAL NEWSWorld: Artificial intelligence: How is the EU planning to make up ground on US and Chinese firms?

After much brainstorming, the EU has unveiled how it plans to catch the US and China when it comes to artificial intelligence (AI).

Ursula von der Leyen, announcing the new strategy, said AI could be hugely lucrative but that it came with key risks.

Here we take a look at what Brussels wants to do, why and what critics think of the plan.

What is artificial intelligence?

Artificial intelligence sees machines use intelligence typically associated with humans, such as learning from mistakes and adjusting to new inputs.

Examples include self-driving cars, voice-powered personal assistants like Amazon's Alexa and the latest e-mail spam filters.

Why is the EU acting now?

"AI is developing fast, which is why Europe needs to maintain and increase its level of investment," said the European Commission in a press briefing. "At the same time, AI entails a number of potential risks that need to be addressed."

The risks include concerns around citizens' privacy, human rights and livelihood.

But the benefits are huge, according to European Commission President Von der Leyen.

"It is 300 billion right away, this is 2.4% of the Gross Domestic Product - this is today. In five years, it will be estimated three times as much," she said. "Today, we have 5.7 million jobs, in five years, these will - estimated - be about 11 million jobs."

There are also fears Europe is lagging behind other parts of the world.

Data recently published by the World Intellectual Property Organisation showed that Chinese and US firms account for about 85% of AI-related patents globally.

What's in the strategy?

The EU says it wants to develop a "framework for trustworthy artificial intelligence", focusing on three key objectives:

Technology that works for people; A fair and competitive economy; and An open, democratic and sustainable society. Practically, authorities should be able to test and certify the data used by the algorithms that power artificial intelligence in the same way they check cosmetics, cars and toys, the bloc said.

The focus for such preliminary certification is on high-risk systems rather than on all AI "in order to avoid unnecessary burden for companies to innovate", the strategy said.

Examples of high-risk sectors include medical equipment, automated driving, or decisions on social security payments.

The EU also wants to use unbiased data to train high-risk artificial intelligence systems so they can avoid discrimination.

EU leaders said they wanted to open a debate on when to allow facial recognition in remote identification systems, which are used to scan crowds to check people's faces to those on a database.

It's considered the "most intrusive form" of the technology and is prohibited in the EU except in special cases.

The EU strategy includes an ambitious investment plan of 20 billion per year over the next decade, against 3.2 billion in 2016.

How much support do the proposals have?

Initial reactions to the proposals in Europe were overall positive.

Interviewed on Euronews Now, MEP Eva Maydell, of the European People's Part,y hailed the strategy as "future-oriented".

She said it would pave the way for European companies to be more competitive.

Andrea Renda, head of regulatory policy at CEPS, a think-tank, told Euronews that he was "very enthusiastic" about the EU's new proposals and their ambition.

"Part of this package is to ensure that Europe is fit for the digital age, and part of it is that the digital age becomes fit for Europe," the expert said.

This includes ensuring the development of AI technology becomes aligned with fundamental rights and European values, he added.

Digital Europe, a trade association representing the digital industry, welcomed the new strategy in a statement.

"Rather than rush to regulate emerging technologies, we are pleased to see a commitment to work with industry and civil society and enhance the EU's robust legal framework where there are gaps. It will be important to keep new regulation focused and limited to truly high-risk cases," said Digital Europe Director General Cecilia Bonefeld-Dahl.

What do critics say?

Some actors in the industry are worried that it will be difficult to define the nature and scope of high-risk cases. They also fear that the kind of preliminary certification envisioned by the EU will make the process more complex and bureaucratic.

The new regulations will have far-reaching implications for US tech giants such as Facebook, Google or Apple.

"American companies, large cloud operators, will probably see their potential future market share shrink a little bit as a result of these proposals," Renda noted.

On Monday, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met top European Union officials as the company warned that potential regulation risked stifling innovation.

However, In an op-ed published in the Financial Times, Zuckerberg said big tech companies such as Facebook need closer government supervision.

"I believe good regulation may hurt Facebook's business in the near term but it will be better for everyone, including us, over the long term,'' he wrote. He said new rules should be clear and balanced and it shouldn't be left up to individual companies to set their own standards.

On the consumers' side, critics say the strategy could go even further to protect rights and privacy.

Too much data is currently concentrated in the hands of a few industry players who use it exclusively for their benefit, said Monique Goyens, Director General of The European Consumer Organisation (BEUC)

It is good that the EU wants to legislate how data can be used better but when it comes to personal data, it must always be the consumer to decide whether their data is collected and how it is shared.

How do EU policies compare to other global players?

The EU has become a major global player in tech regulation. It has already pioneered strict data privacy rules and issued multibillion-dollar antitrust fines against the likes of Google.

Some of the bloc's new proposals, such as preliminary certification for high-risk AI, are completely novel.

"It is the first time at the global level that a policy-maker comes up with such a comprehensive framework for constraining and steering the development of AI technology," Renda said, adding that the policy could become a "reference for policy-makers all over the world."

The EU focus on regulations comes in sharp contrast with the US approach, which is based on flexible guidelines rather than binding rules.

Another major challenge for the bloc is regulatory fragmentation - tech companies trying to access the EU market face a myriad of different national regulations, unlike the US or Chinese markets. Digital actors hope the bloc's new strategy will offer an opportunity to tackle the issue.

What's next?

The EU strategy is open for public consultations until May 19 and will be fine-tuned based on feedback. An impact assessment will also be conducted.

"The Commission has not rushed its own thinking for a legislative proposal within the first 100 days," Renda told Euronews.

"This White Paper enables us to have a period of reflection, to continue discussing where we want to go in the next five, 10, 15 yeas," Maydell said.

Further regulations will be introduced later this year, the Commission said, including "a Digital Services Act to establish clear rules for all businesses to access the Single Market, to strengthen the responsibility of online platforms and to protect fundamental rights."

Source: Euronews
